column8: Adams Peak not worth the trouble
column11: We were a bit unlucky with the weather, so no sunrise, but also no rain. We were there in the off-season. There was virtually nothing open on the path and even they were not welcoming. There was a lot of construction, repairs along the route. People were hard at work. A little tragic were the people who carried the goods and building materials up the 5,000 stairs on their heads. At times great views. An absolute challenge! Once on top, nothing.  Wire mesh fence. In low season, the Sri Pada is also not accessible. And then it goes down again. 5500 uneven steps and stairs with shaking legs. I did it - because my friend wanted it so badly - and she turned halfway around. I wanted to know why everyone wants to go up there. There's no reason. Sorry! The area is beautiful! Look at them! But Adams Peak - unless you're a pilgrim or an extreme athlete - wasn't worth it to me.
The summit delivers a breathtaking sunrise, often painting the horizon and casting a triangular shadow of the peak‚Äîa mystical visual and spiritual climax

I've prayed at Sri Pada more than six times, and every visit feels just as sacred as the first. It's one of the most important pilgrimage sites for Buddhists and truly a spiritual treasure. The peaceful energy, the climb, and the sunrise make it a life-changing experience. One of the most loved places in my journey

column8: A Hidden Gem to Adam‚Äôs Peak ‚Äì The Untamed Sadagalathanna Trail
column11: If you're looking for a raw, off-the-beaten-path adventure to Sri Lanka‚Äôs sacred Adam‚Äôs Peak (Sri Pada), the Sadagalathanna Trail is the way to go. Unlike the more popular Hatton or Ratnapura routes, this trail offers a solitary, mystical journey through untouched wilderness, making the climb feel like a true pilgrimage.

column8: Not a great experience due to overcrowding
column11: We set off at 2am with an informative local guide. We had proper footwear and layers in case of cold. The whole experience was underwhelming : huge amount of commercial outlets all the way up , hordes of pilgrims and we were unable to get to the summit as there was a 2 - 3 hour wait to get up the last 200m and we would have missed the sunrise. Our guide took us on some short cuts over fairly treacherous terrain to avoid the crowds. The climb is fairly exhausting with 5500 uneven steps in depth and height even though we were relatively fit 65 year olds. There was a lot of litter everywhere. I don‚Äôt it‚Äôs worth the hassle. Sigiriya Rock and walking the Pekoe Trail were way better experiences
My bone of my Legs hurt!! I can't sleep. I was Shivering due to the temperature Is too Much Cold. This is no coming back for this. I will never do this again. FOREVER!!!

It was a mental and physical challenge! One of the best life experiences ever! If you want to do the peak you certainly prepare well. Be sure to check the weather. The higher you sit the colder and windier it can get! Take plenty of breaks! It is worth it üí™

Sri Pada or Adam‚Äôs Peak is an ancient pilgrimage site, which has long attracted thousands of pilgrims from all faiths. This conical mountain is 7,360 feet (2,250 meters )high, soaring clear above the surrounding mountain ranges. The mountain is located in the southern reaches of the Central Highlands in the Ratnapura District and Nuwara Eliya district of the Sabaragamuwa Province and Central Province ‚Äîlying about 40 km northeast of the city of Ratnapura and 19 km southwest of the city of Maskeliya. The surrounding region is largely forested hills, with no mountain of comparable size nearby.

column8: An adventure for climbers but with great caution as no facilities available in case of emergencies.
column11: While it is an adventure, it is not for the weak, the sick, people with health conditions, and definitely not for the old.

Climbing Adam‚Äôs Peak is highly recommended. From the sporting side, the more than 5000 steps from Dalhousie are easy to climb for fit in 2 hours.  In fact, the sunrise is very atmospheric, so set off about 2:30 or 3:00. There is little space on top and a cold wind whistles, so take change clothes and jacket as well as headgear! The descent is a little faster with about 1 1‚ÅÑ2 hours. But it depends very much on the amount of pilgrims. Around the full moon the traffic jam is guaranteed and then it can take a sensitive longer time, they say. No guide is necessary, because you can't get lost. Only on the top there are at least 2 exits. So don't confuse here where you came from.

We went up the 5200 steps in November 2024. It was not yet a pilgrimage season and therefore deserted. Except for a handful of locals and monks we didn't meet anyone and had absolute peace. It was wonderful! However, we started at 9 am in the morning and not at night - as is recommended everywhere. Therefore, of course, there was no view upstairs and everything in the fog. Still, it was worth it. In the low season absolutely take enough water with you as no kiosk has on the way! Great experience ‚ù§Ô∏è

Started at 2 am, made it to the top in 3 hours, and got an amazing sunrise without any crowds. The climb felt easier than I thought, and the way down was smooth. Met some super friendly people on the trail too. If you want a chill, i would definitely do it again.

Adam's Peak, also known as Sri Pada, is a sacred mountain in Sri Lanka, revered by Buddhists, Hindus, Muslims, and Christians. Standing at 2,243 meters (7,359 feet) above sea level, it is a popular pilgrimage destination for people of all faiths. The most notable feature of Adam's Peak is the Sri Pada, a large, hollow rock formation on the summit that resembles a human footprint. According to legend, this footprint is that of Adam, the first man, or Lord Buddha, or even Lord Shiva. There are four main routes to the summit of Adam's Peak: the Hatton Route, the Nilamale Route, the Maskeliya Route, and the Palabathini Route. The Hatton Route is the most popular, as it is the shortest and most well-equipped. The climb to Adam's Peak is challenging but rewarding. The trails are steep and often slippery, and the altitude can make it difficult to breathe. However, the views from the summit are breathtaking, and the sense of accomplishment is immense. In addition to the religious significance of Adam's Peak, it is also a beautiful natural wonder. The mountain is surrounded by lush green forests and rolling hills, and the views from the summit are stunning. If you are planning to visit Sri Lanka, I highly recommend climbing Adam's Peak. It is a truly unique and unforgettable experience.

We had an absolutely perfect morning on Adam‚Äôs Peak, hiking up an almost deserted mountain under a starry sky and watching the stunning sunrise before descending under a warm sun. Absolutely none of the chaos or bad weather described on here - which isn‚Äôt to say those reviews aren‚Äôt accurate; just that we were seemingly very lucky. Climbing on the 2nd Nov, a good month before the pilgrimage season really starts, it was like a ghost path. The perfect time to do it if you want to avoid the crowds (which, reading the reviews, sound like hell on earth). Ok, no food&drinks stalls open, but we had water and a few snacks and the lone monk at the summit made us tea. Most importantly, however, we got lucky with the weather. So that would be our tip: climb in the off-season - and pray to Buddha, Shiva, Allah, God or whatever other mountain deity for good weather.

The place is absolutely wonderful, but the climb is really important and not affordable for everyone. But don't be discouraged because you can even get as far as the Japanese temple to enjoy the sunrise. However, it is worth going uphill to start enjoying the surroundings.

It seems like you're asking for a review of "Adams Peak" (also known as Sri Pada or Sri Padaya), a prominent mountain in Sri Lanka known for its religious significance. Adams Peak is revered by multiple religions including Buddhism, Hinduism, Islam, and Christianity. Here's a brief overview: 1. **Religious Significance**: Adams Peak is famous for the "Sri Pada" or "Sacred Footprint," a rock formation near the summit that Buddhists believe to be the footprint of the Buddha, Hindus attribute to Shiva, Muslims to Adam, and Christians to St. Thomas or St. Bartholomew. 2. **Pilgrimage**: The mountain attracts pilgrims from all over the world, who climb to the summit mainly during the pilgrimage season from December to May. The climb is traditionally started in the early hours of the morning to witness the sunrise from the peak. 3. **Natural Beauty**: Apart from its religious importance, Adams Peak offers stunning natural scenery and biodiversity, with a variety of flora and fauna. 4. **Visitor Experience**: Climbing Adams Peak is a challenging but rewarding experience, with multiple trails leading to the summit. Facilities along the way cater to pilgrims and tourists, including rest stops and shelters. 5. **Cultural Heritage**: The mountain and its surroundings are steeped in cultural heritage, with nearby villages offering insights into local traditions and lifestyles. Overall, Adams Peak is a significant cultural and religious landmark in Sri Lanka, drawing visitors for both its spiritual and natural attributes. If you're considering a visit, be prepared for a memorable journey rich in history and scenic beauty.

Try this 5.5-mile out-and-back trail near Maskeliya, Nuwara Eliya. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 56 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through May.
It gets very busy at the top of the climb and it is hard to get through the crowds to see the sunrise! Definitely worth getting there earlier than sunrise to get a good spot

We can definitely recommend climbing Adam's Peak! On the way up we had some crazy experiences that we don't want to mention here so as not to spoil them for future pilgrims. We set off at a quarter to two in the morning, but you should set off around one o'clock. Since locals climb Adam's Peak 24 hours a day, it can get extremely crowded at sunrise. You can reach the summit in about four hours. However, it can happen that you have to watch the sunrise on the stairs between thousands of people. Unfortunately, the entrance to the summit is very narrow, which means that there is a backlog of several meters. Sometimes you can't make any progress. The first three hours are easy to walk, however. After the climb, plan on having a lot of sore muscles in your calves :D

My husband and I really enjoyed the ascent of Adam's Peak on Friday April 5, 2024. We are dynamic seniors and we had no problem climbing the 5,200 steps: 2h40 of climbing and 2h10 of descent with a departure at 2 a.m. We were very lucky because there were few people and we were able to climb at a steady pace. You just need to be motivated and not be put off by the effort. The night was very clear with a magnificent starry sky, and the sunrise at 5:30 a.m. gave us incredible colors. The 360¬∞ view from the summit is splendid. On the other hand, I think that the climb during the day must have been very difficult in the humid heat which was beginning to be felt when we returned to the lodge at 8:30 a.m.

Not sure of it was due to the day or date, Tuesday 16th of April. Maybe something to do with post New Years Celebrations. But as we reached 30 minutes to summit, we barely moved due to traffic jam. For around an hour, to the point that we decided it was best to go back down. We left at 2am but there was no chance of us making it up by sunrise, nor did we see any possibility of there being space for the sheer amount of people. We luckily made it down quick enough to watch the sunrise from the roof of our hotel ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

The Sri Pada is a pilgrimage site which has been held sacred by the devotees of four religions namely Buddhists, Hindus, Christians and Islamists. Historians agree that this site, even prior to the introduction of Buddhism to the Island, had been¬†a sacred site where the primitive people worshipped the Sun god. 5/5

Two options- the day time hike and the other more popular one, the night time climb. Day timer Leave earliest -7AM the best .There's a time zone between 6am to around 11 am when the cloud ceiling stay way up and above the sky so the scenary and photography would be ideal during the time frame. 7AM start means you can be at the summit by 11am without the need to make it a physical exercise. This is just before the ceiling starts to descend. Better to begin return from the summit by around 12 to be safely back to Nallathanni by 3pm. This could be before the skies open up for afternoon rain. Take water- 2 lilters. Best not to buy water from the shops as we too would be aiding the plastic pollution by supporting the very source of that problem- the sale of PET bottles along the route. Nighter.. Ideal time to leave Nallathanni would be 12pm, giving you sufficient head way to reach the summit by 4am. The gallery where the much famed sunrise could be viewed AND photographed[ photography is not allowed at the upper tier] is quite small and has room for not more than 100. This place is packed to capacity by 5am. So better not be too smart at starting late. The payment of course is one might need to bear the chill at dawn which could easily be in single digits. But to secure a decent vantage point on that little gallery you need to be seated there by 4am the least. Payback for the pains of the biting cold added by 10kmph winds could be that 45 minute absolute fascination of the sunrise - the finest on earth, so they say. Make sure to move away from the gallery just after the sun reveals itself in full. Head back towards the other side of the summit to see an even more spectacular sight -that of the perfect triangle shaped shadow of Adams Peak- spread over the thin film of morning mist for more than 40 km.

I was dreading this due to temperamental knees but didn't regret it for a second! I have a good level of fitness, a 39 year old gym goer 3-5 times a week so when I say this is easy please bear this in mind. My heart rate stayed pretty steady throughout (120) with a slight increase on the steeper spots. Some tips from me; 1. DIFFICULTY:  I'm not silly enough to think this would not be tough for some people and I definitely saw people struggling but if you go slow you will be fine. The first half is pretty wide steps, quite a nice walk and then yes lots of steep steps. 2. DURATION:  We went at a pretty slow pace, left at 02:30 and was at the summit for 05:00, we stopped off a few times for 5-10 mins and it felt like a nice walk. (remember to add any walking time from the hotel on to this time) it took us about 2 hours to get back down. So with stopping at the top (1hr) we did it in 6 hours. Again remember we did this relatively slow, you could do it faster if you wished üôÇ 3. COLD: It is cold at the top, I'm an English girl I had shorts on but did have to put a hoodie on, if I stayed any longer than the 10-15 mins I was up there I would have needed to layer up more 4. SLEEP BEFORE: There were so many people sleeping on stairs on the way down, clearly they had stayed up the night before, this could be due to the challenge they set themselves for their pilgrimage but if you don't have stay awake don't! We went to sleep at 20:00 The night before waking up at 01:00 and we felt very fresh 5. WATER: Drink a litre before you go it will help with your breathing loads, I drank approx 2 litres from a water bladder whilst walking. I saw so many people struggling with water bottles whilst walking - if you can take a  bladder do! 5. ATTIRE: Until about the last 30 mins I had some gym shorts and a crop top, I wore hiking shoes too (God send), towards the end it was cold and I wore a hoodies as mentioned above. I have dicky knees so wore knee straps the entire duration and didn't get any serious pain throughout. 6. WHEN TO GO: We went on the 9 April just before the children broke up for the new year which was also a weekday it was absolutely fine, no real problems. I have heard there are lots of crowds weekends and holidays! 7: THE SUMMIT: If you are religious great I think you will like the top, for me I'll be honest, I wasn't going to stay for more than 10 mins, photos are prohibited and it was rapidly building up with people. Just you reach the summit you will need to remove your shoes, I have heard they can go missing so we put ours in our bag. I was also asked asked to cover shoulders/knees to enter the shrine that is there. I couldn't see where I could have taken a photo when sunrise did come so we rang the bell and quickly started to descend before sunrise. 8: SUNRISE: We walked down a flight or two of stairs and sheltered in a cafe until sunrise (the cafe was the first one we came too on our descent down) we bought a couple of bars of chocolate and they let us sit in their tent which had windows so we could see when the sun started to rise. When the sun started to come up we started to walk down the stairs and there were many places we could stop on the way to take photos. I have no idea why anyone would freeze at the top (unless for religious reasons) when there didn't appear to even be a viewing platform to see the sunrise. 9. MONEY: Food and drink is cheap. Although we had nothing other than packaged or bottled due to being warned away as food is cooked in river water. A bottle of coke was a ¬£1 a chocolate bar 80p. HAVE TO PAY FOR TOILETS Rs50 (about 13p) so don't forget to take some small notes üôÇ In summary yes it could be tough if fitness level is low, take your time, avoid peak times but enjoy! Lots to see especially on the way down, stunning views and a real accomplishment! ‚ù§Ô∏è

Most westerner tourists want to do this hike at the same time - sunrise, but we didn‚Äôt bother and have no regrets. We started after 7am and returned before midday. What we learned: 1. Avoid weekends and full moons, the traffic levels are insane. 2. We heard many stories of sunrises being so crowded that people reached a standstill traffic jam, waited 1-2 hours, barely/never moving, before turning around and leaving. For people who did reach the top or close to it, fog/clouds often impacted seeing the sun rise. 3. It is a very tough hike with the last part of it being constant uphill stairs. Go at your own pace, take breaks when needed, drink plenty of water and an energy drink/coke or two. 4. There is no nice viewing platform at the top, it is a temple. Similarly unlike most hikes there are no nice quiet places to have a rest at. The stops that do exist are often filthy and full of rubbish and already occupied. 5. There are plenty of drink/food/snack vendors along the majority of the route, including some where you can have a sit down meal. Cold drinks are not always available, note if the fridge is actually on. 6. There are toilets available, you‚Äôll often have to pay though it‚Äôs not much. 7. There is a swimming spot near the bend in the trail at Seetha Gangula Crossing (not the water you can hear falling right at the bend, but further south on the opposite side of the path to the public latrine complex). Treat yourself, relax your legs, swim with the locals. 8. There's an alternate (and far more friendly) route from Pine‚Äôs needle. It is not as crowded and is more of a slope as opposed to constant stairs. 9. Be prepared for the usual staring and whispering as you walk past locals, some will also find it amusing if you're a big sweater like me and throw out the occasional jibe. 10. Not all monks are nice, friendly people.

On March 21, my friends and I decided to visit the magnificent Adam‚Äôs Peak mountain. It took us 8 hours to get to the very top and 3 hours to go down. We started getting up at 00:30, we wanted to be there by dawn, but crowds of locals and queues got in the way. Nevertheless, we reached the very top, bowed and went on our way. And now about the main thing. I will highlight the advantages: 1. There are small cafes where you can have a very easy snack (rotti, tea/coffee). 2. Availability of normal toilets every 300 +/- meters costing 50 Rs. 3. The entire path is illuminated. 4. Bomb species. Minuses: 1. Crowds of locals, since we climbed the day before the Poya holiday. I think on other days there are fewer people. 2. Uneven step height.

I believe that every second person who planned an active trip to the ‚Äúglorious, blessed land‚Äù (that‚Äôs how ‚ÄúSri Lanka‚Äù is translated from Sanskrit) included a visit to one of the holiest Sri Lankan places ‚Äì Adam‚Äôs Peak ‚Äì on their tourist trail. In different sources you can find various names for this object: Sri Pada, Samanalakanda, Sivanolipatha Malai, Adam‚Äôs Peak, Butterfly Mountain, Sumanakuta, Ratnagiri, Sivanolipaatamalai, ≈örƒ´ PƒÅda, Adam‚Äôs Peak etc. But all this is a mountain with a height of 2243 meters, which is located in a mountainous area in the south-southwestern part of the island in the province of Sabaragamuwa. To the capital - Colombo - nothing at all, some 65 miles. Strange as it may sound, four religions at once consider Sri Pada a sacred mountain. And why? Yes, because at its very top, in front of the temple erected there, on a bare granite (or some kind of stone?) platform, we can clearly distinguish a gigantic depressed ‚Äúfootprint‚Äù, well, very similar to the imprint of a human foot. And each of the world‚Äôs largest religions ‚Äúinterprets‚Äù this very trace in its own way. Christians (which was news to me!!!) claim that this is the trace of the Apostle Thomas: that the latter preached in India and on the Island is mentioned by Gregory the Theologian, Ambrose of Milan, Jerome of Stridon, Peacock of Nolan, etc. Representatives of Buddhism are firm in their belief that this ‚Äúfootprint‚Äù was left by none other than Gautama Buddha himself, who touched the ground here with his foot while visiting the island. In Hinduism, Sri Pada and the mentioned ‚Äútrace‚Äù are associated with the god Vishnu (the latter, according to representatives of this religion, is a human transformation (avatar) in the image of Buddha). Well, in Islam, the same ‚Äúfootprint‚Äù is considered the imprint of the foot of Adam, who at one time was cast from heaven to earth on the island of Serendib (the ancient Arabic name of Sri Lanka), right at the top of Adam‚Äôs Peak. It was around this sacred must see, which made the mountain itself sacred, that at one time they clouded the aura of divinity and, as a result, the pilgrimage of everyone and everything. They say that if you climb the five thousand two hundred steps to the top of Sri Pad, it will have a beneficial effect on the purification of your soul. Atheists, on the other hand, believe that by climbing the mountain, you can enjoy the amazing views that open from its top. In general, everyone climbs/steps up Adam‚Äôs Peak ‚Äúfor their own.‚Äù Why did I decide to go up there? To be honest, I don‚Äôt know myself. Just for the record, apparently - I‚Äôm a naked city tourist and I‚Äôm not very interested in the views of virgin nature, green grass, rivers, waterfalls, stones, rocks, cliffs, etc. Nevertheless, I decided... Having read the reviews of fellow tourists, I dressed warmly enough. I didn‚Äôt splurge on mountain shoes - my ‚Äúcombat‚Äù waterproof trekking shoes ‚ÄúQuechua Waterproof‚Äù, bought from Decathlon during a trip to Normandy in 2019, did an excellent job. The only thing is that I took with me a spare T-shirt (I really got sweaty during the trip) and thick socks (I read that at the very top, vigilant security forces pilgrims to take off their shoes and hang out ‚Äúbarefoot‚Äù (but this only applies to the area where the stupa with Buddha is). I started at the beginning of five - I read that the climb takes two and a half to three hours, and somehow I was not in the mood to meet the sunrise at the top. I made an ‚Äúadjustment‚Äù for my age and shape, which was far from youthful athletic, so I didn‚Äôt walk very quickly. As the altitude grew, it became increasingly cloudy; along the way, I met several cute monkeys hanging out in the thickets along the trail. There were surprisingly few pilgrims - it seemed like I climbed the mountain during the season, then the crowds described in the posts of travel lovers were not observed (or was I just lucky?). Halfway to the top of Sri Pada, you, like me, can admire the Peace Pagoda (Peace Pagoda or Shanti Stupa), built, according to Internet sources, on the initiative of the Nichiren Buddhist order, including both monks and lay people - Nipponzan Myohoji "(Nipponzan My≈çh≈çji) - in 1978. I reached the top in three hours (with a tiny ‚Äútail‚Äù), hung out, took pictures of the neighboring peaks, ‚Äúcovered‚Äù by clouds. The journey back took about the same time. There is a lot of talk on the net about a saying attributed to the aborigines about climbing Adam's Peak (I won't quote it - it's already blurry), but I probably agree with its second part - about climbing Sri Pada again. Some kind of holiness, a feeling of purification of the soul, divinity, etc. I didn't feel it. And I was very skeptical about the ‚Äútrace‚Äù of Adam/Buddha/Vishnu/Thomas: the fact is that this place has been known as sacred since the 4th century AD: it is mentioned in the Dipavamsa (the earliest Pali chronicle), in the Mahavamsa chronicle ( V century), in the chronicle of Rajavalia (the date of writing is not established), in the notes of the famous Chinese pilgrim and traveler Fa Hien. But for some reason there is no mention of the ‚Äútrace‚Äù. But the famous dromomaniac comrade Marco Polo, talking about his travel to the Island in 1298, mentioned Adam‚Äôs Peak as an important place of pilgrimage - and not a word about the ‚Äútrace‚Äù!!! Similarly, in the notes of the Arab traveler Abu Abdullah Muhammad ibn Battuta from 1344: having climbed to the top of Sri Pad, he mentioned the stairs and iron racks with chains that helped pilgrims climb. And, again, not a single mention for the ‚Äúfootprint‚Äù... And only in the travel notes of John Davy, a Cornish doctor and amateur chemist who visited the top of Adam‚Äôs Peak in 1817, do we find a mention for the ‚Äúhuge footprint‚Äù. I do not deny the existence of gods, but I also do not take the side of any religion or faith, and I am also very skeptical about phenomena and events that are presented as miracles. "Was there a boy?" ‚Äì probably only the Earth itself knows about this... By the way, my dear reader, I didn‚Äôt know that there are TWO Adam‚Äôs Peaks on the Island!!! I wrote about the Big one above, but Little Adam‚Äôs Peak, with a height of only 1151 meters, is located near the city of Ella. It takes just over half an hour to climb it, as those in the know say, and the views from its top at sunset are especially interesting. I haven‚Äôt been there myself, but just in case I added it to my travel tablets - maybe someday I‚Äôll end up in Ceylon again...

While i know everybody wants to see the sunrise, going to see the sunset was a much better decision. Starting in the afternoon, after uv index had gone down a bit, it tooks us 3,5 hours to reach the top. It was really exhausting, but on the way you have many toilets and can buy cold water. Not so many people. Never felt cold. Decent was in the dark, but the path is lighted.

For me, it was the third time that I climbed Sri Pada. Or rather, wanted to climb it. Since we arrived on a long weekend, the crowds were huge. We set off at 2.30 in the morning, but a few hundred meters before the summit it was impossible to continue. The traffic jam was so big that we turned back before the summit. Still a great experience, but definitely avoid weekends during the pilgrimage season!

We did the shortest trail from Dalhousie on a "normal" night (no weekend, no holidays) from Sunday to Monday in February. The crowd was still horrific! Our host from the guesthouse told us, the night before 500 000 (!) people did the climbing. And already there is enough information about the steep steps and the countless trash everywhere along the way. But I want to share the insider tip of an alternative (and a little easier) route we got from our host. With this knowledge we could make it up to the top to see the sunrise. So at the "point of needles" you need to turn right (the red line in the picture) - away from the crowd - instead of going straight ahead (the purple line). You'll find an unpaved way with soil and larger stones - this is the right one, just follow it. It's about 20 minutes longer than the usual one, but less exhausting. And don't forget to take a torch with you, because there isn't any light.

We didn't even try to do the hike given how crowded it was. We came across travelers who started walking at 12 a.m. and returned at 2:30 p.m. without even reaching the summit!! Another couple we met stayed in the same place for more than 30 minutes without being able to move forward or down because there were so many people. DO NOT COME ON THE WEEKEND! Maybe during the week it‚Äôs not as bad‚Ä¶.. We arrived on a Saturday, there were hundreds of buses trying to get as close as possible to the starting point, it was a huge mess. So much so that we gave up on doing this hike.

Disappointing experience climbing Adam's Peak. Despite starting our ascent at 1 am, earlier than recommended, we spent 3 hours stuck in a crowd that barely moved. After 7 hours of climbing and still not reaching the top, we had to give up due to freezing temperatures and exhaustion. While the physical challenge was expected, the lack of progress and unbearable cold made it unbearable. Avoid weekends to avoid the crowds

Where to start? The place is beautiful and I am sure the temple is as beautiful. However, there were just way too many people everywhere. There were 3 km of empty buses prior to the arrival and 5h of a 6 lane non-moving queue to get to the top at around 500m below the peak.

The views were amazing! There are three main routes to the peak, Erathna, Hatton, and Ratnapura. We went from Kuruwita via Erathna (known as Erathna Road) which was nearly 14 kilometers to the peak. You can park your vehicle in the Erathna area and several sweets and clothing shops are there. From Erathna, the walking journey began. No stairs at the beginning, but from Heramitipana junction, stairs began. We took nearly 06 hours to reach Heramitipana from Erathna. Heramitipana is the place where Ratnapura road joins Erathna road. Before Heramitipana, we took a shower from a river called 'Kuru Ganga' aka 'Seetha Gangula', which has clean and clear water.

More than 5 thousand steps for a magnificent experience in the company of hundreds of pilgrims and tourists. The climb took just under 2 hours, but I'm a sporty person. I went on a Friday of the first weekend in January and maybe I was lucky not to find the hordes of people I read about. Lots of people at the top, yes, but we didn't even queue for 1 minute to go up. We left at 2.45am. at the top, a footprint of the Buddha and hundreds of pilgrims. Magnificent sunrise over the surrounding mountains.

We came to Kandy to climb this mountain seeking a  beautiful sunrise view as most do. We only planned to stay one night and climb on this night. Unfortunately the night we chose was heavy rain! We were so glad we packed our waterproof over clothes, walking boots and head torches. We were set. As seasoned hikers, we put on a fair pace, rain considering. There are toilet stops on route but you need to pay to use them. The rain kept us wet and thus cool. The crowds were at a minimum so we didn‚Äôt need to queue anywhere and could pass slower walkers easily. When we got to the top it was blowing a hoolie. We ascended so quickly that we would have needed to wait about 2.5 hours for sunrise. Because of the heavy rain, we decided to reach peak and turn around. At the top, no photos allowed, or headwear or shoes, so off came our soaking wet walking boots so we could pay our respects at the temple and see the Buddha‚Äôs golden foot. We rang the bell once (for the number of times you climbed it) and then turned to get down. It felt very tricky the first couple of kms from the top as the steps are very steep and you need to overtake a lot of weary pilgrims. Fair play - most of them were either barefoot or in Flipflops! Everyone was friendly enough too. Despite no sunrise experience I would definitely do this again - fitness really helps you to enjoy the experience. If you are a seasoned hiker like us - we made it up in 1:45 hours  with no stops at all, so factor this in for sunrise. We used about 1.5L of water each but you might need more if not raining. Layers are essential so pack for the top - as last 400m was quite windy. Also definitely stretch hard afterwards as this will save your legs for the rest of your trip.

Climbing the 3rd Highest Peak in Sri Lanka isn't necessarily a small feet. But tis the faith that fuels this excursion or more fittingly this pilgrimage that you should take at least once in your lifetime. For firstcomers, there are some traditions you have to follow. 1. Cleanse yourself with lime at the stream at the base of the mountain, rightfully named "Seetha Gangula" 2. Hand a pouch of medicine symbolizing good health at the "Indikatu Pahana" 3. String along a piece of yarn from "Indikatu Pahana" 4. Throw some chalk on the chalk post at the last stop or "Ahela Kanuva" Make sure that you bring your raincoat and hiking boots. There are shops along the path from Hatton but make sure you bring extra cash because they charge extra for nearly everything at shops along the path.

Ascent on Wednesday, December 6th. We left Nuwera Elyia at 11:30 p.m. and started walking at around 2:40 a.m. We were really, really proud when we got to the top - the holy Adam's Peak is my personal highlight! :) No matter how fit or untrained you are, do it!! Just do it :) It's best to do it on a weekday and not during pilgrimage season. It was super empty when we went - so unfortunately the temple was also closed (the only disadvantage). Make sure you bring a flashlight (preferably a headlamp)! The path is only lit during pilgrimage season. It's a strenuous climb, distribute your energy well, don't be put off when others pass you (we caught up with them later). The last third is the hardest: your legs hurt, but it's good mental training to have the goal in sight. We had two bananas and cookies with us. We always had a snack here and there, which gave us good energy. At the top we had breakfast with bread from the hostel. Don't eat too much on the way because it's quite a cardio session. Take enough water with you. Otherwise, even in the off-season, there are stands that sell food and drinks. When you get to the top, it's cold and windy. We had several layers of clothes on and a spare shirt with us because you're really sweaty when you get to the top.

Adam's Peak, site of the Sri Pada Adam‚Äôs Peak,¬†mountain¬†in southwestern¬†Sri Lanka. It is 7,559 feet (2,304 metres) high and located 11 miles (18 km) northeast of¬†Ratnapura, the capital of Sabaragamuwa province. It is well known for the Sri Pada (Sinhala for ‚ÄúSacred Footprint‚Äù), a¬†hollow¬†that is 67 inches (170 cm) long and 18 inches (46 cm) wide and resembles the print of a human foot. The Sri Pada is venerated by Buddhists, Hindus, Christians, and Muslims. Many pilgrims of all faiths visit the peak every year.

We were a party of four, forty and fifty somethings, three Sri Lankans, of which two Kandyan dancers by trade. The dancers could have strolled up in the usual time, but waited for my wife and I taking six hours to ascend the Hatton path and two to descend. We needed breaks at many of the benches, a couple of which are under cover. Only the police station at the start was open and this was the only problem. A staffer claimed locals are banned out of season due to vandalism and demanded ID in return for relenting when we explained my wife has UK residence and needs her brothers as guides. There were only a dozen or so of us on the mountain, mostly young backpacker couples from Germany. The first parade of shops at the start were open, in fact are open 24h for the sunrise seekers, and a couple more further along the first third of the route, so there was some opportunity to revisit required water estimates. There is litter and rubble in many spots to the side of the stairway but the stairs were clear with handrails or walls. There were some toilet blocks we didn't try, and showers at two sites near the start we saw working. There were side steps at a couple of spots lower down to the river where locals bathe, where you can scoop some cold water on your face. We came across builders finishing a new toilet block about half way up, which looked to be quite modern. A couple of waypoint signs had fallen off, which count down the stages by numbers of steps accumulated. At the top we met the caretaker who helped us with the brew we took up. Cloud came and went during the trek so views are a lottery. We knew the temple wouldn't be open, but locals can still worship outside and you can peer over the gates to see the temple. We sat on the top steps before the temple steps proper and there was no wind. Those of us in just a base layer were fine without needing extra layers even when stopping in a breeze along the way and when sitting at the top with no wind. So save the weight and avoid coats if you're not going in peak season or planning on waiting for sunrise; a waterproof will be windproof and trap warm air. A few showers threatened to force us to dig out the waterproofs, but locals know the clouds soon pass so you can usually ignore them and stay breathable instead. I managed without a hat due to cloud cover. The choice of trainers rather than flipflops like locals paid off as it gets wet and one leach jumped on one of us. As a couple, we were left with sore knees and feet respectively and my pulse had not recovered an hour after descent, and, as warned, leg muscles refused to allow gainly walking the next day. Apparently I probably got dehydrated without realising it, which is why I had to will myself up the last few steps: drink your water all the way up, don't save it for an emergency, the ascent IS an emergency. The customary stray dogs guided us up, and, after leaving us behind to perhaps adopt a faster couple, on returning and finding us they jumped and howled with excitement. They are in poor condition so you don't want them cuddling up when you're eating. We say wild monkeys arguing in the trees, bigger than the tourist monkeys you see at most attractions. You'll also hear frogs and see a few birds you could try to identify.
It's totally worth to give it a try. The mountain has an amazing view. Anyone who go to Sri Lanka must watch that mountain. Highly recommended.

We took the hatton route which starts from Nallathanniya town. It's the shortest (around 10 kms return) and the one with the best facilities but has a steep ascent with 5500 steps. The steps are made of concrete and there are guard rails all the way hence its one of the safest trails in the country, but it will still do a number on your knees.  [ A doctor friend advised us to wear knee guards from the beginning. Sadly we took the advice only after we returned from the trip.] This is a religious place and there is a season to travel, staring from December full moon poya day and ending on May full moon poya day. During the season the path is well lit (a torch would still be useful in the night though) and there are plenty of shops with food (instant noodles, roti, snacks etc), drinks (even energy drinks) & first aid along the trail. There are washrooms along the way. We used one maintained by the last shop in the trail ( you have to pay), which was extremely basic (covered in rucksack with the squatting pan fixed to the dirt floor) but it was surprisingly very clean. The same may not apply for other washrooms along the trail. You can travel off season but the lights will be turned off (a problem if you are climbing in the night) and the shops along the trail will be closed. Plus the weather is prone to rain which will turn the stairs into waterfalls. But if you travel during the season, you have to be mindful of the crowds which will lead to long queues. It is quite a popular option to climb during the night to reach the summit by early morning to wait for the sunrise. We took this option and went on a weekday (Thursday, 2nd of February) but it was school holidays and the Friday was a half day holiday. We started at 10.30 pm. It was slow going from the beginning. (But this was probably kind on our knees.) 3/4 of the way (around 3 pm) we heard from those returning that the summit was already packed and you will not be allowed to stay there till sunrise. So we made the mistake of taking a break for about 45 minutes since we didn't want to experience the summit in the dark. Once we resumed the climb we ended up in a long queue and it was 9 am when we reached the summit!!! The summit was also closed from 6 - 7 am for religious activities which made the queue even longer. (But foreigners were allowed to skip the queue and reach the view point in the summit since the queue was actually for the place of worship which was at a higher platform in the summit). Return journey took about 6 hrs. Partly due to crowds (but there was no queue), our knees and since we took long breakfast and lunch breaks on the trail. What to wear: The weather in the night was 16c but we were sweating profusely due to the climb. When we reached the entrance to the summit around 8.30 am it was around 11c and quite windy . It is also a religious place hence semi - covered gym/ hiking wear would be an ideal option. If you are planning to reach the summit early morning (around 5 am) for the sunrise it is better to carry some worm clothing and some head covering for the morning dew. What to take: During the season almost all what you need will be sold in the shops on the trail. But we found that our muscle pain relief balms, saline mixes and glucose quite useful ;) A torch is useful in the night and a hiking stick would help with knees.

amazing place we need to be visited at-least one time in our life and the hotel and restaurant  to book before arriving to Adams peak is to be easier for making your vacation so, happy as well highly recommended hotel in this place ayes hill is preferable moreover, they have free settle facilities and amazing staffs and comfortable rooms with good view point.

This is a very physically challenging experience -- we took the Hatton path, there are >5000 steps and they are neither evenly spaced nor consistent height.  Recommend either bringing a pole or locating a walking stick prior to your endeavor.  There are an amazing number of stalls up to the top that provide water, snacks --- you will be dumbfounded by the number of stalls that all sell the exact same thing right next to each other.  There are a few toilet stops along the way as well --- we didn't use them, so I can't attest to their status.  We started at 2a and got to "The Last Tea Stop" around 5:15a; had a coffee and then proceeded the final leg to the top. After finishing this experience, I would offer a few suggestions: -- bring a little flashlight so you can more easily see the steps; even though there is lighting along the path, it is not full-coverage. --instead of heading directly to the top to view the sunrise, pick a seat on a step t that is near but not AT the top.  The top is silly-crowded and the sunrise is still only in the east; ie. the sunrise isn't enhanced with a 360-degree view (that you most likely won't get anyway with the crowds). --  after sunrise, head up to the top.  Stay to respectfully observe the offering --- a ceremony that takes ~30 minutes.  The line to view the Sacred Foot is, well, long.  And you won't actually see what is considered the footprint -- it is covered with magnificent gold fabric.  It is a very sacred visit for the locals who drop some currency into the dish and then bow/kneel with a few seconds of prayer.  We (Americans) clearly didn't fit in with the crowd, especially as we only wanted to view the object.  It's 50/50 if I would recommend taking this time. -- don't forget that walking stick: you might be amazed at how something so seemingly inconsequential takes the stress off your knees/legs. -- if you aren't a stretching person, try to change just for this one time else your legs will most likely remind you of the hike for the following 4 days in most unpleasant ways. I think we could have avoided the muscle pain if we had simply taken a little time to stretch our legs after the hike. This was a great hike and if I were ever to find myself here again, I would do the hike again.  I noticed another review that commented to the trash along the path --- yes, that was surprising and disappointing.  Yet for me that was just a side-disappointment; it wasn't something that took away from the experience. ENJOY!!                  (and stretch! :-)

My wife and I decided to climb the adam's peak at the end of our trip to Sri Lanka. We had quite high expectations since many travelers posted great pictures and feedback about the climb. Now our personal experience was the following, we woke up at 2am to try to summit by 6am at the latest. The trip began with a short walk in the village of dalhousie until we finally reached the beginning of the path (Hatton path). The amount of trash there was just insane, it really looks like a junkyard, people are irrespectful of the nature. We didn't bring any water/food since we were told that everything was available for purchase there (which is true) however the level of hygiene in these shacks is really questionable. Many locals climbed at the same time than us and while most of them just stare at you, some of the people there were quite scary, my wife fell particularly unsafe when some guys (a group of 10/12 young adults) were circling us, staring at her and yelling at us (we failed to decipher what they said but I doubt that it was any friendly). Now when you finally reach the summit (after waiting in a queue that can last after 1 or 2 hours), the crowd prevents from seeing anything, unless you spend the night there camping like some of the locals. Even though, the weather is quite misty there so you're unlikely to see this breathtaking view that is advertised everywhere. That being said, sport-wise it is a good challenge, it is very hard to make it to the top (some people will tell you that 80 years old people make it, it is true however they climb in 8/10 hours, not 2/3 like you will) Also worth mentioning that we've met fantastic people everywhere else in Sri Lanka and never felt unsafe anywhere else.

Get ready for an infinite flight of stairs -5k and some more!- that will destroy your legs and knees for days (coming down is worse that going up!) unless you are really, but really!!, trained and fit. Leave at about 2:30 am to be able to get to the top before dawn, because that‚Äôs the aim and the temple closes at 6am. The atmosphere on top is magic and the dawn is a breathtaking experience. Get dressed in layers because while ascending you will sweat, but at the top, waiting for the sun to rise, is freezing cold.
Well worth it if you moderately for and not going in high season. Takes about 90 minutes to get up there but when it‚Äôs busy you have to wait 2-3 hours and move step by step which is absolute hell.

We didn't go for the sunrise and instead started our climb around 11am. We would be able to get to the top in 90minutes, but traffic jam in last section slowed us a lot. Views are magnificent although in our day it rained a lot and valley was often not visible. At the top you must remove your shoes, so count with it.

It‚Äôs a tough trek - I did it from the Hatton Road end and stayed at the Slightly Chilled Hotel which was excellent.  It‚Äôs about a 10 minute walk to the start of the trek.  There are loads of shops open at 2am (time I started) it is  5000 steps from the start  - I walked for 2.30 hours up steps and I guess I was about 1 hour from the top - but then major people traffic jam!  It was 22 Jan 2022 during the pilgrim period.  Literally you could not move and we were walking about 3 steps every 10 mins.  There is a way up and a way down separated by a metal barrier and lots of people went up on the wrong side - at least they didn‚Äôt have to standstill and nobody seemed to be stopping them.  I would say do not do this walk on a weekend or a public holiday - try to do it in the week.  You will see locals carrying their babies up there - elderly ladies with sticks  slowly making their way up / it‚Äôs a lovely feeling.  We were told to beware of people taking things from your back pack - I just put water in there so not worried because you may be squashed into others.  It‚Äôs the same way up and down, just make sure you come down the same side of the mountain.  Its easy to do. No charge but take some change for donations to the monks.

We travelled to Adams Peak through Kuriwita on the 22nd of December 2021. Things to bear in mind 1. There is a motorable concreted road about 2_3 km you can reach to a temple starting from the usual hiking point down at Erathna. This is not lit up. But will save your energy for the trip. A SUV is the best to go up this route with steep bends but small cars also were seen making the journey. The last bit is not concreted but about half km has rough terrain with stones. Can go through with a four wheel drive. Villagers at the start point will not give you adequate information but you can reach approximately 2_3 km through this motorable path with no difficulty. 2. The climb is adventurous but tedious. Needs a lot of caution. The foot pathway is by the edge of a steep cliff and if you loose a step you can fall hundreds if feet low. Step carefully as the stones are loose at time may be slippery or the muddy pathway may be washed away partially. 3.Must carry a good torch with good battery life. The foot path is lit up but may need extra light at times. 4. A big rain coat or a poncho will save your rucksack from getting wet during heavy rain fall your are likely to experience. Wear good quality shoes you  will have to walk through ankle deep rain water streams and your shoes need to withstand the water, mud and the rough terrain. Walking through rain is a blessing as it will give constant ice packs to the feet and cool you through out. 5. You need to cross the Seetha Gangula the river holding on to a big rope and walking through the water so if you have kids need to be careful. One slip may cost the life. 6. You are likely to come across creepy crawlies at any time so tired carefully in the pathway. In the thick jungle there will be snakes and dangerous insects. It is infested with leaches.so keep looking for bleeding spots. 7. Take adequate supplies of analgesics, anti-inflammatory spray and plasters, antiseptics for small cuts bandages etc . There are no medical care points till Heramitipana and any type of injury or illness is something you don't want to experience. 8. Take one good warm jacket, mittens and a cap after 12 MN it will be cold till about 5 pm. 9. There are about five shops till you meet the Rathnapura road .all these will serve hot drinks fruit juices, warm food and energising bites at very reasonable prices.they also have polythene rain sacks not very useful but can come handy. Carry your own sweets carbs and water always. 10. Resting places and toilets are very clean but we travelled just at the begining of the season. 11. It is advisable to climb down the Hatton route or take a few hour break at an ambalama.before climbing down the same pathway. 12. Be ready for the best adventure but the scenery and the experience is most remarkable and is a life time experience. 13. The whole journey will take 12_16 hours based on your energy level. If you start at three pm you can reach the peak by 6 pm. 14. The sunrise is most remarkable from this route as it will help you to witness the shadow of Sri Pada on the sky.

Adam's Peak offers stunning views of the region: from water reservoirs, to deep valleys and rolling mountains to breath-taking waterfalls. The main attraction are the sunrise, and Buddha's footprint at the Temple (currently closed since the pandemic). This place normally has thousands of climbers each day but given the current situation and that peak season begins mid-Dec, we were only about 10-15 climbers. We started at 2.30am and depending on your speed, it can take anywhere from 2.5 to 4 hours. There are about 6000 steps and barring a few medium ones, most are fairly steep. All the steps are in very good condition, and there are railing throughout. The gradient through the climb is pretty intense. It was completely cloudy when we went so we had no views, but we did see waterfalls on the way down. At the moment, there are no shops/vendors along the route, except at the bottom. An intense hike, but worth it if you enjoy the activity. Be prepared for winds and cold at the top. The total hike is about 16km.

We started our hike at 5 am, and whilst we missed the sunrise we were mostly climbing when it wasn‚Äôt that hot. There are stairs the whole way up, and we had to use the handrails to come up and down the steepest parts. We would‚Äôve given this five stars but the views at the very top are quite limited, so be sure to look around on your way up and down to take in the stunning surrounding landscape. It took us around 2 1/2 hours to get to the top, and quite a lot of water too!

Sri Pada (Inappropriately mentioned as Adam's peak) is the most sacred peak in the world. Thousand of devotees climb this mountain to worship Lord Buddha's foot print.  The season last from December full moon poya day to May full moon poya day. Officially the gates of foot print (Uda maluwa) are closed in off season but hike in off season carries a great experience. My latest off season experience occurred in September 2020 amid of Corona threat. We did a night hike along the easiest route-Hatton Sri Pada route. (There are six routes to hike Sri Pada and ultimately only two routes bring devotees to the foot print). We two were the only human existence at that time. There were no lights along the path like season. No shops were open. We slept at an Ambalama and reached Uda Maluwa in early morning with hope of Sun rise. But it was mist and gloomy weather. In off season you can expect torrent rain and thick mist. But the environment is fresh and you can enjoy some waterfalls as well.

When we arrived in Dalhousie at the foot of the mountain (from Hatton train station there are regular buses which cost the equivalent of about 50p), we had just completed a big trek the previous day in Knuckles. The plan was to get up at 2am and meet a guide to walk up to the top for sunrise. We ended up cancelling this because we were still shattered from the previous day but seeing the lights in a trail up the mountain, curiosity got the better of us. We decided to do it differently and instead started at 5am while it was still dark and just walked up as far as we wanted (until after sunrise- we stopped about two thirds of the way up which took us a bit over an hour) and I‚Äôm so glad we did it. Most of the reviews just talk about the view and the sunrise and how cold it is waiting at the top, but it‚Äôs such a brilliant opportunity to be immersed in a cultural experience and religious pilgrimage which is additional to all of these things. You don‚Äôt need a guide, just follow the path lined with stalls, follow the lights and the Sri Lankan people. Going up at 5am and then coming back down part way meant we shared the walk with other people but we were the only tourists and we didn‚Äôt get held up or stuck in queues by the sheer number of people. I have no doubt the view at the top is beautiful, but for me the experience of Adam‚Äôs Peak was about the incredible views and sunrise on the way up, the silhouettes of the monkeys jumping in the trees against the pink sky, trying the sweets from the stalls, the scent of citronella and incense everywhere, the shrines and the lights, someone playing a plastic container as a drum, fresh hoppers for breakfast, the soundtrack of chanting and waterfalls, seeing the families from babies to elderly grandmothers helping each other up and down the steps and feeling the religious significance of this day for so many people walking. We almost didn‚Äôt go because we have lots of walks with beautiful views planned but it‚Äôs so much more than that. Is it worth it? Yes definitely, but walk it your way and as an experience rather than just a hike.

This is a very sacred place for all the Buddhists. Lord Buddha has placed his foot mark. Normally there 3 main routes and Nallathanniya is the shortest path. It took nearly 5 hours to climb and 2.5 hrs to get down. Midnight is the peak time because it is very nice and breathtaking scenery to view the sunrise.

Adams peak has 3 main routes. 1. Hatton 2. Rathnapura 3. Kuruvita. Hatton is the most popular route with perhaps used by 80% of the people and more or less 99% of the foreigners. It is said to be about 6-7km climb. This route is very well developed with good stairs / railings lot of shops and clean toilets (need to pay Rs.20 to use them). Before the ascend there is a sort of a toll gate where the locals / Buddhists will be given a small sermon. Foreigners can skip this and proceed to a door but they will ask you for a donation. Write the amount in the book and proceed. Avoid climbing during poya days or long weekends as it becomes extremely crowded and you will not be able to reach the summit unless you are prepared to climb one step at 10 minutes speed (am of-course exaggerating), the last 500 or so meters. If you are climbing hatton but if it is really crowded at the top and you do want to reach the summit; there is a road joining the hatton and rathnapura roads so that you can cross over and try your luck with the less crowded rathnapura route but this means adding about 1km more. Be careful of what you eat as last thing you want is a bad stomach. Two of us fell in to that situation and we suspect it was the sweets we bought and ate at the start point. If you are going to stay at the summit and wait for the sunrise then you will need some serious jackets but otherwise though its cold at the base, is is not cold (but sometimes hot) after you start the climb. Tip for Foreigners: Even if you are very physically fit, your legs are going to ache quite bad after the trip so, do not plan anything for the day after but to relax at your hotel. Also the toilets are of the squatting type. Empty your bladder before you reach about the last 1km of your journey as there are no toilets until you reach the top AND you might be stuck in traffic for hours (we were stuck for 4 hours) if its a busy day (and water is not guaranteed at the top) The 2nd most popular route is the Kings Route (Raja Mawatha) starting from Rathnapura. its said to be about 8kms but probably more. Both this route and the Kuruvita route is NOT EASY. Do not attempt if you are not very very physically fit. I understand most locals ascending from this side rest at a rest house (there are over 8 of them along the way) for many hours (sleep) and start. Do your research well before you attempt one of these routes. Also I heard of a tourist who mistakenly descended down this route (which I found strange that they did not realize it because steps are very different on rathnapura side and the landscape is VERY different). Anyway getting a taxi from Rathnapura or Kuruvita back to hatton is going to be very expensive (over 100kms), so becareful that you are descending hatton side. We ascended from hatton and descending down rathnapura side. Rathnapura side is fine until you come to the temple which you see from the top which you "think" is the end point and probably similar to the distance you would have descended if you were taking the hatton route. But you are in for a surprise when you are there because the actual journey starts only here! We chose the Kuruvita route which is the longest... over 14kms (felt like 20). Basically you will be ascending and descending few more mountains and arrive at kuruvita. The paths are rough and going in those endless was like playing temple run...(you think its never going to end). In this route you will not come across seats by the road or shops or toilets like you see on hatton road. Basically there will e one shop and toilet roughly every 2Km. Some toilets are very good but some are not at all good. At one point about 8kms down the line you will come to the river. Its extremely clean. You can have bath here. The danger of the kuruvita path is that most of it is through the jungle (but well lit all the way and no known situations of attacks by any animal) so if you hurt yourself there is no way you can be helped out. Given the rough paths it will be very difficult for anyone to lift you and take you to the destination (even air lifting whether possible i do not know). If you are exhausted beyond hope, there is way to get a taxi avoiding the last 4km of the journey. There is a rough path which a trishaw can come. At the police post those phone numbers are there. The 3 wheeler journey takes half and hour to the town (about 6 kms) and only 1 or 2 trishaws. Since the trishaws are high in demand they could act arrogant which we faced and end up waiting nearly 3 hours to get the taxi. Heard Rathnapura Raja mawatha (the original route to siripada) is less distance it is also strenuous with continuous steps for kms and kms. Kuruvita is an excellent tour for hike lovers (this would be the mother of all hikes that you can do in LK). I would recommend ascend from kuruvita and descend hatton BUT with a sleepover / break in midway. This is about a total distance of about 22kms. I would NOT recommend starting from rathnapura ending kuruvita or vice versa. Do not try this route with infants!. Some stupid people does that as we met many such people. Also if it rains while you are taking the kuruvita road, you are done and there are places at some points that if you slip and fall you will fall infintely. This is why you should not attemp this way OFF Season. Hints people taking the Kuruvita Track: Travel light, take a hiking stick, wear GOOD shoes (which can withstand stress - you do not want them broken) and have a flash light in hand. Phones will be useless more or less on your entire journey. I am sorry if i discourage anyone taking the longer routes BUT though its actually challenging and people I know who had struggled with the journey after sometime either forget the hardships but doing so may put someone who is not fit for the journey attempt this (thinking its similar to hatton but just longer) and fall in to trouble. Basically even for the tough guys, it will be more strenuous than you heard or thought it is.. seriously.

One of the three pilgrimage sites for Sri Lankan Buddhists, the climb was a very tough slog. We left at 0200, the group making it to the top before sunrise after 0600. There are roughly 5,700 steps, the biggest and most challenging ones naturally near the summit. There is sufficient lighting for the ascent in the dark. It was about 9C in the cold of the night. Some shops were open heading up, many more when coming down, the descent taking 2.25 hours. At the top there was a chance for a quick look at Buddha‚Äôs footprint, suggesting a deity of gigantic, rather than human, dimensions. People waited for the sunrise, the cold secondary at that stage. An unusual feature was the shadow of Adam‚Äôs Peak reflected on the western side of the mountain top. You will feel the climb in your quads and calves for several days later. This is one of those climbs where there are as many (or more) devotees as tourists so be respectful.

Highlight of the experience has to be the sunrise and the shadow of the mountain (breathtaking views!) on the west side which occurs at around 5:30-6am. The climb is relatively okay, with steps and railing the whole distance on the Hatton trail. Can be a tough experience if prone to knee pains e.c.t. We gave ourselves about 5 hour to climb up as we were going in a larger group but most moderately fit people can do it in about 3 hours. I recommend going in season as there is lights and lots of shops to grab a bite/ drink tea situated all the way up the mountain (so no need to carry lots of food). Had no problem with and food/drinks that we bought. However, be sure to avoid poya (full moon days) as they are more busy. Also be sure to have a driver to drive you home/to next destination or stay a day in a hotel around Sri Pada as you will be too sleepy/tired to drive!!!

hi every body this is a super amazing place, i never thought climbing up a hill is this much fun Lucky for us we encountered very good weather without rain but we were prepared with rain jackets and some warm clothing . the temperature we encountered was around 18C there are to ways to reach this place Hatton side and Rathnapura Side we went thought Hatton Side because the distance seems to be shorter to climb it was a very nice night with clear sky we started climbing around 1am in order to have just enough time to watch SUN RISE which is a main feature of this trip and also to have the morning chanting from the temple at the peak where the foot print of lord Buddha is situated it was a challenging walk where you have to climb around 7000 steps my advice for travelers specially ladies try to avoid Denims and get a thermal light weight bottom or a tank bottom. take ample time to climb and do not give up, its fully worth the hassle to get there once you get you will realize it the amazing view and the atmosphere take water bottles the water seems to be bit expensive up there i had 3,1lr bottles with me which was enough for the trip down as well at the quarter of the trip there is a Y junction where it says " shortest way through Japanese friendship temple to Left" do not take that because it is full of steps which I found bit difficult, and the right hand side road does not have that of a distance and also have a gradual climb which is easy we started around 1 am and managed to get to the top by 6 am i was not a fast climber i was supporting  my wife and others in our group to climb and encouraging them. On the way through Hatton side before reaching adams peak there is a another place called Norton Pone a old dam which we stopped to have dinner which food we carried which i found interesting, pics attached the whole trip cost me only 24 hrs, we left colombo around 6pm and got there through HATTON way around 11:45 pm and started climbing around 1am and got to the peak around 6am and after the chanting we stared climbing down around 8am and got to the bottom around 12.30 pm and had lunch at the near by food stall at the carpark and went to the stream and left the adam's peak around 4pm to colombo around 10pm focus your mind and start climbing do not give up for anything devote your self and keep one thing in mind just to complete the climbing and get to the peak, take your time when climbing do not ask anyone how far it is it might discourage you a bit fully worth the effort please believe me have a pleasant trip because i had one cheers

To reach the summit where the shrine to the Buddha‚Äôs footprint is was totally worth it. One bit of advice for day hikers, even though it is cool, the humidity is full on and you will sweat. Best is a sweater in the backpack for the summit and a gym shirt or something light for a top and hiking pants.

This review tries to give a little guidance on the time it takes to do this trek. I took: - 2 hrs 25 to do the ascent, which includes only ~10 mins of stops - 25 mins at top admiring the amazing views - 1 hr 50 to go down This was: - 3.30am to 8.10am all in. - going at quite a fast pace, to reach the peak for sunrise, and get back down before the sun is in full force - solo and in off-season, so no having to stop for other people I would advise using these times as minimums, bearing in mind: - most would stop more than 10 mins during the 6,000+ steps ascent - it would be more leisurely and less strain on your legs to go down slower than I did - during pilgrimage season and at weekends I believe it's much busier, and you may encounter slower people ahead of you (the steps are wide in most places so often you'd be able to overtake) - you should tune your start time to when the sunrise is as well as your pace Note it is easy to navigate. From Adam's Peak village, people can point you to the start. It's through the town (slightly downhill) to the bridge over the river, then to the left and just 40 metres from the bridge as the path turns sharp right is the "Sri Padaya" sign - go up the first steps of many!

First comes DENIAL. Having left our hotel at 2:30am we had chose to take a 5 minute break to catch our breath deciding that after an hour of walking that we must be about half way...we were not. In fact we had only just started what we later came to call ‚ÄòThe Proper Climb‚Äô (exchanging the word proper for the occasional expletive during our darker moments). Before moving onto the next stage, it‚Äôs worth giving a bit of background to our trip to Adam‚Äôs Peak. My wife had very kindly organised a once in a life time trip to Sri Lanka in December of 2019, providing a day by day itinerary of what to expect. Me, being an idiot, did not check said itinerary in nearly enough detail and as such made my first big mistake with regards to Adam‚Äôs Peak...pack sporty clothes because you WILL sweat a lot during this climb. Also pack plenty of layers because it‚Äôs cold and windy at the top. Oh and water - lots of water. There are plenty of small shops by the path on the way but you‚Äôll pay a premium. Having arrived at the area the night before the climb and realising just what a lengthy journey this was going to be, I swiftly googled how fit someone should be in order to attempt it. Most reviews said ‚Äòa middle level of fitness‚Äô. What does middle level of fitness mean? I figured I could run around a football pitch for 90 minutes so was probably ok. If you‚Äôre in any doubt yourself, you should be able to walk for a good 5-6 hours on stairs (that‚Äôs up and down total). So, back to the stages... Next comes ANGER. This kicked in around the 90 minute mark. The irrational anger at that bl**dy mountain and all it‚Äôs s*dding stairs. This transferred swiftly onto anger at the person who organised the whole thing, my wife. You can probably guess how that went so we‚Äôll move swiftly on. Third up is BARGAINING. At around the 2 hour mark my wife and I began to give each other little walking challenges in exchange for small breaks. We‚Äôre talking less than 50 meters on stair case between breaks. Then the rain hit... Whilst huddled under the corrugated roof of a path side mud hut drenched in rain and sharing our fun sized Mars bar we hit DEPRESSION. It was make or break time - clearly the mood was dark. Plenty of of others in what had become a communal hiding spot we‚Äôre considering turning back. Was it worth getting to the top? Would we even make it in time for sun rise? Then the Mars bar kicked in - it was go time. Finally we had arrived at ACCEPTANCE. Yes we couldn‚Äôt have been more wet if we‚Äôd taken a flying leap into the nearby river, yes our muscles were begging us to stop but we were 3/4 of way up and had a glorious sun rise to witness. With renewed purpose we powered up to the summit and reached it with around 30 minutes before sunrise (total climb time around 3 hours). As it ended up, we were engulfed by a cloud a didn‚Äôt actually see the sun come up. Never mind. This didn‚Äôt take away from the immense sense of achievement in making it to the top, nor did it stop the high fives flying with fellow climbers. We‚Äôd done it. So why the 5 star review? For us it was the joy of making it all the way up, meeting fellow walkers and sharing stories of our trip. It was pushing these ‚Äòmiddle level of fitness‚Äô southern fairies to the point of breaking before rewarding us with stunning views (in the end) and a memory that would last a lifetime. Thanks Adam‚Äôs Peak. You b*stard.

I‚Äôm writing this review as there wasn‚Äôt much information about walking Adam‚Äôs Peak out of season. We walked early December and we worried we‚Äôd be the only people. However there were probably about 100 people walking so a nice amount of people to do it with. The route is well signposted from Dalhousie and there are steps all the way. We started at 3am from the bottom and were up by 5.10am. It‚Äôs hard to say how long to factor to do the walk given different peoples fitness and walking speeds but would say most people were up earlier than they expected. I think you could leave at 3.30am and be ok if you‚Äôre relatively fit. It‚Äôs cold at the top so bring plenty of layers. Some people had to leave because they were too cold. It‚Äôs a great challenge - about 1000m of ascent in a short space of time. People saying coming down is harder but going up is definitely harder IMO. The views from the top are nice albeit ruined somewhat by some pretty ugly infrastructure. As we went out of season the temple at the top wasn‚Äôt open so may be better in season. However it was busy enough when we did it so imagine it‚Äôs crazy in peak season and difficult to reach the top if there‚Äôs a lot of people. There‚Äôs not a huge amount of space at the top. Getting down took about 80-90 minutes. Enjoy breakfast when you get down! And only book a hostel for the night before. Have breakfast, get an hours kip then head to the station. Definitely worth doing for the experience and easy to jump off the train at Hatton but only 4 stars as the view is a little ruined by some of the buildings on the top.

This three months journey was & still is something unforgetable. One of stops was sacried Sri Pada.  I have to confess, it was difficult that time to get nearby the Adam¬¥s Peak. We informed  in  tourist offices in Colombo and Kandy. Their answers were all the time same: "It¬¥s off season, steps are slippery and ascent dangerous."  Even the obtaining of Sri Lanka¬¥s detailed map  was difficult. Then we were lucky and got the road map. We should get to Maskeliya where one of three trails to the summit started. At about 22 o¬¥clock we got of the bus in Maskeliya, ate some bites in local hut. Against the midnight started our way and then climb to the hilltop of Sri Pada. Thanks bright starry night it was possible to see the contours of a dark mountain range with the rising peak quite away from us. Sorry to say due to fog we did not see the Adam¬¥s Peak shadow, Only a short one after fog dissapeared and sun was up. I found the level of difficulty medium (though I think most people I witnessed arriving & going up as I was going down, found it moderately difficult. Plan you trip so you have enough time. You only need one night stay at Nallathanniya which is just at the starting point of the hike. I started the hike around midnight, leaving me enough time to get to the top at sunrise. Prepare for heavy traffic along the way. hence the early start. Once you are at the Indikatupahana a traditional landmark along the way, you have a choice to continue on the same route or change it to a more adventurous but rewarding one. Changing to the Ratnapura track will let you bypass the morning rush that piles up closer to the top. At a certain point before the sunrise, the temple will shut the entrance gate. You do not what to be stuck among thousands of people on a stairway knowing that you are missing the best view of the island. Also, make sure you have enough time to settle in, find a good spot to see the view well before the sunrise. Loved the street food along the way.

It's the 4th tallest in Sri Lanka. Youngest was just 7 and he climbed it without any hastle. We climbed during off season so the crowd was less and the shops all were not operative. Most prefer to do the 3 hour hike at night up the longest staircase in the world,according to Arthur C Clarke.The path is paved and perfectly maintained so even a senior citizen  wouldn't find too much difficulty in reaching the summit with some help. If the climb begins at 10 pm its perfectly possible to find few hours of sleep at the top before the sunrise .Wonder is not just in the sunrise .,its on the opposite side when the perfectly conical shadow of the sacred mountain spreads across the western mountains and valleys.for about few minutes. Climb down is easier with 'base camp' attainable in under 2 hours. A morning ascent is another option which is ideal for scenery sake.Best to begin the trek as early as possible so you would find decent solitude along much of the way until the pilgrims who climbed the night before start to appear out of the mist after 9 in the morning. Visibility up top could be shrouded in mist in most of the months so patience is needed to take a peek at the vista between clouds banks which roll in. The most exhilarating of the climbs would be the attempts done in off season ,between May and December ,much of which falling under the rainy season in the peak wilderness .This climb requires some planning as the rains in better part of the day may bring in cascades all along the route ,as well as down the staircase now turned in to a veritable water slide. Strategy should be to be clear of the mountain before 5 pm as the denizens of the forest would venture out by then.Summit would be occupied by few monks who would depend on weekly supplies from the town below .You may meet the post man who climbs the mountain each day and that would be the only human soul along the route unless there happen to be few others crazy as you. shoes need strong traction /water abundant in many creeks / warm drink in a flask /plenty carb/ biscuits /chocolates./Camera would be a burden unless well protected /clothes ready for a decent dunking /stick to the path ,don't venture out .Keep phone contact with the base in case .Best to report to police station before the climb and make sure to tell them when you come back. Difficulty level in an off season climb is high due to the high possibility of slipping on the concrete steps.

There isn‚Äôt much at the town, except that it‚Äôs the town closest to Adam‚Äôs Peak. We came in April to climb Adam‚Äôs Peak during pilgrimage season December to May. Due to enforced curfew, we can only start our climb after 4am aiming to reach the summit by sunrise at 6am. From the first step at the base to the last at the summit, the climb will get steeper and narrower, toward the top if you are running or walking in fast pace like us, there are hand rails to grip yourself up. The bus ride cost 184 Lkrs and will take close to 2 hours, Tuk tuk cost 1500Lkrs and 1 hour. The Tuk Tuk driver was sneaky, he told us the agreed price was for per person, I threatened to report him to the police since we are so early and have time to do so. Then he toke our money and drove off.

Do not underestimate how gruelling the climb is to the top of Adam‚Äôs Peak. 4800 uneven steps make it difficult to get into a rhythm on the ascent. But the path and steps are all concreted with hand rails on the steepest sections, so no mud to negotiate. If you are well prepared and reasonably fit, you will make the summit. Your legs might feel like jelly and heart will be pounding in your chest, but that is soon forgotten.
