Before you set off, make sure you climb at night when it‚Äôs coolest (a torch is handy for those sections that aren‚Äôt very well illuminated); check to see if it is expected to be busy (we did the round trip in 5 hours but heard of people taking 15+ hours at a weekend due to the volume of locals and tourists on the route); wear stout shoes and take warm clothing (it may be warm at the bottom but at night there can be a cold wind at the summit); take plenty of water with you (there are stalls on the way up where you can buy food and drink, but the price goes up with the altitude!). There are also occasional toilet facilities on the way up but you don‚Äôt get any niceties for your 30 rupee entrance fee. The best view of the sunrise is just below the summit, before you reach the temple area. And then there‚Äôs the descent!! Slow and steady in both directions and you‚Äôll be ok.

It was a hard trekking of approximately 12 hours on hard rocks and uneven surface. I would say, it is not the root for someone who has not tested his/her endurance or otherwise stamina. Nevertheless, the nature will pay you the effort by five folds, it‚Äôs guarantees. The trekker or the adventure will witness lots of green, waterways, small waterfalls, nice sceneries and many adventures during the trekking. The trekker should carry enough food and water because of due to limited supply on its way. I would not say no shops. There are shops, but limited numbers. At the same time some of the shops may close on weekdays due to a smaller number of people.

What an experience. We set off from our nearby guesthouse at 2am and climbed the stairs to peak for sunrise. I'd really recommend starting during the night, as climbing the stairs without the heat of the sun made a huge difference. Don't be put off by people saying it's too difficult (I scared myself a little before we went!) - we peaked in well under 3 hours and although the middle section was a little tougher, with regular breaks we made it to the top no problem. Yes, we were a little achey the next day, but totally worth it! We climbed on a weekday evening, and were pleased to see many more Sri Lankans than tourists climbing. We peaked at around 5am, took a look around and at the footprint, then based on advice we'd seen online started the climb back down before sunrise. We were so glad we'd read this - the top was incredibly crowded and any view would have been blocked by a mass of people and camera screens. The steps on the way back down have a much better view of the sunrise and face east more clearly. We walked 50 or so steps back down and sat to watch the sunrise there. Fantastic experience and would highly recommend for your time in Sri Lanka!

We went on to Kuruwita bus top to catch the first bus to Erathna at 6.00 am and the bus reached a place called Adevikanda by about 1 hr which is the starting point of the hike. It took 11 hrs (14 km) to reach to the top. There are plenty of natural beauty and sceneries to watch all the way we had a good river bath in Seetha Gagula on the way as well. First half was not much challenging but we felt the weight of our backpacks in last trench as even a plastic shopping bag felt as extra weight. Last two 2km was very steep and our group was really straggled. But little exercise and preparation could help you If you are not a seasoned hiker or a person who do regular exercises. Avoid holidays and weekend as it‚Äôs so crowed in summit and the may be long near summit to enter. Also be prepare to be at the summit at least couple of hours to rest and its always wise to choose Hatton/Nallathanniya route to go downhill as its shorter and easy. There are 03 routes to reach to peak of Sri Pada mountain. First route is Hatton/Nallathanniya route which is about 5 km to the top. This is the easiest. 90% of the people use this route. The second route is Siripagama route (also called Rathnapura route) is about 9 km to the top and you can experience the natural beauty as the trail is though the villages and jungle. However, the route has been modernized in recent past which lost somewhat of its beauty. Third route is the Kuruwita trail which is about 14km hike to the top. I have completed all three routes and but the Kuruwita trail is the most memorable eye pleasing experience. Yes, it was an exhausting/challenging 10- 12 hour hike but end of the day felt satisfied and accomplished.

I think it was worth it! It's a hard climb up nothing I would recommend if you are not used to workout(even though elderly lanes does it and small children). Bring warmer clothes, it is warm when you go up but freezing at the top. View was amazing and it was so cool when the sun went up and the surrounding mountains and beautiful views

At the entrance trek of adam' peak, there will be a few people waiting you along way to a contruction hindu temple, a group of people included a "monk". They will ask for donation 1000 sri lanka rupee, and in order to gain your trust , he will show you a book with plenty of name listed from different country. The way they approach you is like a must to pay for the donation prior enter and appear pushing attitude and blocking the entrance way. We refused to pay as this is called donation, if not the government would have set up a ticket counter, black and white written in the resit. We are travel as a groupvof 4 girls. We replied that we prefered to pay on the way back here. They answered the donation counter will be closed in an hour. We felt something not right. Then one of my friend answered the we will donate at the summit point. The guy get stunned, and stopped push us for the donation and let us walk pass the pathway. Overall is safe to hike at the midnight of night, along the pathway is full with local people there. Just be extra careful if someone ask for donation.

Well hiking 5500 steps is not easy, most of the review wrote that hike in midnight so that you can watch sunrise, but we start hiking at 6:30, after a difficult hike, we reached 2/3 of the mountain at 8:30, but there was cloud and in case of raining, we didn't go to the peak, we came back. My friends were very tired, but I love hiking, and I wanted to continue. If you love hiking, do it until peak point. We went on Sunday, it was full of Buddhists pilgrim. If you have chance to go in week day, it will be great, otherwise weekend is very crowd with local...

On the way to the starting of the hike, there will be a gang of guys with young bogus monk look like trying to lead you to the way up but actually they lead you to the otherside of the correct way and start asking for donation. They even have log book with the name of the donor and also the amount that they donate. I glance through the log book as they ask for donation ask like a fix price that is 1000 rupee. I realize that something fishy going on. I told them that i will do the donation after i comedown from the hike. One of tge guy told me that they will be there for limited time only and i can feel like they start to forcing me for the donation and not allow me to pass through the way up. I only able to pass through after i told them that since limit time only they have, i will do the donation when i reach the peak as isnt it the same. The gang and the bogus monk look stunned after they heard what i had told them.At the end luckily i manage to go through the obstacle safely.

First off, I'm in possibly the worst shape of my life. We started the hike around 1h45 and it took me about 3 hours to get to the top (would have taken less but it got a bit crowded at the top). About 2hours to come down. The temple is ok, the views coming down are great though. We did have to wait 2h at the top for the sunrise as we left too early, and it was very very crowded (and chilly!) at the top. I'd do it again though!

Amazing views once you made it all the way up the endless steps. Make sure you get there before sunrise. Pilgrim time is very special with a great atmosphere and do recommend going if you around at this time.

We did the hike in the daytime. It wasn‚Äôt too busy, just us and locals taking on the 5000 steps to the top. It was tough going! The main disappointment was that there was so much litter everywhere and a strong smell of sewage. It‚Äôs a sacred place for many religions but it‚Äôs so poorly maintained or looked after.
Really amazing journey,you can feel the fitness levels.Recommending to visit at least once in your lifetime.

Ignore the "don't go" and "too full" reviews. Yes, there's probably going to be a lot of people. And no, you might not make it the top. But the experience of taking the bus from Hatton to Delhouse (gorgeous scenary) and the 2am early climb are totally worth it. You mill be surrounded by hundreds of pilgrims and it will be a completely inlmerssive and maybe even a surreal experience as you walk with the people seeing all the shops along the way. Get as high as you can and then stay warm as you wait for sunrise. It will be gorgeous. Set your expectations accordingly and enjoy!

Sri Pada (Adams Peak) is one of the best hike to do in Sri Lanka. It's one of main holy mountain sacred since ancient times to Buddhists because of foot print of lord Buddha. Most of the tourist start climb early morning or midnight to see beautiful sunrise from too of Sri Pada. If you travel between December to April that's the season for climb.
Adams peak can be visit after December poya to month of May. Amazing place you should definitely visit. Specially dont visit in long weekend. Its very crowded.

Siri Pada- Adam‚Äôs Peak in English- is not for the physically unfit but an experience which I feel justifies the effort. It‚Äôs a religious site for all the main religions on the island-Adam‚Äôs footprint at the top for the Muslims, Buddha‚Äôs for Buddhists, Lord Shiva‚Äôs for  Hindus and for Christians either Adam as well or St Thomas (depending on who you read).  The aim is to arrive before sunrise to experience the wonderful colours and hopefully see the mountain‚Äôs reflection in the clouds. We saw both and it was truly amazing. There are various routes but the easiest is via Nallathanni (5000-6000 steps all the same) and that‚Äôs the one we took. After parking car you set off with initially a gentle rise but it quickly becomes more challenging as the steps are often higher than a normal stride (around 9‚Äù/20cm) Take energy boosting supplies (we took mars bars and energy drinks) although there are small shops (kade) along the way and for any but the fittest, walking poles are a real help, especially coming down. It‚Äôs really cold at the top so fleeces/ long trousers necessary. The climbing season is December to April although climbing outside these times is possible but cloud and rain can ruin the experience. Avoid Poya (full moon) days as crowds will be there and even though we went several days after full moon we still had a wait of around 1 1/2 hours on the final stretch. Coming down, for me at least, was the hardest as my knees were finding the descent a real strain.  However, many people of all ages and fitness do make it. We are both in our middle/late 60s and not super fit but did do a little ‚Äútraining‚Äù for about 3 weeks beforehand. We took 3 1/2 hours to climb but 4 to come down but the young couple staying next door to us (both looking pretty fit) took 2 1/2 hours up and 1 1/2 down. Your legs are pretty stiff the next day but for me all this was worth the pain. There is something about setting off at 1am to climb a mountain and although I‚Äôm not religious, it was a spiritual experience.

We did the hike on a week night during the season (feb. 2019). We were located at mango house (dalhousie) , the closest accommodation to the entry point of adam‚Äòs Peak. We started a 2 a.m., which gave us sufficient time to tackle those 5000 stairs at a relaxed pace. Aside from the physical challenge the social aspect was the most interesting. Most tourist get up to the top rather fast paced. Whereas the locals aren‚Äòt in a hurry. The beginning is more or less a walk, when the stairs get steeper and more narrow the whole scenery gets a more dystopian vibe. Exhausted people sitting on stairs, resting. Old people, even on crotches dragging themselves to the top. Aside from the path You are walking you surroundings are completely blacked out. It feels like you are on a ship or a tunnel, the wet and foggy air plays into that perfectly. At the last few hundred meters the steps are getting quite steep and everybody is holding on to those rails. You know everybody‚Äòs goal to get to the top but you don‚Äòt have any idea what it actually looks like up there. It‚Äòs a weird hike into the unknown. Up there it was crowded with people, just sitting in the mist, covered with blankets, keeping each other warm. The lost ship metaphor fits perfectly. Waiting to be saved by the sunrise. We rang the bell one time like we were supposed to. It was a cloudy day but that didn‚Äò dampen our experience. It was a relief, when the darkness was lifted and you could see your surroundings in daylight. It was demystifying, the dirt and waste covered areas near the stairs. It felt like being out all night, walking home, when the new day took his place, while wondering how different the world around you looks. Overall we loved it and told everybody about our experience. Even the getting back down wasn‚Äòt that bad. Our muscles made sure we remembered adam‚Äòs Peak even days after we did the climb.

This hike is not easy. I don't think an average person with no fitness routine will find this fun. We were a group of 4 young adults all with a good fitness routine and yet this hike proved to be very challenging. 5,500 steps is no easy hike! Initially we decided to hike in the night to make it for  sunrise at the peak but we were too exhausted from our previous day's activity and so we started our hike early morning at dawn. It's believed that Adam descended here on this mountain and so his footprints are found at the top. January to November is off season so you wouldn't find a lot of people and the temple is also closed. It took us 3 hours to climb and another 3 hours to descend. During off season everything is closed, you will find a few people climbing. There are no shops open or food stops. The place is also home to a lot of stray dogs, which tend to follow you. There are wild monkeys and pigs too. After a hard climb, wanting to give up half way, we finally made it to the top. The peak was windy, cloudy and super chilly. There was a guard outside but he wouldn't let us in because of the off season. Regardless the view from the peak was breathtaking and we were not left disappointed.

The climbing is challenging and fun. the way down is beautiful, can‚Äôt argue with that. BUT and it‚Äôs a big BUT! (We claimed it on a regular Wednesday, thought we will catch a beautiful sunrise) The problem is the amount of people - tons of locals in all ages climbing in order to pray, the road is full of temples and for the Buddhists it is a holly place. Therefore there is no chance to see the sunrise, no way to find a nice spot. The peak is basically a small temple full of people pushing each other. Disappointing. DONT WAIST YOUR TIME ON IT. Must say that If the top of the mountain wouldn‚Äôt feel like a crazy survival on the sunrise minutes place so it would be a great experience.

Was worried about it after reading negative reviews here and unfortunately they were accurate. I climbed on Tuesday Feb 26. Started at 1:50, reached the stopped / extremely slow moving line at 4:15. The waiting was terrible. So many people crammed in. Finally got up top and found a spot to wait for the sunrise. Put on all my warm clothes and waited an hour in the cold amongst the growing number of people. Once the sunrise began the whole pack of people all smooshed together in the direction of the sunrise to get the best picture. It became one static mob and it was impossible to move for at least 30 minutes. My hands/arms grew numb because I was being squeezed so tightly in all directions. Yes the sunrise is beautiful but better climb a different mountain to see a beautiful sunrise without all the stress. All the tourists I met along the way down felt the same. What a disappointment after anticipating this experience for so long.

We set off at 1am and hit queues at about 3am. The queuing lasted 5 hours before we were told by tourists coming down that we still had another 3 hours until the summit, so we turned around and went back to our hotel. Genuinely one of the worst experiences of my life. There was no redeeming feature. Queuing in the dark, half way up a mountain, freezing cold. It must be different on a week day as the other reviews are all really positive but I wouldn‚Äôt reccomend this to anyone.

Should you visit Sri Pada (also known as Adam‚Äôs Peak)? The mountain is best known  as a pilgrimage site for locals and tourists alike.  It is the most sacred mountain in Sri Lanka. There were around 5,500 steep steps on the way to Sri Pada Mountain. The top of the mountain has a huge footprint. The Buddhist residents say it's the footprint of Buddha's left foot. The Hindus claimed that the footprint belonged to Lord Shiva. The Muslims and the Christians believed that it was Adam's first step after being kicked out from the Garden of Eden. Yes, whoever braves the steps and reaches the summit would be rewarded with panoramic mountain views. It is an ecologically diverse place hidden from the world.

Nefelibata travels was very helpful and quick in arranging a trip for us from Colombo to Adams peak. Given the short notice of 5h after calling them, they gave us price quotes and were ready to pick us to begin our adventure. Prices were relatively reasonable and they were always punctual with their pick up timings. The driver was really nice as he bought us water and tissues in case we weren‚Äôt prepared for the hike as well. 4h of hiking to catch the unforgettable sunrise and another 2h of heading down. It was tiring but worth it. Catching the sunrise was one of the best ways to end our memorable trip. The driver brought us out for good Sri Lankan kotthu before we headed back to Colombo too. Definitely recommend :)

As instructed by our guide and hotel, we were out the door just after 1:15am in hopes of arriving at the summit for sunrise. We climbed the stairs for three hours (going at a modest pace with plenty of water/rest breaks in between) and thought we were just about to reach the summit when our journey came to a sudden halt... There were thousands (no exaggeration) of people ahead of us - all stopped! This was the line people had been talking about! Only, it wasn't some short queue like at the grocery store - it was interminable! We waited for 2.5 hours in the line, but only managed to move maybe 75 more steps towards the summit in that time. The chill combined with the anger of watching unashamed tourists blatantly skip the line by climbing through the bushes made those 2.5 hours absolutely miserable, too. We watched the sunrise in line around 5:30am (still gorgeous!), but finally decided to turn back around 7:15 am -- 6 hours into our journey -- once it became clear that we would be waiting another 3-5 hours (again, no exaggeration) in that line if we wanted to get to the top! In the end, we got back to our hotel after 10 am. A 9 hour adventure, and no summit. :( So disappointing! It wasn't a poya day. It wasn't a holiday. It was just crazy busy! We don't even think that leaving earlier would have made a difference, as the number of people was overwhelming. People from our hotel who went during the day seemed to have better luck... One other thing - several reviewers noted that going down the mountain was only a 1-2 hour affair. We found it to be 3+ hours... and that wasn't even getting to the top!

This is one of those "once in a lifetime" things. Do it once and you never need to do it again. We went at night so we could catch the the sunrise. Both of us weren't in particularly great shape, but also not sedentary creatures, and it took us about four hours to get to the top. Not going to lie, it's HARD. But overall, it's a great experience to share with travellers and pilgrims.

It was my second trip after almost 12 years. We started climbing from Nallathnanniya by 1 am. it was so cold & we was prepared with jacket  for it. We reach the top around 5.30. but could not go in until 7.30. they have worship time from 5.30am to 7am & try your best to reach their before 5.30am.  better to take short eats or biscuits as you are gone spend few hrs there. food and drinks are available but double the price. i dont think its too much as shop owners has to pay huge transport cost. avoid climbing in day time as it will difficult with the sun. go with better foot ware as there are many steps to climb. dont climb  fast take your time. pain will only come after one day of climbing.

We were a bit worried about the tales of queues and  not getting to the top for the sunrise, the trick as other reviews say is avoid poya days and weekends as the vast majority of climbers are local not tourists. I am a moderately fit 64 year old and it took us 3 hours, take your time and stop for a cup of tea and a biscuit, got to the top an hour before sunrise when it gets busy, Views and sunrise amazing, well worth the climb, legs a bit stiff next day, do  it!

We started our trek to the top of the mountain at 12.30 am, mainly because there would be less people and it would not be baking hot. We eventually reached to the top of the peak at 4.15 am, waiting to see what all the hype was about the sunrise from the top of the peak. The climb and the waiting was worth it, the sunrise was the most spectacular sunrise I have witnessed, in addition the views from the top of the mountain were amazing and a photographer's delight! The climb was steep and challenging but it can surely be done! Adam's peak is well known for the Sri Pada, i.e., "sacred footprint", a 1.8 m (5 ft 11 in) rock formation near the summit, which in Buddhist tradition is held to be the footprint of the Buddha, in Hindu tradition that of Shiva and in Islamic and Christian tradition that of Adam; there is also a temple at the peak.

We climbed last night and it was quite hard but don't be scared. Someone takes 2.5 hrs, some takes 3 or 4, but everyone can make it :)) I did it too and when you climb and see all other people - some in flip-flops - then yes, you can make it too :) The best place to see sunrise is from the side where the stairs are. But be ready, there will be a lot of people :) But the view is worth it :))

I started at 2.30 and I arrived at 4am sharp. Did no breaks, just looked down the stairs! What a challenge...if there will be a next time I‚Äôll start around 4am or I‚Äôll go slower. Up there it‚Äôs too crowded and the view isn‚Äôt really good. Go down a bit for an amazing view. Doing down was 60min, fast again and without any break. So if you‚Äôre in good shape you can even beat my time ;) (Went back by hop on bus to Hatton over Maskeliya for 100 rupees and took the train to Ella for 210 rupees 2nd class)

We went up at 2 a.m. and started our trip up. It was really a fantastic experience. A bit of a hard climb sometimes, but mostly steps. Impressive to see the locals climb (some 80+). We went on a Saturday which at the beginning felt nice as we were there with the locals, but when nearing the top we hade to stand in line for hours. Later we got to know that there were a three day-weekend which explained the many people. Try to avoid such dates and full moons, otherwise weekends are probably fine. Not that cold (at least not for a Swede), we went with a thin jacket and that was enough.

We went to Adam‚Äôs peak just before the pilgrimage season in Decembre and it was one of the best things I‚Äôve done in Sri Lanka. The hike up was exhausting and the walk down was way worse, but the sunset we got at the top was absolutely amazing! We went up at 3AM and it took us a bit less than 2 hours. When you‚Äôre almost at the top, I recommend you get a hot drink or just wait at one of the food places until it‚Äôs almost time for the sunrise, because it‚Äôs very very cold up there. Also, bring a pair of changing clothes (tshirt, sweater, scarf, hat) otherwise you might get sick with the cold up there after sweating.

Just don't... I mean, I expected that it will be difficult and crowded but I did not expect that crowd... I love hiking and dare to say my tempo during walking is high and it was also here until we did hit the crowd of locals. First 4km we did in about 1hour. Next 500m we stayed in line for approximately 2-3hours. Imagine black friday sales on top of the hill. Views are nice but not worth it.

Adam's peak was our first stop on our three week trip to Sri Lanka - we are both very physically fit but we found it exhausting! The hike is mainly steps all the way to the top- some of which are so steep! There are tea shops so you can stop for refreshments but it is very challenging. We set off around 4.30am and were back for 8am. Very sore legs for days after!

This is not a 'traditional' hike. All the way to the top is made of concrete steps so that everyone can do the hike. The hike is exhausting but even 70 year old ladies can do it (even if it takes longer). If you start at 3 am, you should be perfectly fine to reach the tip for the sunrise

5500 steps, some steep. Hand rails along some sections. During (pilgrimage) season time it is well lit with lots of people around. No special gear required. Just carry water, a good jacket to put on once you reach the summit as it gets really cold up there (if you are doing the sunrise climb), and a camera. You can carry light snacks or buy them along the way up as there are plenty of vendors. Took me about 2 hours 15 mins to ascend at a steady, un-rushed pace. Started at 3 am and reached well before sunrise. Suitable for all fitness levels.

I so worried about doing this, will it be too hard, will it be too busy (we went on a national holiday day), will it be too cold, will it be difficult doing overnight??? The worries went on. But my other more calmer pragmatic half told me to just do it...and I'm so glad I did. Yes it was hard, walking all those steps isn't gonna be easy, but there are hand rails for the steep ones and there's just no rush, pace yourself and take it easy - it's totally doable. Plus if 80 year olds with sticks and pregnant ladies also carrying another child can do it, then anyone can do it. Yes it's busy but not consistently, there were busier patches around rest stops and steeper parts but that's good as you get to have a rest too. And despite it being a national holiday it wasn't as bad as people made out. It was busy at the top, so the last 150 meters we queued but I was glad as I could the steep steps one at a time and rest in between. People around me (my other half was ahead) were friendly and kept me going especially one old chap who kept telling me only X amount of meters! Yes it's cold at the top so do take layers and will more than likely have to sit on the floor so maybe a small blanket is a good idea. But it's not long before the sun's up and it gets hot again so bring sun cream too! Yes it's difficult walking at night, but again just prepare yourself. drink plenty of water, take or buy snacks along the route and take rests when you need them. Overall it's so worth it, the views are amazing, the experience is one I'll never forget, the people are so interesting and friendly. For some this really is a pilgrimage, to heal them, to bless them and it humbles you. I was quite emotional at the top, probably from the pure exhilaration of doing it and tiredness but also witnessing so many people to whom it meant so much was so special. And to be accepted as a westerner without affiliation was very special. So I say, just do it!

Did the climb as a family including a 7 and 8 year old.  Was challenging but a great thing to do.  We didn't do the early morning climb to see the sunrise, so when we climbed saw a few tourists returning but otherwise only saw locals.  No toilets near the top, plenty of little shops for drinks and snacks.  Watching locals carrying 30 - 50 kg loads on their heads whilst climbing was inspiring

This was something i wanted to do when i decided to head to Sri Lanka however i didnt really do my due diligence and so ...its tougher that you think its going to be...up ..and down. So - give yourself plenty of time if you want to be up there for sunrise. I started earlier than normal and attacked the steps until such time as I realised that you need to pace yourself and quite literally let the steps come to you (very zen i know!). As a Western tourist I admired the older pilgrims who were climbing in their bare feet. When you get to near the top the steps get very steep and you need to take care. The sunrise was a stunner although a big group of Italians decided not to take the Silence sign to heart! You need to take care on the way down...the legs..the knees are aching and the best advice i can give is to try and get a leg massage. But i was very happy i did it...and so will you!!

This seems to be a hike on more and more tourists' radars - indeed, when I hiked I reckon more than two-thirds of those doing it were western tourists.  Anyway, this is a non-technical hike in that 90% of it is steps, but it's still pretty tough on your body - 1000m or vertical ascent over 5500 steps is going to hurt pretty much anyone who isn't a mountain runner!  The start of the most common hike from Hatton Road is somewhere in the middle of Dalhoosie - it's not marked anywhere, I assume it's somewhere past the bus station, maybe at the first bridge you cross?  Anyway, it's possible to get slightly lost early on, so check if you're not sure (ask a local, there'll be a few around!)  You'll also get accosted by local monks too, so be sure to take some rupees for donations!  The hike is strenuous and while it'll probably feel a bit cold at the start you'll soon warm up.  Make sure you take something warm for the top though as you'll soon cool down up there before the sun comes up.  You'll need food and water for the hike, but you don't need to load up like I did, there are many many vendors selling food, drinks and clothing right the way from the bottom to (almost) the top, so you can get stuff en route if need be (in my defence, I was trying to reduce my plastic footrpint!)  If you take it steady you'll have no issues, but the thing to remember is that seventy year old women do this barefoot in the rain, so it shouldn't be a problem for most people.  Dont get me wrong, it's not easy - it's not supposed to be, it wouldn't be much of a pilgrimage otherwise - but I'd say it's absolutely doable for most people, just give yourself a little more time if you're not 100% sure of yourself.  The top is very busy and for some reason the temple doesn't get opened up until after sunrise (not sure if this has always been the case?) so the steps up will be very crowded.  Get up a little earlier to get a decent position for the sunrise if possible.  I did it during peak season, though on a non-poya weekday, and it was still very crowded, so expect quite a few people up there jostling for position when the sun comes up!  The temple is a little disappointing visually, but it's the spiritual side that matters I guess, certainly this seemed to be the case for the locals when they got up there.  Be sure to also get a photo looking west when the sun comes up, where the shadow of the mountain is cast onto the horizon.  Also don't underestimate the journey down - your tired, lactic-acid-filled legs will be fighting against you so be a little careful!  And don't make plans for any major hikes for at least a couple of days afterwards - it'll take a bit of time for your body to recover.  Overall though, a very good experience, I'd say well worth doing as it's genuinely a bit of a challenge, and I think if you keep in mind the spiritual pilgrimage background to this hike you'll probably enjoy it a lot more.

It was a mind blowing hike since I did it solo at 04:30h on a weekday. However I just missed to be on top for the sunrise but since I was almost there (5mins away from the top) I think I even had a better view which no1 get to see more often. I did the hick in 2hours and since I was in a hurry to see the sunrise, my recommendation is to take time and hick to enjoy more if you are travelling with a group.My trip was from Hatton road and my next plan is to take the Rathnapura road which I believe more adventurous...

I have wanted to do this hike for years (ever since I was a child), and decided to go in off season, thinking it would be quieter. It definitely was quiet, my traveling partner and I were 2 out of 10 (literally) travellers in the town. It was wet, we lucked out a little with the rain as it didn't pour down on us as it had the other people who were there the day before. Basically the pilgrimage to the top was amazing, but the clouds covered every possible view. Couldn't see more than a couple feet in front of yourself. Plus, the temple was closed when we arrived at the top.

So I did the early trek up. Starting at two on a clear night. The way up was fine. Just got soaked because of the effort and the high humidity. So it is good to bring a clean shirt for when you arrive at the top. It is kinda cold. I also had to wait a decent amount. Make sure that you have a decent spot for when it starts.

I walked Adam's Peak with my husband and two children (age 14 and 11).  I was concerned about the volume of steps, but it wasn't as bad as I expected and it's really only the last section that seems to go on forever! We climbed on Thursday 20th December and I was worried it would be too busy but it was mainly tourists and not busy at all.  Part of the route wasn't lit, so we used the torches we'd bought the previous afternoon from market traders.  This was money well spent. We wore skins and jumpers and were far too hot on the climb up, but definitely needed the layers whilst waiting for the sunrise (too cloudy unfortunately). There were a few stalls open on the way up, so in hindsight we didn't need to overload with water and snacks. It took us less than 2.5 hours to go up, with lots of breaks, particularly during the final hour and then about 2 hours on the way down. There are toilets on the mountainside, but I would say only use them if desperate. Remember a donation for the monks.
It is a very long hike, but the view is excellent.  Make sure to get up there early (well before sunrise) as space is limited and it gets crowded quickly.

We did this just over a  week before Poya in December so it was really only tourists doing the climb at this time, which probably was no bad thing as I can only imagine how crowded it must get during the pilgrimage season.  Out of season you will need a good headtorch or torch as its fairly dark in places and there were only a few teashops etc open at that time of year.  Its also pretty chilly while waiting for the sun to rise too.  One thing that was truely amazing was the night sky on the climb up, I've never seen so many shooting starts, just spectacular. The sunrise itself was beautiful but unfortunately the temple itself was closed, the concrete buildings where the sun comes up are also a bit of a blight on a beautiful landscape too which is a shame.  However, well worth the hike and watching the sunrise in all its glory.  Magical.  You can also take in the view on the way down.  Definitely achievable for most fitness levels, its steps pretty much all the way up (and then down again of course). It took us 2.5 hrs with a few stops enroute.

The view was amazing, during the season it gets super crowded, so I opted to watch the sunrise on the stairs between the last tea house and the main "temple" at the peak. The views from there are even better, as there is no fence or wire covering the sight. So I would recommend doing this no matter the season. After the sunrise most tourists went straight down again, so I waited for the crowds to clear and climbed the last bit. Best choice! You can actually get a feeling for the place and the people praying/chanting, amazing energy. Spent nearly an hour at the top, just taking in the scenery. If you're super fit you'll manage to go up in 2 hours. I'm in the worst shape of my life and it took me 2,5h, although I was really hurrying. (I actually took a wrong turn in the beginning and didn't realize until after 1 hour, so by the time I got to the beginning of the stairs it was already 3:30. Oh, the horror!) So for people with no sense of orientation like myself, maybe check out the entrance the day before. The walk up there is some proper full-on, though unwanted ;), kardio.

This was by far the most difficult but worthwhile thing I've ever done on my trip so far. We were staying at The Greenhouse guesthouse and left at 03:30 timed the trip perfectly got to the top with mins to spare so no waiting around in the cold! We did go in the off season so not sure how long it would tike in peak season. Definitely a must do thing in Sri Lanka!

Loved setting off in the dark and waiting for sun rise at the top - if fit, easily done in 2 hours. More steps than you can imagine and most are much bigger height than normal. Calves after coming down ached for days.

I'm a fast hiker to I left the city at 3am and got to the top at 4:30, so had to wait an hour to see the sunrise. My headlamp wasn't working so it was a challenging hike since I couldn't see much and there was no light on the trail since it wasn't officially open for the season. The view from the top and the sunrise is totally worth it but it can also be a great day hike if you don't want to leave too early.

The Adam's Peak climb is not for the faint of heart but is incredibly rewarding. My grown son and I made the climb early Christmas morning, and it was a very moving experience to be with throngs of Sri Lankan pilgrims as well as visitors from all over the world. The climb was an effort but certainly manageable for someone with moderate fitness, and the trail was quite good. There are tea shops which offer rest stations and snacks all along the journey, so it is definitely possible to make the climb in a reasonably leisurely manner as long as you start early enough. We arrived in plenty of time for the sunrise and were able to see the temple and footprint beforehand, as well as the dawn ceremony by the Buddhist monks. The crowding to film the sunrise was a little intense, but there was actually space on the side where the pyramidal shadow of the mountain appears, and the view of the surrounding landscape is breathtaking. I will remember and be grateful for this experience for the rest of my life.

A great sunrise (SO early in the morning), and so full of people - some of them apparently having a religious experience.  It was a "one time" kind of experience, I've seen a lot of sunrises on many a mountain - this was one more.

Not the easiest of walks a total of 27 500 steps of climbing through very difficult so should be done by professional hikers. If regular person goes up should leave early like 1am and take multiple breaks. Carry lots of liquids however their are multiple tea shops on the way. Once you reach the top the sunrise is amazing. Coming down is also a challenge with steps. Carry a strong flash light  torch as well. We did it with kids of 7 and 3 years and it was definitely challenge so if the kids could do it so can you

We decided to go up the mountain in the we We decided to go up in the morning with the sunlight instead of in the night in the dark. It was warm enough and not too hot at the same time. The hike up was nice and my girlfriend and I had a very nice time. It took us exactly 3 hours with a couple of breaks in between. I have to admit that we do sports on a regular basis so we had a good constitution going up. Going down seemed to be more difficult for us. We had a funny race with the series opponent - a slow but steady monk. :-) We knew that it is only steps going up and not an actual trail so we were not disappointed at all but we found it was a nice challenge. The views are very nice. We climbed up the mountain on December 16 which was a Sunday and we hardly met any people. We learned that the program season starts on the first full moon of December so we were lucky going up five days before. Because it was not the high season a lot of shops were closed which was not a problem for us. Please make sure that you bring enough water and sunscreen. The summit itself is not so interesting as it is only a minor temple with limited relevance unless you have religious motives. We reach the summit at 11:30 AM and we experienced breathtaking views in every direction.  In the beginning it was a little chilly because we were of course sweating a lot. After 20 minutes and after changing our shirt we sat down in the sun and it was actually very warm. The way down was a little bit more challenging as I have problem with my left knee. We did some breaks again and we needed three hours but you can easily make it down to two hours I would say. Contrary to a lot of other reviews here we did not face any problems with our legs afterwards - only our a right calfs made some minor problems to me AND my girlfriend surprisingly. Summing up I would say it's a challenging but rewarding experience!

I made the climb in 2 hours and 15 minutes with no stops.  It's pure stairs the whole way, no hiking.  The top was a serious let down.  It's completely built over, not a single quiet spot in nature where you can sit and watch the sunrise.  It's all concreted over and surround on all sides by buildings and walls.  As the sun was rising everyone was climbing over each other to raise their phones over head to snap pics of the sunrise.  I was expecting a 360 view and a tree off somewhere to meditate as the sun came up.  But no.  You can't ever step foot off of concrete or experience natural beauty at all.  On the trip back down you can get some much nicer views.

Took a bus from Tangalle to Nuwara Eliya then to Hatton then to Maskeliya and finally to Nallathaniya... They say it's customary for religious purposes to do the home at 2am however my partner and I aren't religious and decided to hike at 6am instead... It still a good time as the sun was not peaking and it was cold so it balanced the sweat.... The hike starts off slow and then suddenly bhaaam steps for Africa.... It was a good hike, I'm quite fit and enjoy hiking but the first 1000 steps killed my lungs probably due to the cold air that I wasn't used to ... Anyways it got better and I'd say that anyone can do it... My partner and I are quite competitive so we did it in 1hr and 50min and 1hr to reach the bottom... When we reached the top, we weren't allowed to get in the temple due to us missing the sun rise hike but it didn't matter, you still get a good view of the layers of mountain... Be sure to stretch your CALVES...
The climb was ok. Climbing down was difficult since the railings were missing in most places. Saw the sun rise.

Can't say that getting to the top was a pleasure - nearly two hours of walking up the stairs, soaked with sweat and trapped between the other visitors. Once we summited, the view was breath-taking and absolutely worth it. Just consider your timing if you decide to get there before the sunrise. Getting to the top without taking any breaks and at fast pace took us 1:45. My in-laws (mid 50) made it in almost 3 hours. You need to critically assess your capabilities to make sure you do not miss the sunrise. Also, consider that if you are faster than you expected you need to take something warm to dress (long pants, socks, a hat). We almost froze to death, it's really cold at the top and being sweaty only makes it worse.

Just to balance a bit the comments here, if you are reasonably fit you can reach the summit and be back in a couple of hours but if you are not fit you probably won‚Äôt reach the summit. I am an over 50 mountain runner and it took me 2 hours 20 both ways. The stairs are in good condition, becoming increasingly steep with handrails for the steepest part. The views on the forest, lake, stupa and waterfalls are magnificent. If you wander out or the stairs as I did, you may come back with leeches on the legs. Enjoy !
expect a difficult walking journey for 6-8 hours..don‚Äôt expect an amazing view because of foggy weather..

Well myself and my partner both 50 did this last week and let‚Äôs get real it‚Äôs bloody hard work!!!! We went during the day just to enjoy the experience it was hot and three days later I can just about walk without my calf muscles hurting. It‚Äôs definitely worth the effort but don‚Äôt kid yourself that it‚Äôs easy if your not used to that level of exercise!!

We climbed off season (Nov) and didn't know how much of an impact the temple being closed would be. The top was an anti climax, we didn't get to see the sunrise as it was cloudy, thankfully there was a break in the clouds on the way down, which we got to see the stunning view. We read that the trek was mod/easy, we are both walkers and keep fit and we found it incredibly tough! It is unbelievably steep in places and the steps are relentless! There was welcome rest points along the way, locals selling tea, roti and snacks... Worth starting around 2:30-3am...it took us 3 hours to get up at a steady pace, it was a good job we didn't rush as a lot of people were beating it up and ended up waiting around at the top getting cold. Definitely take a rain coat and something warm for the peak!

If travelling in Sri Lanka, you should definately climb up Adam‚Äôs Peak/Sri Pada. That is, if you are in OK shape physically. It is about 5500 stairs, and really steep some places. We saw people really struggling, and some that that had to turn around. So it might not be for everybody. If the shape is not the best, remember to have enough time. We started walking at 02.40 and were on the top at 05.10. I think we went in an average tempo, and we also had some stops here and there. Why so early? To reach the sun rise at 06.00! The view at sunrise was really, really beautiful, and a great reward for climbing in the darkness for hours. We went off season (season starts in December I think). This means fewer people, fewer open ¬´shops¬ª along the way, and less lights. So if you go off season - bring flash, light, water and some food. And bring some warm clothes to wear when you‚Äôre up, it might get cold. The way down goes faster of course, but can be a little hard for legs and knees. Now the sun is up, so you can enjoy the great view the whole way downüòä We stayed at Slightly Chilled, and can really recommend that place. Nice room, good food, and great staff. One night is enough though, not a lot to do in Dalhousie besides the climb.

Left around 2am for the peak and realistically should have left around 3am. It took two hours to walk up whilst talking and also stopping to catch your breath at certain points. Just before the top there is a mini stop to get a coffee, tea and Roti? At the top the views were worth the wait for sunrise 5.45am. Get a good seat at the top by the stairs to the temple or the right side to avoid the view of the building in the  way at the top. Well worth the climb up and down.

As I did not want to lose a day feeling tired I decided to do the Adam's peak hike at sunset instead of sunrise. I started hiking at 2.30 and reached the top around 4.50. Walking down took us around 1,5 hour.The weather was a bit hot (around 24 C), but the views on the way up were beautiful. On the way up I only met 3 other tourists and a guide (coming back down) and local workers who are repairing the stairs for when the temple is going to reopen next month. We were three people only at the top (including the priest of the temple). It was quite cloudy at the top so the sunset was not amazing but the views up and down below the top were well worth it. The stairs are very easy in the beginning but get quite steep up around the top (once the handrails start) and there really are a lot of stairs... I saw some monkeys, dogs and a wild boar as well during the walk. Some of the shops were open but I would recommend to not completely rely on that and bring your own water/snacks. In the middle of the hike there are no shops for a long time. Don't forget mosquito spray, rain coat (I did not have rain), hat + sunscreen (sunset), warm clothes/change of clothes for at the top. Do not forget a torch whether you hike at sunset or sunrise. You have to be fit.. it is not easy. Some people at the hotel did the same hike at sunrise the day after and they had about 100 people at the top. They did see the sunrise but not the view as it was cloudy as well. I guess you just have to be lucky.

A tough climb up. We left our guest house at 2:30 AM and arrived at the start (the shrine) at 3:00 AM. It took us about 2,5 hours to ascend with a few stops along the way. This is off season and it's not recommended to do because of rains, mist and falling rocks, but we were fine. Once we arrived at the top it was a true victory for us and we were blessed with dry weather all night and day and a wonderful view over the hills and valleys. It's not about watching the sunrise from the top, it's all about the climb itself. The descend was tough as well, mostly for the knees. But it was amazing to see the landscape bathing in sunlight. Great experience!

After leaving my hotel at 0245 I took on the walk of 5500 steps, what a hike this was. If you go from ratnapourer it‚Äôs 12500!!!! Watch out for leaches, I got done even with boots socks and long trousers. No guarantee of a view, it‚Äôs not always about the destination!!! But I was luck :-)

Would 100% recommend - not a must but if you like hiking I would advise!! Left at 2am...didn‚Äôt have any water with me but there were plenty of shops on the way up - even in the off season. Take a head touch as most isn‚Äôt lighted. Despite the 2am start it isn‚Äôt cold at all - just a t shirt is absolutely fine...when you start walking you warm up! Even shorts would be fine. Pack a spare t shirt as you will want a fresh one for the way down! We went in off season and it was cloudy at the top and didn‚Äôt actually see the sunrise. Best advice - if it gets 10 mins to scheduled sunrise and it‚Äôs cloudy, just go down some steps - still a great view and you get to admire the sunset. Even though there was no sunrise, the views on the walk down were worth it 100%. If you‚Äôre a lone traveller it‚Äôs a great way to meet people as you get the bus from Hatton together.

I climbed Adams Peak 30.10.18. Most shops and stalls were closed and it wasnt to busy. Top tip, when you get to the top, walk back down past the tea stall and on the right hand side there is a platform with a much better view without people or wires in your way. Took 2 hours at a very fast pace each way with 30 minutes on top. I would also recommend to bring a spare t-shirt to change into as you sweat a lot on the way up and its very chilly at the top.

I decided to climb alone in late October. I normally like off season travels and as long as you know what you are getting into this is an amazing adventure! I stayed in nearby Maskeliya instead of Nallathanniya. Started the climb at 2:30am reached the peak at 5am. Deceased at 6am and reached the bottom at 7:30am. Couldn‚Äôt see the sunrise but I was expecting that anyway. The views were stunning tho, the climb it self is a brutal one! Gradually getting steeper and steeper once you hit the top the feeling of achievement is immense. I would say there was roughly 30 people climbing and most of the way I was completely alone...exactly what I wanted üòä Get the following and you will be fine! - head torch - back up torch - 1 ltr water - snacks - thermo flask with coffee üòâüëåüèΩ - rain coat üß• in case (didn‚Äôt rain) - Sidalepa (Sri lankan balm for leeches) - don‚Äôt wear slipper wear trainers and keep ankles covered. Rub the balm all over feet and ankles! other wise the leeches will get you! Enjoy this special pilgrimage site

This is a bit of a Buddhist pilgrimage and possibly one of the hardest walks I have ever done, not that I‚Äôm a fell walker or mountain climber. It was eight miles to the top and back and you set off at 2:30 am to get up there for sunrise. We went off season so when we got up there the little temple was closed so we couldn‚Äôt see the footprint that the Buddhists climb up to see, this was probably a good thing as I have heard you can get close to the top and then have to start queuing to climb the last leg. If you do go out of season make sure you take a torch, head torch is probably the best, also make sure you take plenty of water, you‚Äôll need it.

We started at 3am giving us plenty of time to reach the top for sunrise, it took 2 hours to reach the top, it is hard climb but worth the effort, I got to watch the sunrise on my 50th birthday which was my reason for climbing.

We started our trek at 2am knowing full well the peak will be in the clouds as we reached the top, but we wanted to do it anyways. We knew the trek would be physically hard?! But that was hard hard! Took us 6 hours haha and coming down was the hardest part for us! Took a good 5 - 6 days for my legs to recover! Just be mindful of leeches! Try and cover up your legs as much as possible, especially your ankles where they easily got into and wriggled their way into your shoes! YUK! Take 40% deet insect spray with you!, thats good to protect yourself from leeches too! Other then that, enjoy and give yourself a pat on the back when you've done it! :)

We left our hotel at 5 am in the dark, only using a mobile phone light as a torch, which was sufficient, though it would be better to use a proper torch as it didn‚Äôt get light until about 5.45 am. We decided not to use a guide which was fine as there were signs showing us where to go.  Luckily we took a small amount of money with us as we were greeted at a Temple at the beginning of the walk by a monk who requested we sign our names into a register book and make a small donation before he blessed us and wished us good luck.  The walk quickly changes from gradual rising easy slopes into continuous steps.  The view throughout the walk is breathtaking with lots of photo opportunities.  The last 20 minutes of the walk is probably the hardest and steepest, though being able to see the temple at the top is motivating.  Besides the spectacular view at the top you will not find much else except the temple, which was not accessible when we were there. As we left our hotel too late to see the sunrise we were lucky enough to pass may travellers coming down from the peak and when we arrived at top we were the only people up there. The climb down is much easier and quicker.  This walk took us just over 4 hours. A great way to start the day, I would certainly do this walk again.

Try not to be put off from doing this walk, so long as you have s good level of fitness and prepare sensibly, it is very doable and not something to stress about. First for some practical advice. You will need: *A torch (essential as it is pitch black and you can‚Äôt do it without one) *1.5 litres of water per person *idealy some high energy snacks, we haf breakfast bars and that was fine * rainjacket, unless of course you are travelling in peak season in which case maybe not *comfortable shoes or trainers (I worr running shoes and was fine) *a change of tshirt for the way down (you get sweaty on the way up) Start time: 2.30am Arrival at the top: 5.30am Finish at the bottom: 8am So, we started this walk at 2.30am, like most other people. We booked a hostel very closeby, a mere 10 minutes walk which was super handy. As you start there are a few street stalls where there you can but water, and some sell torches. There are also lots of large and interesting shrines. For the first 20 minutes or so the walk is quite pleasant, and is actually well lit in some areas. After however as the steps begin the walk gets a bit tougher. The steps were fine, there were just a lot of them. About mid-way, after 1.5 hours walking, is when the walk became more arduous. The steps become steeper, and you need to rest at regulat intervals. There was drizzling rain on and off up the walk which was not a problem as we had our rain jackets, but did mean we got very hot and sweaty. We were not the only ones feeling the burn, everyone around us were healthy looking, and were also hving to rest every 10 minutes of so. After about 2.5 hours of walking it started lightening up a touch and we could see the peak, which really spurred us on. The final stretch is another arduous bit, but by that point you are used to it. In terms of the top itself, it was very misty and there was no sudden breaking of dawn. The temple itself was closed and so 30 or so tourists and some Sri Lankans sat around watching the sunrise. The views were nice, but as we were a bit cold my brother and I changed into a spare, dry shirt we brought and headed off. It was only as we headed down that we really got a sense of how the beautiful the place was. There were waterfalls, forested areas, a few monkeys, and beautiful mists floating around. It really was worth it for the views back down! I would recommend this walk to any healthy persons happy for a hard couple of hours of walking. We went off season and the weather was okay. Cool, but not too rainy. I would just note that the village of Dalhousie itself although very tranquil and pretty was also pretty much dead. The coffee shops were empty, and I felt fortunate that our hostel had a restaurant as the restaurants around werent especially inviting. We also wanted to buy a few basic toiletries (mouth wash, some ulcer gel) and the shops did have any of it, so just make sure you have everything you need when you hear over. Do Adam‚Äôs Peak walk, so long as you go in expecting to have to work your legs you‚Äôll very likely have a great time!

I had read a lot about Adam‚Äôs Peak and the pictures which are shared by other travellers look really amazing. Finally we decided to climb the mountain. We started at 2.00 am, reaching the top at 5:30 am, just 15 minutes before the sunrise. September is off season so there are not many coffee shop to rest. We were lucky because the afternoon was raining, but the weather was clear at night. The views are gorgeus! The best sunrise ever.

A real sense of achievement climbing to the top in the middle of the night. We found it very tough - both up and down, but it was a great experience and watching sunrise from the top with about 50 others was amazing. What a view! I think we were very lucky with the weather. I know that I wouldn't have done it in the pouring rain as I would be worried the steps would be too slippery. Make sure you bring a torch, plenty of water and something warm to wear at the top.

Amazing experience! Don't overestimate your fitness level, this is a very hard hike. I left the accommodation at 2:30am and reached the top around 5:00am, right on time for one of the best sunrise ever! Going down is has hard as the climb because your legs are extremely tired. All stalls and kiosks on the way up were close. It's pitch dark, carry a torch light with you or you won't be able to do it. Bring  a change and warm clothes for the top, it gets cold especially when you are soak in sweat. Highlight of my stay in Sri Lanka! Totally recommended but be aware of sore legs for at least 4 days.

Check the weather before you decide to do in off season. Hiking in the dark and pouring rain, we were soaked by the time we got to the top. The temple was closed (which we knew before heading up) so people just clustered under awnings trying to keep dry until sunrise. It was intensely windy and very cold. It was so cloudy that you could not see sunrise or any scenery. Overall a hard hike up and down would have been worth it if the weather was better and views were available, however I wouldn‚Äôt recommend in off season.

normally the off season and often has hazy views. If you are lucky you can witness the best sunrise in Sri Lanka. What a climb. Over 5000 steps... all .concrete, all the way to the top, that's amazing in itself and 2243 mts high. you can see different birds and some animals.

We had a lovely walk up Adam's Peak and were lucky enough to have perfect weather.  We chose to start walking at 6am so we could enjoy the scenery in both directions. We missed sunrise on top of course, but also got to do the climb completely on our own, and we were the only people at the top. There isn't much space at the top, and I think at least 100 tourists came down as we went up.  The climb took us 2 hours from the hotel and the descent just over an hour. So if you are quite fit and don't want to sit in the dark for 2 hours consider starting a bit later in off season! A daytime ascent would probably also be a good choice in bad weather.  The fact that the temple at the summit is closed doesn't detract much from the loveliness of the walk: it's a great hike and the views, if you get them, are superb.

This was a voluntary activity which my wife and I decided to do. It is spectacular, but it‚Äôs a tough climb. The views from the top when you get your breath back are stunning. The temple is closed at the top from June to October, so you won‚Äôt see the foot, but it‚Äôs something that is worth doing. It was about 5.5/6 hours return for us. We passed people who gave up. The slope is daunting, but due to the rapid rise the temple comes into view quickly.

What a climb.  Over 5000 steps... all concrete, all the way to the top, that's amazing in itself and 2243 mts high. We were told to start early to arrive to see the sunrise.... we chose to start at 8am which was a wise choice. We started in a slight drizzle and the early part of the trek was through hundreds of little tea shops that were 98% closed due to off season. The track meandered up a valley with lush green bush and numerous waterfalls across the valley.... and then it felt like we were climbing vertically. We climbed... and ... climbed ... and climbed. It got considerably colder the higher we got and started raining quite heavy not far from the top. So of course we had absolutely no view the entire climb as we were shrouded in mist all the way. Thats the weather for you... totally unpredictable. There were some interesting little places and temples on the way up but we were quite chilled and just wanted to get up to the temple at the top and back for a hot shower. Some places were very very steep and slow going, some parts had hand rails which was helpful. Very disappointed to find the gates at the top locked so we couldn't even walk around it. We made it up and back in half the time we were told so that was good. It was a great feeling to know that we had climbed to the peak and back.

31st Aug 2018. Wee hours 1AM. Pitch darkness. Mountain with some wild animals & quite built up steps for about 5000ft climb Non season so only very few people. Since we are not professional climbers they recommended we start early to reach on time at 5.30 for sunrise. When we three (that included a guide) started there were no one. wild sounds and waterfalls and stream sounds all around it was a scary feel. Very cold occasional dew drops from trees in the beginning. As we reached close to top the dew drops were like rain drops. After about a quarter of the trip there was a tea stall. Where we met some fellow climbers from Europe. as I was slow and steady by the time we reached top at 530, we had about 50 Europeans reached and thats all the crowd. Being non season Sivan Oli Pada  Malai Temple now Buddha Pada temple was closed. The chill strong breeze on the top was thereupatic. We stayed on top for about 30mts and headed down. Again we moved slowly stretched our time breathing fresh clean air. Another natural detox excercise for mind and body
one of good place in srilanka nice place with green colour ,dutch church ,adamespeak its really good to visit

We hiked the peak in August which is the low season because of the monsoon. There were like 20 other people all tourists. It was very misty and believe me it is not something easy to do during the heavy rains. The earth floods it's like walking in a very cold river for 6 hours!! All of this and the gate to the footprint is closed during the monsoon and you cant see the promised views because of the fog. But hey you can get a nice warm cup of tea at the top!

If you climb Adam's peak once you are a fool. If you climb it twice, you're an even bigger fool. This saying is exactly how I feel. I'm glad we did it, but unfortunately it was not the season... the season is in January/February.
one of the hardest walks of my life but when you start getting higher the view is amazing, would not recommend for everybody but if you like waking up stares for a couple of hours it is worth it

I have climbed the sacred mountain 02 times now and will definitely go again. But I've never used the easy and crowded Nallathanniya route. For the first time I took to Erathna road and the second time I ventured on the Palabaddala route. Those paths can be considered moderately difficult ones. ( Tougher than Nallathanniya). What I don't like most is the crowd at the top. Especially if you summited in the early morning to watch the overhyped sunrise, It'll be jam-packed there. If you're willing to try tougher but scenic routes, Choose Erathna or Palabaddala instead of famous Nallathanniya. Btw "Sri Padaya" is the correct name. It has a long history before this "British" try call it whatever they want.

It is not easy to get there, the way up and down its pretty hard, but definitely worth for it. Just prepare yourself good with warm clothes or blanket while are you waiting for sunrise. It could be pretty crowded tho! Not only with tourist but with the locals as well. So definitelly you are not going to be romanticly alone there.

Don't climb the peak in the off season to see the sunrise. If it rains the peak will be in the clouds. You will not be able to see the sunrise. The peak is worth climbing because the path up is beautiful.
Had quite high expectations, but ruined by weather, heavy rain and fog. It must be good during season, but off season doesn't worth it.

Our experience and what I expected of Adam‚Äôs peak were two very different things! In hindsight I wouldn‚Äôt do it in the off season - Dalhousie was like a ghost town with only a very few number of tourists and we were the only ones in our hotel. We set off at 3 and it took us two and a half hours to get to the top. Climb was fine but very wet. At the top there was a huddle of cold, soaking tourists - unfortunately the temple was shut and we were in the middle of a cloud so no sunset to be seen. Bit of an anticlimax so started the slow, soaking walk back down. There are loads of stalls on the way up so can only imagine what the buzz must be like in the pilgrimage season. Overall we did enjoy it but not sure it was worth a night out of our holiday and two days travelling. There were no direct buses from Hatton so two buses took around 2.5 hours, or 1 and a half in a tuk tuk.

We set off at 3. The climb was pretty boring, the weather was terrible. Got the the top and it was all closed, windy cloudy and cold. Such a shame we took a 8hour bus detour to get here. Wouldn‚Äôt risk this when the weather can be so shocking. Could probably find better in the fricin Peak District.

If you're visiting Sri Lanka and looking for great Adventure then do try this with Little Adventure. I have seen people with different age groups join there programs and they reserve there services and other hikes, rides, trekking,Marine Adventure too... Check there Facebook page as its very active. Contact Ashan Seneviratne directly for a great adventures.

We did the hike in low season (July) so we got rubbish weather. It took us 2.5 hours to get up and 2 hours to get down. The hike was awful, it was never ending on the way up and also on the way down. It was the hardest hike I ever did and the view at the top was not worth it because there was no view. We were in the clouds, it was raining and so cold. I wouldn‚Äôt recommend it in this season, I regretted every minute. (And I love to hike)

We went up off season in July. It‚Äôs dark at night, you‚Äôll need a light. Hotels like Slightly Chilled sell them for cheap. The holy place on top will be closed. A nice guy will sell you hot tea. Off season you‚Äôll walk 2,5 hrs if you are somewhat fit (we did it in 2:05 inkl. chats and breaks). Don‚Äôt walk too early, it‚Äôs chilly up there. Recommendations: If it‚Äôs humid and the forecast is for clouds at night, forget about the sunrise and consider walking at daytime with higner chances to enjoy the beautiful landscape. Bring warm clothes - you will feel cold waiting for the sunrise ;-) Off season: prices for Tuk Tuk up from Hatton to Nallathanniya: 1-1500 LKR. Check for strong Tuk Tuks, some almost don‚Äôt make the way up. Off season bus transfer will take you between 2-3 hrs, a Tuk Tuk with good power 1:15 hrs. Off season: prices for Tuk Tuk up from Hatton: 1-1500 LKR. Check for strong Tuk Tuks, some almost don‚Äôt make the way up. Off season bus transfer will take you between 2-3 hrs, a Tuk Tuk with good power 1:15 hrs. Enjoy Adam‚Äôs peak!

Time to move on from Kandy.¬† There is a LOT of windy hill driving ahead of us but first a stop at Kitulgala to do some white-water rafting.  Then there is a LOT more windy road driving and climbing upwards and upwards. This is tea plantation countryside. We arrive at Adams Peak and check-in. It's the Sri Lankan New Year and at this time they take the opportunity to do a pilgrimage to their favourite religious site. Be it Buddhism, Hindu or Christianity - Adams Peak applies. And so it came to be that we now have a true insight into what a pilgrimage is. What an extraordinary thing to do and experience and witness. What a test of mind and body. If you want to experience 1000's upon 1000's of people at once practicing respect and empathy for one another this is it. For us it took 3 1/2 hours to climb up the 5500 steps, starting at 5:30pm. For some people take days to do the ascent. We saw parents carrying their infants in their arms or on their shoulders. No back packs to carry kids in here, no what we would consider appropriate footwear either. Jandals and bare feet are everywhere. We saw toddlers climbing. We saw elderly that defied belief that they could do this climb. We saw people with disabilities, crutches even. We saw people sleeping in the rest stops, showering in the places to bathe, eating in food shops, sitting wherever they felt the need. We chose to spend half an hour at the top.¬† ¬†For others they were sleeping already waiting for the sunrise and others were settling in in the cold.¬† There they were sitting with children asleep in their arms about to wait the next nine hours out until sunrise. Some had the same sense of pride and wonder to them as we felt others were quietly and gently praying. There was nothing of significance to see here, just the knowledge and/or belief that it may exist. That is the first footprint on earth of Buddha, Adam or .....  and then 3 hours for the descent After midnight we swallowed some panadol after we use our hands to lift our legs into bed with the hope that in the morning we will feel fine.¬† ¬†Bahahahahahahahaha.  ¬†We remind our children and ourselves that one day this will make more sense than it does right now. Handy Hint:  Take something warm to put on at the top.

So we reached Nalathanniya - The base town at around 1.30 pm and had a quick lunch...Our assessment told us that it was better to take the chance up the mountain now than at 2-3 am the next day...so we got our rain wear and started the climb enthusiastically at 2.40 pm knowing fully well that it would be dark on the way down. We had 2 x 15yr olds and one 10 yr old with the 2 adults. We managed around 60-70% of the way up...There was not a soul in sight...even the police booths were deserted and the stall all shut. Unfortunately we got hit by a crazy Squall and Thunderstorm which forced us to stop and re assess...The leech weren't helping either.Finally in view of safety and visibility we decided to turn back. But it was a great experience even doing that much. The kids were a little disappointed but safety first....Monsoon probably not the best time to go...Next time we'll attempt it in better weather maybe. The sacred nature of this place makes it attract thousands...and during peak season - it is best avoided. So be very selective about when u wanna do the climb of 5500 steps...the last half a km of which is extremely daunting even for really fit people...or so I've heard.

Really awsome up hill trip. So tks really difficult. 4 hours step by step to the up.  Morte than 5000 steps..... if you want to see the sun rise, you have to start about 1.00 am, because there is a very, verz traffic jam :)  Forget to take some good pictures or selfies, because too many people.... dont forget watter, power bank or some lights because main road can be overcorowed and old way is without lights. Bud its really nice experience, you are discovering your self. And for the end: go back down slowly, because your legs will be crying :))))

I did a 230am hike up the mountain at the end of May.  In spite of  record flooding going on in other parts of the country, I was very lucky & had no rain on the climb.  It poured that evening until apprx midnight  and when I awoke at 200am the skies were cloudy but no rain. It was so nice to hike there this time of year there were 10 other people going on the climb that night and   there were still a couple of tea shops open. While we did not get to see the sun rise because of the clouds we were rewarded with multiple water falls to see on the way down.  I would much rather go during off season then to deal with all the crowds during the pilgrimage season.  I would encourage people to go this time of year instead of letting the weather forecasts scare you off  it is so peaceful to hike there now.

Would be ideal to have a good sleep before climb up and can find good hotels around Nallathanniya. We stayed in Wathsala Inn and had 4 hours sleep then started our journey around 12midnight. As we heard it take 3-4 hrs to go to the top but be took more than 5hrs. Hiking poles helped a lot. We were lucky enough to see the sunrise (Irasewaya) and spent nearly 1 hour in the hilltop (uda maluwa). It was a great experience and must visit at least once.
Good 7 kms of climbing experience. Climbing off season is always better. Don't forget to carry mineral water and some snacks. If you are lucky you can witness the best sunrise in Sri Lanka.

According to my point of view, Adam's Peak is the best hike that we can do in Sri Lanka. We need a good confidence to do this as its really cold on the hilltop. Bring more food as its quie expensive in the boutiques on the hilltop. Once we did it from Nallathanniya and this time we did it strting from Palabaddala, a quite long way. We enjoyed it  a lot. I'm sure I'll do it once a year.

Now is the low season for Adam's Peak. Basically the town is like a ghost town. Most of the shops/stall are closed. Knowing the fact that it is so cloudy, i assumed i will not be able to see the sunrise. So I decided to leave later and I started from the bottom at 4am. Only one stall is open (for food/snack/drinks). On my way up, it was extremely dark, please bring head lamp if you're here during low season. Zero street lamp and its creepy. I didn't see anyone until i hiked about 1hour... At one point it was really tiring, so i slowed down. I spent 1h50m to the peak. Didn't manage to see anything. The temple was  closed. But there's  a local guy (i believe he works for the temple), he offers me hot tea, he says its free but i gave him $ as donation and he accepted. Then i stayed for a while,  but it was extremely  windy and due to the wind it was really cold. Head down and spent 2h30m, took me longer because on the way down, it was brighter so i stopped on and off to take pictures of the beautiful greenery and waterfalls. Would recommend to do it during day time maybe 7am or later. Not during midnight.

I was super nervous about this climb due to all the reviews regarding how hard the climb is. While there is no denying that the climb was challenging, it is not impossible for those who don't deem themselves super fit. I still thoroughly enjoyed this experience! The sunrise was incredible, the best spot to get a good view was about 20 metres back down from the summit along the final section of stairs looking back towards the sun rising. Many other places at the summit were hard to see due to the large crowd however the stairs gave everyone their own uninterrupted views. My favourite part (other than the sunrise) was watching the elderly women make their pilgrimage with their families, and watching the various religious groups chant prayers at each other as they pass on the stairs. I would recommend spending a little extra time at the top as many tourists immediately start their descent after the sun has risen. The prayer hour at the top is quite special with mostly locals only participating. The views on the way down are just as impressive and are better enjoyed without the large number of tourists rushing their way down. Adam's Peak can easily be reached by getting off the train in Hatton and then the local bus to Nallathanniya. If you time your trains well from Ella, Kandy, Nanu Oya or Colombo, Adam's Peak should only take 1 night/morning out of your Sri Lanka itinerary as there is not much else to see or do in the area. I would recommend arriving in Nallathanniya late afternoon or evening, and then leaving as soon as you descend Adam's Peak.

Did the hike 18/5/18 in complete darkness. Only very limited places open and no lights except from at the police stops. There's a small tea shop at the top, costs 100rupees. When we did this there were about 70 other tourists doing it. No locals as they only go in pilgrimage season. It can be a bit daunting to climb it in darkness, but as long as you have a torch it's fine and this means you can see the stars. We had no rain at all, not even the evening before, so were lucky. So from my experience, no need to worry about climbing it now. Less people, more scenic. Don't think you need to worry about rumours such as robbers, wild dogs etc etc.
What an adventure! Climbing all those stairs in the middle of the night was amazing. It is quite an effort, but definitely worth it. Even if we did the climb off-season it was a fantastic experience.

Started at 2am Hiked in the dark took a torch with us Its a challenging hike but take your time a 2am start will get you there before sunset. Was my first hike ever. I didnt know what to expect there were some challenging moments. Nailed it in 2hours 50 and i stopped many times along the route as well as a coffee break to give me more energy! Sunset was BREATHTAKING and when you get to the top you really earn the right to take those photos! The climb down was amazing as it was pitch black walking we didn't see anything but coming down just WOW! Lots of picture opportunities along with a well deserved foot massage.

Absolutely amazing view, I would definitely recommend going for the sunset.  Due to the proximity to the Sri Lankan New Year the stairs to the top were very very crowded.
