We started climbing around 2:30am and hit a packed solid line around 5am, we waited in the line until about 7:30 before turning around. We later found out there was a trail beside the police building that would have led to an entrance to the top from the other side of the mountain.  You can see this trail on Maps.me.  So, if you are going in April plan to leave very early or use this side trail to reach the top. A few comments: It was mainly Sri Lankan people making the trek to the top of Adam's Peak ranging from babies to elderly. The lowest temperature was 12C so unless you are waiting at the top for a while or you come from a very warm climate a light sweater and a hat is sufficient. There were lots of places to buy snacks along the way and lots of toilets although the toilets were not in great condition. There is a free leg massage at the base of Adam's Peak sponsor by a balm manufacturer. There isn't much else at the base of Adam's Peak, I would recommend only staying in the city for one night.

In 2010 Sri Lanka was awarded its 8th UNESCO Heritage Site ‚Äì The Central Highlands, actually a group of highlands including the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary, Horton Plains and Knuckles Conservation Forest. It includes Sri Lanka‚Äôs 2nd highest mountain, Sri Pada or Adam‚Äôs Peak at 2243m above sea level. The mountain is considered sacred to different religions and has many different names, but it is usually known as Sri Pada (= Sacred Footprint) or Adam‚Äôs Peak. It‚Äôs isolated conical shape is very distinctive and visible for miles. On a clear day, it is said that, from the summit, you can see Colombo, 65km away. Sri Pada is associated with Buddha, but long before Buddhism arrived in Sri Lanka in 246 BCE, the mountain was already being revered as the home of the god Saman. Then it was called Samanelakhanda (= Saman‚Äôs mountain). The Sacred Footprint, a large indentation in the rock at the summit, is said to be made by Buddha himself on one of his 3 journeys here, although Muslims consider the footprint to be that of Adam, when he was first cast out of Paradise. Christians claim that it was made by St Thomas, the early apostle of India, and Hindus consider that it was made by Lord Shiva. Although the appearance of the rock indentation is like that of a print of a left foot, it was not made by any of these worthies. At more than 1m long, it was more probably made by Bigfoot. Nevertheless the mountain and the ‚Äòfootprint‚Äô are revered by several religions and pilgrims mingle with determined foreigners to climb Sri Pada. There are many different routes to the top, but probably the most popular starts at Dalhousie, 33km from Hatton and, after 5,500 uneven steps, between 2¬Ω and four hours, and 7km later you should arrive at the summit. The peak pilgrimage time is between Poya Day in December and the Vesak Festival in April/May but the busiest time is January to February. During the peak period the route up is lit and there are many tea houses along the way. Most visitors come to see the ‚Äòfootprint‚Äô in its little temple, ring the bell and await the dawn. If you leave Dalhousie at about 2.30am you should, pedestrian traffic permitting, reach the top at dawn. But be advised that after a strenuous climb, it will seem very cold on the 165m2 summit and very crowded in the peak season, but if you avoid weekends and Poya Days, you can also avoid the biggest crowds. The return journey, down those steps, though is a killer, particularly if you are not fully fit. For the climb you will need some warm clothing, maybe a plastic raincoat, water, energy snacks, good stout shoes, a lemon to deal with the leaches and a determination to succeed. There is an off-peak season when few people climb, but there is a good reason for that. It is usually wet, cloudy, cold and slippery.

Very simple: avoid during the pilgrimage season from December to May that is unless you are a pilgrim yourself. The place is hugely crowded with children screaming etc..., not the kind of climb we fancy. We left our guesthouse at 2am in order to reach the summit for sunrise. After nearly 3 hours of climbing. The crowd suddenly stopped. We thought there had been an incident. Then we started to see people coming back, all foreigners like us. Why? It would take us anither 4 hours to do the remaining 500 meters. We were not ready for that and like every other foreigner we walked down and still saw the sunrise on our way down. We were forewarned but thought people exxagerated! Well unless you want to climb fir religious reason, avoid from December to May.

I loved every minute of this experience, from getting soaked in a down pour during the afternoon before, feeling the excitement of anticipation with all the street vendors / stalls, getting up in the middle of the night and joining the peaceful and contemplative trickle of pilgrims which gradually turned into a buzzing throng, the closer to the top and narrower the path until we were squeezed into a mass of people on the top - think music festival! We headed straight back down again, slowly so that we could watch the sun rise during our decent. One bit of advice is not to get too hung up about getting to the very top if it‚Äôs really busy, we were lucky as it was an unusually quiet sat morning in the season. If it had been really busy it would have been worth it anyway but I‚Äôd probably have turned around once I got to the narrow bit rather than have stood in a queue for 2 hours which is apparently quite common.

The view going up was really nice but at the peak itself, it's really disappointed. A lot of garbage everywhere and it's really crowded. It's sad because it's a sacred temple but some tourists there go for taking pictures without respecting the place.

Climbing Adam‚Äôs Peak is another Sri Lanka‚Äôs highlight.  We started at 2.30am and got to the top in two hours; I‚Äôd be surprised if it takes Average Joe more than 3 hours to climb.  Plenty of tea houses and fast food stalls on the way; possible to buy water too.   The climb is not particularly hard, (uneven) steps all way up; steep in some sections and there are several bottle necks with people ascending up too slowly for anyone‚Äôs liking.  The religious complex and the footprint are interesting enough, but the sunrise is the main reason for making the effort.  We arrived there more than 2 hours before the sunrise and, unsurprisingly, got immediately cold as soon as we stopped climbing.  Luckily, we took a change of clothes with us as well as two extra layers and windproof/waterproof jackets.  We managed even to have a little nap with crowds whilst waiting for sunrise.  The sunrise itself was spectacular with beautiful, beautiful views of mountains, mist and clouds below.  Beautiful views on the way down.

Climbed up at night during the weekend, so was extremely busy. Unfortunately on the way up a pick pocket took my phone, I was so gutted, first night on sri lanka! Just be careful, be aware, there are big crowds squashed together at some parts. Also, can be very very cold at night, my friend could not last till sunrise, so take extra clothes/blanket etc.

Hiking Adam‚Äôs peak in the middle of the night for sunrise seems a quintessential Sri Lankan travel experience, and we enjoyed it but know that it is more a pilgrimage than a nature hike (as you are surrounded by crowds, many people struggling, trash, etc.), and you may be stuck in long lines during the hike. That being said it was an interesting experience, tough hike and we were happy we did it, but there are a lot of drawbacks. Nallathanniya is out of the way and make take a couple of days out of your itinerary, the places to stay at the base of the mountain are very expensive and poor quality compared to elsewhere in the country, the hike is always crowded and may impede you from reaching the top and the hike itself is concrete stairs without any real outdoorsy climbing.

We climbed on 18th of April and we started at 1:30am, we were 100m below the summit at 3:30 and then qued till 7:30 when we turned around still 15m short. There were so many pilgrims and because of the high angles, vegetation and people you will get better views at Ella rock or little Adam with a lot less pain. We are not as fit as we used to be and it took us four days to recover fully from the hike. Seriously suggest leaving this to the locals who feel it's their utmost religous duty to climb this mountain and this was evident by elderly women climbing in utter pain and locals shocked at us turning around near the top in disbelief. I think western tourists should give them some extra room rather than clogging up the top waiting for a photo of the sunrise or selfie.

I was so excited for this after doing little Adams peak, it was not as I expected at all. I would only recommend doing it if you're religious. It's just one big commercialised walk with shops selling over priced food and tacky toys all the way up. Bright lighting so you don't feel like you're surrounded by nature and can't see the stars (which is the thing I love most about sunrise treks) it's very dirty, full of litter and the smell coming from the 'toilets' is unbearable. There are so many people trying to walk to the top, that around 300m from the top (I am guessing) we came to a complete stand still, we didn't move for around 20 mins and that's when I decided to decenf back down and just watch the sunrise as I was walked, many others joined along the way. It's a very long way to walk only to be disappointed. I am usually one to read bad reviews and still love the place I'm visiting, but on this rare occasion I agree with the bad reviews. Especially as there is nothing else to do in nallathanniya (where the mountain is based) other than Adams peak so I feel we wasted 2 of our days in Sri Lanka which is sad because it has been my favourite country of the trip. Little Adams peak is so much better in Ella so I would recommend going there instead.

Adam's Peak is a religious pilgrimage site located near Hatton.  It is a holy site for Hindus, Buddhists and Christians.  You will climb 5,000+ steps.  It is a strenuous climb in the heat and humidity.  The people climbing to the top are a testament to the religious convictions of the Sri Lankan people.  The site is very commercialized with hundreds of shops along the way..  Washrooms will cost you 20-40 Sri Lankan rupees.  Bring or buy lots of water

Adam‚Äôs peak is a spiritual place frequented by religious people. If you are, like I was, under the impression that this a hike not be missed: you are mistaken. You will walk up concrete stairs for about 2-3 hours depending on fitness. It is super crowded and you will need to wait many times, shoulder to shoulder with hundreds of other worshippers. There is nothing wrong with this of course, however it is quite far from a hike in the nature. If you are looking for that, Ella Rock or Little Adams peak are much better. Also, the area around Adams peak is super nice with gorgeous lakes and tea plantations. In summary: go for the religious/spiritual spectacle, skip this if you are looking to hike

We decided to do this climb since it was deemed as one of those once in a lifetime things if you are in Sri Lanka.  While I don‚Äôt regret we did it, I‚Äôm not sure if it was totally worth it.  We started our climb a little before 2 am in the early Monday hours so we could make the sunset.  When you start the walk there is an entrance where monks will try to get you to sign your name and give a donation.  Just remember you don‚Äôt have to and can walk past them, this climb is free. We aren‚Äôt super fit people but do exercise regularly and go on hikes.  This was without a doubt the most physically taxing thing I have ever done.  I think the main issue for us was that the steps upward were so super wide that one step felt like five.  We took constant breaks but still felt drained as the steps kept going endlessly.  Also, it was very sad to see the endless trash just littered along the entire way we were walking. Around 5:00 am the walk became super steep and very narrow and we basically got stuck because there were so many people.  We thought we would miss the sunrise but managed to get into the gates at the top around 6:00 am to wait for the 6:16 sunrise.  It was so incredibly packed and uncomfortable that it was hard to enjoy this beautiful moment and accomplishment.  Plus the sunrise was a bit of a letdown since it was cloudy.  Going down was much easier and we even did a massage at the bottom.  Unfortunately our muscles were so sore that we couldn‚Äôt walk for about 3 days after. So yes, this is an incredibly spiritual climb especially when you see all the people climbing beside you and their devotion to this.  But it is also extremely difficult and packed and you might not see anything up Adam‚Äôs Peak if the weather doesn‚Äôt cooperate.  So just consider those things before you embark on this journey.

Surprisingly easy to navigate, this climb is somewhat gruelling; however certainly achievable. The views at the top make any pain worth it! We commenced our trip up at 2am and reached the peak at 4:30 am after a steady ascent. This gave us ample to time to explore the peak as we awaited the sunrise. I would advise finding a position lower down on the steps for a better view of the sunrise as crowds tend to amass on the peak and consequently obscure any good spots. After the sunrise we swiftly started our descent. This served us well in avoiding the surge of people coming down and we were able to reach the bottom in good time.

At the beginning, I expected it would be long hours to climb up the stairs for non fitness person like me. Apparently, it took me just a bit less than 3 hours including human traffic jam when almost reaching the top. The thing that I could learn from this hike is about focusing on my steps and breaths instead of keep complaining about being tired. The views on the top are AMAZING! A bit sad that the construction block the views. You can‚Äôt see any views on the way up (since it‚Äôs dark) but the views on the way down could easily make your day and worth for visiting!

You do require good footwear and a level of fitness, especially because it is pretty steep on the way down. I had brought my trekking pole and was very thankful. You are encouraged seeing the elderly locals or young couples carrying young infants up the over 5000 steps and back down again! At the top is a temple for the pilgrimage. It is not built or meant for 100s of tourists to enjoy a sunrise. We felt disrespectful trying to catch a glimpse of the views while locals are there praying and trying to use the temple for its purpose. As it was so crowded (and we did not go on a weekend or full moon, about 300 tourists) we couldn't even see the sunrise. We tried to start the trek back down early but we're stuck behind a large crowd bottlenecked down a single file stairway. We felt that the effort was not worth the payoff. We would suggest if you really want to climb it then start the descent before the sunrise and watch it from a little further down. Still have gorgeous views but avoid large crowds.

It's just not worthy to climb adams peak.it s only non sense to climb climb and endless climb of 4 to 5 hours to find nothing.Dont try rather enjoy other beautiful places in shrilanka.its sincere opinion of our entire group.

Well, after all the Internet fuss about it, honestly I expected to be more difficult. We booked a hotel near to the bottom to automatically start the climbing early in the morning. We did it at around 3 AM and in about 2,5 hours we were already at the top. We could have made it in two hours time but we took our time thinking the road to the top will be longer and much more difficult. Th√© truth is, if you are not used to any kind of effort, this task will be a tedious one. If you have stomach issues in the morning, do not attempt to do it, the toilets that you will find on the way are bellow any standard. People keep talking about leeches and stuffing their socks in their long pants....what a joke...just put a pair of good trekking shoes, a short and a t-shirt, I guarantee, you will sweat a lot. Maybe you can pack a long sleeve or a spare T-shirt , because waiting for the sun to come up on the top, can be a little chilly. To conclude, Adam‚Äôs Peak is worth doing it,  was my favorite hiking activity in Sri Lanka.

This is a must-do when travelling to Sri Lanka! But it can be very crowded in weekends and especially on full moon Poya days and Tamil New Year. For those who are interested in the number of steps, i counted them and my count was 4558 steps counted from the gate near the lying buddha to the bell at the top. But it is not very accurate because there are some splits in the path (near the stupa). The temple at the top isn't big and the only interesting things are the Adam's footstep (photographs not allowed) and the bell who you can ring when you complete the climb. My tips to get to the top without trouble: - It can be advisable to do a smaller climb a week prior to the Adam's Peak (like Sigiriya Rock or Mihintale) - Go during the pilgrim season (december to may) because the path is illuminated at night (it's also nice for photos!) - Avoid full moon Poya and weekends if possible, please also avoid the week before and the week after Tamil new year (mid April)! Otherwise you will struck intonthe crowds and you won't reach the top. - Pack enough food to replenish your energy during the climb and do not forget to bring a bottle of water to avoid dehydration. There are numerous shops along the paths to get food / drinks, so you can also purchase extra when running out of supplies. - Wear good walking shoes or booths to avoid blisters and foot injuries. - Walking poles can be a good use during the descent to reduce pain in your knees. There are also handrails in the upper part of the path.

My friend and I decided to do the touristy thing and went on the hike up Adams Peak this morning. We spend a night (or parts of it) in a hostel and got driven there by Tuk Tuk free of charge, which was nice. At the bottom of the mountain it already was quiet crowded and as we ascended it got even worse. Of course it was the weekend so we expected it to be more busy. The hike is totally exaggerated by pretty much every review I found online - it‚Äôs just not that exhausting and bad as people make it sound. Seriously people, do you ever move? My favorite quotes were all the ‚ÄúI‚Äôve never done something that exhausting in my life‚Äù - sad... On the top it‚Äôs just freaking ugly and because of all the buildings you can‚Äôt see anything of the surrounding nature that‚Äôs actually really pretty... We managed to get really great places to watch the sunrise (which unfortunately wasn‚Äôt that special today, not the peaks fault though). All in all it was terribly underwhelming and we‚Äôre glad we mostly stay away from this kind of touristy crap. This country has sooooo much more special places to offer! So just maybe do this when you‚Äôve already exhausted all your other options on your travels through Sri Lanka ;)
A religious location also a well known tourist attraction place Most of the foreigners prefer visiting the place because of the calm weather with wind & light showers

It is hard, but it is absolutely worth it! The ascend takes 2-3 hours depending on your fitness level. If you want to see the sunrise, you have to bring a change of clothes (you will sweat through yours) maybe a blanket, because it¬¥s gonna be real cold and windy up there. Also you have to take off your shoes, because it¬¥s a temple, so bring warm socks. Depending on when you start the ascend and how long you take you have to wait for some time up there in the cold and wind. And it¬¥s gonna be full of people so you have to be kinda early to get a good spot and therefore be prepared for a longer wait. We decided on some point to leave the temple and go a bit down to the next tea hut, where we enjoyed the great sunrise as well, but relatively sheltered from the wind.

We climbed Adam's Peak on a Tuesday morning. There were not a lot of people. I read that it is best to avoid weekends or fullmoon. When we reached the top after almost 2 hours is was quite crowded on the peak as everyone was waiting for the sunrise. We waited for around 5 minutes and decided it was to cold to wait there. So, we went down to the second last tear where they sell hot tea and coffee. We watched the sunrise from there which was beautiful. We like hiking and this is definately a good option to include some sports into your travelling agenda. (We didn't climb for the religious aspect.)

This is a tough gig! You need to do it because you want to and you can...certainly not because you expect to see a footprint. You would be very disappointed. Some advice from a seasoned trekker: wear lightweight trekking boots, take a walking pole, carry some water, some money and a jacket, buy a bottle of Coke or Pepsi about two thirds of the way up! The uphill is tiring, the downhill is brutal, but you will feel very proud of your achievement. (PS I am a 69 year old woman)!

We started at 2:30 am to walk up the stairs to arrive at the top of Adam's peak and I had read many advises about the preparation and first I had to say When u go up it will be hot so don't put to much close on you to go up Along the stairs u have all the way shops to buy drinks or snacks which is very nice üòâ U don't need to be an athlete to do the Adams peak we saw a women of 93 years going up to the peak! No need to hurry if u start at 2 am cause it took us 2h30 to go up and we took many breaks up there then it's colder its good to have a blanket or jumper to cover im yourself from the colder temperature If u arrive early on the top u would more chances to get a place to seat around the temple otherwise on the stairs u have aswell plenty of space to watch the amazing sunrise What a magical view after the walk!! Best sunrise I ever saw in my life Going down was easier and took us 2hours Advise when u go down go to the massage shop and get as much as possible legs massage We didn't get any massage and our legs were painful for 1 week! Stretch alot after the long walk aswell!! It's better to go to see the peak during week days avoid weekends cause it's very crowded by locals and It can take u up to 12 hours walk with big queues Adams peak a magical and beautiful experience I totaly recommend to anyone visiting Sri-Lanka!

It is definitely worth stopping off in the area to get up early and climb to the top. We stayed in Maskeliya and started at the hike at 2.45am (30 min tuk-tuk ride from Masleliya) and reached the top by 5am going at a leisurely pace. The sunrise was fantastic (just after 6am) and the hike back down offered some awesome views. Take warm clothes for the top as it is chilly. We were very surprised by the number of people at top and some people who arrived after us struggled to get a vantage point. Glad we stopped off to do this.

The total time of the climb really depends on your fitness level, the location of your hotel and amount of people having the same idea as you but in average it will get about 2.5 - 3 h to get to the top. We started our climb at 3:30 am from Nallathaniya and would recommend everyone to do the same if you wanna see the sunrise as it is around 6:15 am. We were lucky that on our day of visiting there were a very few people and the weather was good. We saw too many people climbing down even before the sunrise because they had started too early and couldn't stand the cold anymore. It can get very windy up there and you can get chilled easily especially when you remove your shoes to be able to enter the temple area. So calculate your timing wisely. The climb itself might get very steep sometimes and you will feel your calfs even several days after the climb but it is manageable and it is 1000% worth it. The views are spectacular. Forget about sunrise and go to the opposite side of the mountain to see the perfect triangle shape. You won't see in anywhere else in the world.

It was a great hike up! We enjoyed meeting random locals who cheered us on. We started at 1am and during the week. It was PACKED when we got up there. Hold your belongings in front as this we were advised by a police officer when we got to the peak. Bring extra socks as it smelt like urine and you can't wear shoes. Make sure your bag is big enough for your shoes (plastic bags for your shoes). Once you get to the top, stay on the same side as the bell or you won't see the sunrise. And don't move. It was extremely crowded. Wear warm clothing...we brought a blanket. Worth seeing the beautiful sunrise :)
This is magic mountain beeing an important  palce for buddists, muslims and christians. It offers amazing view of sunrise

i got to the base of adam's peak 5 hours late because of the heavy traffic coming in on a friday. the only way i can explain the amount of buses and vans, is to compare it to the largest music festival you've ever gone to and imagine that type of traffic getting to a trail head. the parked buses lined miles and miles of the narrow road. i was told this was because of it being a friday and many people doing this pilgrimage can only take a long weekend to complete the trip. as an avid hiker, i was really concerned about the amount of people on this trail. i was told by a local that on the weekend when it gets crowded, it can take 45 minutes to move one step. there are 5000+ steps to the summit. i stayed at a cheap motel at the base of the mountain. i didn't care about seeing the sunrise, i just wanted to experience the hike. so i got to the trailhead at 4:30 am. there were more people coming off the mountain than going up so i figured i missed the crowds who went up early and i'd summit in 2 hours. boy was i wrong. there were thousands and thousands of people going up and coming down. you can't keep a regular hiking pace because you're weaving around families literally carrying their children and helping their elderly up or down. many have to sit or lay down wherever they may be and that's not necessarily on the side of the "trail." i was by myself so could maneuver around quickly and easily without bothering anyone. going with more people would have been tricky as it was SO CROWDED it'd be hard to stick together. there were times i got stuck on a stairway and couldn't go around anyone as the masses we packed too close together. it wasn't too steep, it wasn't a physical challenge at all if you're in decent shape. most of the people on the trail did it in flip flops or bare feet. i was almost at the summit (maybe 800 feet to go) and i came upon a bottle neck like i've never seen before. no one was getting around that going up or down. there was a pack of people that literally choked the trail. and they were moving at a snail's pace. actually they weren't moving at all during the 15 minutes i stood there trying to decide what to do. i turned around and headed back. i got to my hotel at 7:30 am and my guide was very relieved to see me. apparently there were people who had left the hotel at 7:30 PM the night before and still weren't back (12 hours). i told him if i had wound up on the back side of that bottleneck i'd be stuck at the top too. for me, it was a great experience as it's something i couldn't have imagined and i was moved by the pilgrimage and what an effort it took for these people. it was also a great experience because i was lucky enough to have been able to move on that mountain without being on the wrong side of any jam of people. i would not recommend this hike on a weekend. no way.

We decided to go there for sunset and after going down we found out we did very well ... we were almost alone for sunset and really enjoyed the stay up. No locals on the way up just some. That day we were also only one tourist on the way so that was also good :). We made it for 2,5 hrs up and down 1,45 hrs without not that much rushing. What I‚Äôm going to say is that when we went down around 7 pm there were sooo many groups locals and tourist claiming up. When you imagine how crowded it must be up where is no that much space and also the others coming from the different way of the road it must be horrible! I understand that sunrise is maybe really better to see but in the end of the day, I would really not enjoy it so I‚Äôm happy we went there 2pm came around 9pm and had also a good sleep...

Concrete steps to the top. Dirty and strewn with rubbish. This is spiritual pilgrimage, not a travellers trek. There are locals of all ages, some really struggling with the steps and I can‚Äôt see how rude tourists barging past them in an effort to get to the top as quickly as possible adds to their experience. The view from the top is good but it‚Äôs very crowded.

We were very lucky to get a quiet enough day, without rain or cloud during the sunrise. I did this walk on a Friday with my partner and mum (who is a healthy 60 years young). Following previous reviews we decided to leave our accomodation at 3am, starting the climb at 3:30 and arriving at the top in 2.5 hours for the start of sunrise. This meant we were not waiting in the cold for sunrise. We packed plenty of layers of warm clothes and were able to experience the prayer call at the top. The walk was challenging at parts but we had plenty of breaks, the steps were well maintained and it was only last little bit at the top that was really busy. Almost at stand-still up the steps by the temple but we perceived and got through to the other side which had a lot more space, great views, the large bell, flame, and also toilets (these were free, not 30 or 50rs like the others). There are plenty of stalls selling food and drink along the way, both hot and cold. And we noticed a number of drinking water filters inside the shops, so take a bottle and refill from there to save on the plastic waste (you will notice on the way down - in the daylight - just how much rubbish is left along the path and also the incredible people who carry huge crates of drinks up on their backs to be sold). All in all a great experience. Probably not to be attempted on a weekend or Poya Day.

The start was good and we met a lot of locals, there were nearly no tourists at Adam‚Äôs Peak. A few hours later we knew why: it was Sunday and holidays in Sri Lanka, so all locals came here to go to the top! In the last 1.000 steps (of 5.200) we had to wait so much time. Sometimes we waited 30 minutes to climb up 1 (!) step. We were really done after this experience. Would do it again, but definitely not on weekend! If you want to buy drinks, something to eat or stuffed animals - you get everything on the way to the top.

We went up to Adam's peak start at 2 am in the rain. While we admired the spirit of the pilgrims we re saddened by the lack of respect to the mother earth. When we see the condition of the tract it was simply a rubbish tip. People littered with out any self conscious that this is a sacred place where they come and pray. We left the place with a disappointment as we see this place with a true potential but being wrecked by the mass!!

This is a must for any tourist in the area. It's a very early start (0200-0230) to make it to the top before sunrise however the path is lit and there are so many people you can't get lost or lose motivation. It's very steep and uneven so take time, and make sure you have warm clothing or a blanket to throw around you at the top as it gets very cold. It will take about 2-3 hours to get up all the way so you may be standing/sitting around for a while waiting for the sun to come up. After the sweat of the climb it's bitterly cold! It is busy at the top but you can find a reasonable spot to take photos. Lots of stalls dotted along the way selling food and hot and cold drinks, however I'd suggest at the bare minimum take some water with you. Comfortable light clothes and proper walking shoes/trainers are essential! You will want the rest of the day to relax and do nothing, so don't plan on moving to another destination the same day.

Well worth the early start, though don't start too early. There are plenty of shops/cafes open along the ascent offering tea/coffee and snacks. At the bottom there seems to be a first aid station there as well. Along the route there are also squat toilets available. Most of the path is well lit, though there are a couple of sections (for a few metres) not lit, so I would advise you to ensure you have a flashlight on your mobile phone (no need for a head torch). I am quite a fit male adult so the ascent took me 2hrs and I did not even break a sweat. I had hoped it would be a bit more strenuous. You share the steps with a lot of locals making the pilgrimage as of course this is a holy ascent for many different religions. Once at the top ring the bell, take a seat on the large steps facing East and wrap up. Make sure to take gloves, hat and even maybe a blanket (many people up there had one). It is very chilly and windy at the top. I would advise getting to the top maybe 1-2hrs before, maybe 2hrs before. This might seem excessive but in doing so you can get a good seat on the large steps facing east. If you arrive just in time for sunset you will not get far as it becomes very packed at the top and everyone is jostling for space to see the sunrise. There are toilets at the top. It is well worth the early start and I highly recommend.

We started to climb up around 11.30 and reached the top around 4am. Alot of people gather to see the sunrise. There is not enough space for alot of people to gather to watch the sunrise. It gets very congested. It's very cold and windy up in the mountains and it's hard to stay out for a long time. If you are going up to stay till the sunrise please take a blanket or something to cover yourself against the cold winds. Adams peak is very dirty,with the locals throwing trash everywhere. Although there are toilets till we reach the top,it doesn't have a proper disposal system so there are bad smells coming from everywhere. The steps are steep and small. This is a pilgrim site,but the presence of so many small shops and vendors gives it a very commercialized outlook which makes us wonder if this is a pilgrim site or a sweets bazaar. The mountain it self is nice. The view is also good. There is an old sinhala saying which roughly translates to," a man who doesn't climb Adams peak once in his life is a fool and also the man who climbs it more than once is also a fool ". I became a fool by climbing it twice.

It's an incredibly humbling journey, watching generations of people tackling this beast of a mountain. Top Tip, set off as early as you can to get a good seat for the sunrise at the top. The vast majority of people making this journey are doing it because of the spiritual impact, however for the tourists they're mainly after the nice views / sunrise at the top. Just remember to respectful on your journey, we saw lots of pushing towards the top and it's embarrassing. Just remember where you are. There's loads of places for food and water along the way so don't bother stacking your bags with supplies, Also take something warm for the top, it gets cold at 4:30am! Took as 2.5 hours at a moderate pace with a few stops for food and water. Well worth the early start.

We climbed Adams peak on a Tuesday night and even then it was still busy when you got to the top. Be aware that the steps are quite steep in some places and it takes a minimum of 2h to get to the top. With a few little breaks it took us 2h15m to reach the top. We are quite fit but even we struggled and our legs ached for the next 2 days!! Sunrise was just before 6am in March and we started our decent as soon as the sun started to appear to get out of the very crowded area - would recommend doing it this way as you see the views just as well if not better than at the top as there aren‚Äôt any people blocking your views! Worth doing but be aware it‚Äôs not easy. Path is lit during the busy season (December-April I think) and lots of shops en route up for snacks and water etc. So you don‚Äôt need to take lots with you. It is cold at the top but only if you are camping out for a long time so bring warm clothes otherwise it‚Äôs not too cold on the way up.

The feeling of smashing all those steps is incredible! We left our hostel in Dalhousie at 2.30am and 'peaked' by 4.50, then had about an hour wait until the sun began to rise! It was very cold at the top and we were definitely glad we had jumpers and coats! It was very busy, but I think as long as this is expected then it's fine! At this time of year crowds are part of it, it is a pilgrimage after all! Though I would definitely avoid weekends and holidays (near full moons) though! We went on a random weekday. It was humbling seeing some barefoot Sri Lankan's slowly making their way up and down despite what appeared to be ill health. To be honest we couldn't see much from the very top (due to crowds), we started the descent as the sun was rising - at the top of the stairs is where we saw some of the most incredible views!

The accomplishment feeling of climbing 5640 stairs is amazing, and the panoramic view from the top is a great reward. The sunrise above the mountain is speechless. There is a big queue of almost half an hour for the last 100 meter and the place is fully packed with people waiting hours to see the sunrise. The peak is a bit cold, and while descent, the sun can burn. There are many places along the climbing to stop, rest and  drink some local tea (40 Rupees).

More than 5,500 steps of climbing bliss. The interactions we had with the families & children particularly, made the experience unforgettable. Athleticism level is not an issue. We encountered several elderly individuals climbing up and even a pregnant woman. Steps are in good condition & it took us 2.5 hours to reach the summit. We ascended in the afternoon which was good because we avoided the log jam which apparently happens if you do the sunrise hike.

A good walk, but don't get up at 2am for it. We left at 2.30am, arrived at the top at 4.30am and there was still a queue to get in - it was freezing cold so we went back down and caught the sunrise from lower down.

Adam‚Äòs Peak/Sri Pada/Samanalakande or Butterfly Mountain is amazing experience, both spiritual and physical! It is more than climbing and taking the photos of the sunrise. Adam‚Äôs Peak is the place of coexistence of different religions and peoples. The 5500 steps give you time to reflect on yourself, to test your physical strength and willpower, to enjoy the beauty and power of the nature, to meet and talk to Buddhists, Christians, Muslims, Hindus or just tourists as  you, and to became part of thousand years of pilgrimage. We went to the Adam‚Äòs Peak from Dalhousie, at the beginning of February, on the middle of the week, far from full moon, during the terrifying monsoon rain which didn‚Äôt discourage us to climb. We needed practically 4 hours to the top.  We started early, at 1:30 AM and monsoon stopped letting us to advance slowly but firmly, decided to make it co√ªte que co√ªte . To prepare you, just look at others reviews, best and worst, it will help you to take what you really need and to climb the Adam‚Äôs Peak in best possible way.  Don't carry too much food and drink as you can find it along the way. Don‚Äôt forget the gloves and warm cap, some cloths to change at the top.  You can buy a very good (and warm) raincoat for 500 Rs at the local market in Dalhousie. I would recommend you to take the walking sticks. Mine were more than useful. It is not easy to climb up 5500 steps and quite difficult to climb them down, it is cold and wet but when you reach the top, you will know that it is unique and beautiful. The kindness of the local people, pilgrims of all ages including children, and calm of the food sellers, is a good therapy for the hurried and upset tourists. Think that you are climbing the holly mountain. Stop time to time, take a cap of tea or just a bottle of water, excellent Hawaian Cookies, and rest at small stands along the way.  Take your time, don‚Äôt push your physical forces, stop if necessary, and enjoy the nature around you including the night frog‚Äôs song if you climb at night. Once on the top, pay tribute to the sacred footprint of Buddha/Adam. You will have to take your shoes off but you can do it just next to the Temple and keep them with you. Don‚Äôt be afraid to step on the cold and wet stone, it worth the effort. It is not obligatory to leave the money, but it is always good to give something to the Gods, so pay what you want, even 100 Rs would be good. Don‚Äôt forget to ring a bell as many times as you reached the Peak ÔÅä! You can find on your right, going up, just before reaching the Temple, the shelter where the local people coming from around Sri Lanka use to take a rest. It is crowded but they will let you some place, if not you can stay on the covered and warm entry. Be on time to take a good position for the sunrise. The first ray enlightening the Adam‚Äôs Peak is as the first ray that God sent to the Earth. Beautiful. We didn‚Äôt have chance to see the shadow of Adam‚Äôs Peak but we don‚Äôt regret it. Even if we would miss the sunrise, climbing this holly mountain would be enough to keep this moment as one of the best of our life.

I was really looking forward to Sri Pada. The reality was crushingly disappointing. I began from the guesthouse, the walk to the start of the steps was a little bit like walking along a pier in Blackpool UK. Random stalls selling cheap tat, anything from a pink teddy bear to a remote control helicopter! It was bizarre. Then the climb began it was rammed, I expected a few tourists but they were there in mass groups all chattering and yelling between themselves...I wondered if they actually knew what Sri Pada was, especially as these tourists barged their way through in shorts and sports tops. It was humbling to watch some of the really old local people climbing up there, clearly struggling but determined - a true pilgrimage. I my minds eye, the little tea shops on the way up were quaint little places ran by a local family, how naive! They like the stalls at the bottom, only most had Asian dance music blaring out from them. To the top. So this is a place of great religious significance for Buddhists, Hindus, Muslims and Christians, at the top you are asked to removed your shoes and head ware and do not photograph and record in and around the temple - in other words show some respect! Massive groups of Germans, Chinese and mixtures of other tourist hoards were all gathered up there for the sunrise - many had put their shoes back on, head ware back on, all yelling and screaming at each other taking selfies - it was embarrassing, after 15 minutes at the top I came back down is disgust. Personally if I was a local religious person I would not want the tourists allowed up there, but if you take the loud gobshite tourist away then the local businesses would suffer - its a tough one. However one things for sure, I would make sure everybody up there showed the respect it deserves, or I would have them thrown out.

Adam‚Äôs Peak was something I was really looking forward to doing - the hike for sunrise at the temple it with hundreds of others, the triangular shadow, the challenge. However the realities of this walk are that it is over crowded and commercialisation is rampant. We set off at 245 on a tuesday morning and reached the top at 515 having had plenty of breaks after realising we would be waiting at the top in the cold for far too long if we didn‚Äôt. At the top was pretty chaotic, one of the temples set on fire on the lower level and on the upper level everyone had their cameras out fighting for a picture of the sunrise even though it was 545 and sunrise was a further 30 minutes away. When the sun does come up the views are fantastic and the way down is so much better than the way up as you are focusing on the trees, lake, mountains rather than the concrete steps, bright lights and copious amounts of litter that people have decided to discard everywhere. There are plenty of hikes around where you can get as spectacular views which may be less ‚Äúspiritually significant‚Äù but also come without the crowds and litter.

Slow and steady wins the race..........and that's just it. Adam's Peak has got to be the most challenging thing we have done to date. At times we were ready to give up and head back to the hotel; but we persisted. As with previous reviews we met people of all ages going and coming back down again. In fact, it was the 'older' pilgrims that made us realise that if they could do it so could we. It was also encouraging to see that some of the younger (more athletic) walkers/climbers were also finding the climb tiring. We saw them race off at a pace that would get them to the top in record time, but found them struggling to cope with major 'muscle burn' at some of the rest stops on the way. The climb is made more challenging by the fact that the steps are not even. They vary in height so take care on the way up but also on the way down, because just as you get into a rhythm you come across a step which is almost twice the height which will jar you knees. We set off at 2 am and made it to the top at around 6 am. We also had a local guide with us who was useful at the top, but not so useful on the way up as we always seemed to be on 2 km from the top. As others have mentioned it gets crowded at the top, and this was where our guide helped us. He found a way through them to find a great place to view the sunrise. It was truly spectacular and the view from the top was all I had hoped for. we were even able to see the shadow of the mountain on the mist. At 7am the shrine enclosing the foot print was opened and we were allowed to enter. Remember, this is a place of worship and locals are there to make offerings and to pray, so please be respectful. Do not miss the chance to experience the climb, even if you cannot make it to the very top, you will be rewarded with incredible views of the surrounding area.

I think Adam's peak would be a great place for people who love nature. Unfortunately I was there in August which technically is off season (for pilgrimage), so there was absolutely no one except for me and my friends and the very kind dogs. We reached the place quite late in the afternoon and didn't intend to hike the whole thing either, so we only did a few kilometres before heading back. Adam's peak is meaningful for various religions, and I can't deny that there was a mystical feeling about the place. It was peaceful, and had some amazing views while hiking up, but do beware of leeches though. By the time we reached the bottom the mist already covered the mountains. Anyway I shall definitely try this hike again and hopefully the entire way to the top!

It is a force of nature; a conical mountain that stands 2246m in the midst of a beautiful area of lush green vegetation and tea plantations. It is also a very sacred place and important to Buddhists, Muslims, Christians and Hindus. It is not a physical challenge for nothing.. no pilgrimage ever is. You will probably do around 25k steps from bottom to top and down again and unless you are physically fit or a spring chicken, you will find this a strenuous activity. Having said that, every time my resolve wavered as I climbed one step after another, I looked at the people around me. My companions ranged from little ones of 5, to parents who carried their babies in their arms, to grandmothers and grandfathers well into their 70s or 80s, often helped by family members arm in arm. That to me was the essence of climbing Adam‚Äôs Peak. It spoke to me of the strength of family ties and the need to rely on others in life, that one can‚Äôt and shouldn‚Äôt go through life alone. The downside to this amazing place is the commercialisation, the shops and the resultant rubbish that accumulated along the way. Who can blame people for making a living? It‚Äôs the tourist who is probably at fault for most of the rubbish here. The saying ‚Äútake nothing but pictures, leave nothing but memories‚Äù is pertinent here. Other reviewers comment on the steepness of the steps and the cold at the top of you go before sunrise. All true. But so worth the effort of seeing the sun rise above the eastern hills. Go.. but do your bit and take all your rubbish down the mountain with you!

Almost everybody can do this. Yes it‚Äôs not easy, but I thought it was totally worth it. I need to say that our day started perfect. It was nog too cold and not too warm. At the top the sunrise was just perfect and so amazing. It was not too busy so we didn‚Äôt have to wait in line to get up to the top. I loved being between de locals and everyone was so so friendly Must see / do for everyone!
Not what we expected, at all. It was jam packed with people despite our early start at 1:30 in the morning.  Full of pushy people, it was a 2 hour wait in the ‚Äòque‚Äô to get all the way to the top.

I climbed Adam's Peak 2 days ago. It was bloody beautiful. We left early, just after 1am, because i'm pretty unfit and knew i was going to need some time. We made it in just over 4 hours... it only started feeling crowded near the top at about 4am ish. People were generally super respectful on the way up, there was alot of comradery, especially for people like me that were dying by the last Km. You do get to a point when you think, omg when will this end! And then it does and you feel GREAT. Beautiful sunset. The way down hurt like hell. I fell down a flight of stairs which was quite funny, and lots of people came to help. All in all amazing experience. If i can do it, almost anyone can.

We went there on 21/2/2018 and absolutely stunned by the view of sunrise up there üòÆ We started at 2 am from our accomodation (about 15 minutes to the starting point) and had few mini breaks here and there as well as tea and toilet breaks which took up around 3 hours to get up! We fortunately able to secure a spot at the stair just before the actual temple and sat for about an hour in cold for sunrise to happen which is around 6 am from memory and we started making our way down around 6:30 am; took us 1.5 hours back half running (we wanted to get back ASAP to catch up on some rest before taking bus back to Hatton and continued our journey by train). Arguably this is one of the hardest hike we have done, however, you will be amazed on how many locals from different clothes attire (barefoot, sandals, long skirts) and ages are able doing it well! Definitely need to do stretching pre and post hiking. Remember to bring small money for you to pay for toilets (depending on where it‚Äôs located, price LKR 20-40; the higher the expensive it become) or cup of black tea (we paid LKR 50/cup). FYI - 1.5 litres water bottle cost LKR 200.

This is a enjoyable walk in a lovely area. However,the walk is demanding. One of the nicest parts is joining the pilgrims in their pilgrimage. The people are just so happy and friendly and appreciate that you are doing the journey with them. We walked in the afternoon as we didn‚Äôt want to walk in the dark at 2am and it was still good. In the early morning your feet can freeze at the top so we thought the afternoon was appropriate.Stay the night in a hotel nearby the start of the walk

We climbed Adam‚Äôs peak after a religious event but was still very busy. We started our climb at 0230hrs from our hotel which is one of the closest. It took us around 2 hours to get to the 500m mark which is where the queues began. This did include a few stops on the way. Although I wouldn‚Äôt say you have to be an athlete to do this, it is tough even for the fittest of people. The crowds were moving but it was a squeeze and we just about made it up for sunrise! The sunrise was incredible and you see different views when coming down with the daylight. The only thing that didn‚Äôt make this experience 5 stars was the crowds. There was lots of pushing and shoving at the top and we didn‚Äôt expect it to be so crowded. It was a shame as I think this does ruin it. But as said in other reviews do take warm clothing as it is chilly up there and especially when you are standing waiting for sunrise.
don' go on weekends, it will be full, very full and you get stuck before reaching the top. Don't get stuck with templedonation, there is no fee.

We did the mistake to go on Saturday. Normally they recommend to start at 2:30 to be on the top at the dawn. We were in a  really good rhythm and we stopped in ever green place restaurant. Was impossible to go further ( 2 hours )Other tourists were going down and told us they only walk 10 steps in 1 hour!!!! We check google maps and approx on a normal day in 15 minutes we probably will be on the top. Was a pity. My recommendation: go in low season and during the week

We decidet to climb to Adam¬¥s peak on 4.2. 2018 and we didn¬¥t have the idea, that it is in the same time holidays in Sri Lanka and as well the celebration of Independency. We started from the hotel Wathsala Inn at 01¬®:00 AM. The way up was a dream. It was full of local people, young, old, mothers with little babies, blind people, all wanted to reach the top before sunrise. The trip upstairs was very difficult, we did it in 3,5 hours, due to crazy "trafic jam", because the narrow stairs were full of people. But the experience, when you are tired but upstairs and you did it is amazing. On the top it is windy and cold, it is good to have with you some proper cloaths. Even local people are going just in flipflops, or without shoes... To go down was very difficult and 4 days after I still had have huge legs pain. But it was great and we were happy to be there. To be a part of that trip, to speak with smiling local people, to share with them that moments.

Ok if you are looking for a serene sitting on a ledge overlooking the sunset pondering life ...this is NOT going to happen during climbing season .  It is an amazing experience if getting to the top is just a part of it .  Stay at Adams peak itself near the start of the walk ..don‚Äôt stay at hatton which is a rough 90 minute ride .stay at the accommodation at Adams peak itself .  Getting up at 2 am for the hike up is at must and adds to the experience .  There are tea rooms the whole way up and don‚Äôt be fooled it‚Äôs a tough climb ..especially the last part..I‚Äôm fit and active and it was hard . If you are injured at all just don‚Äôt do it . It‚Äôs about 3-4 hours to the top ..rest a lot of you can it gets really steep ...at the top it‚Äôs CROWDED and you jockey for position to see the sunrise ..the sun rise was pretty and being crammed into the rock concert like pack at the top added to the experience ......... Then it‚Äôs 90 min back down for a well earned breakfast Amazing experience but it‚Äôs the total package not just the view

We decided to go for it and make the climb, not realizing just how hard it would be.  A few pieces of advice: wear light clothes to start (you're going to get reeeeeaaaallly hot as you climb), but bring layers because it is pretty cold at the top, wear good, supportive shoes (your knees and feet will thank you), if you have ANY walking problems bring some sort of walking stick/cane/brace because it is very hard on the knees, and bring some sort of electrolyte drink.  There are food stalls that sell water, tea, coffee, and snack food, but they don't have that. That said, watching the sunrise from up at the peak is breath-taking and is not to be missed. Also, you don't need a guide, so don't let anyone try to buffalo you into getting one.  The path splits here and there, but there's seriously only one way to go.

We started to walk at 02:00. When we got close to the top we got stuck. It was to crouded and we didn't move for a long time. It got really cold as a Well. We saw the sunrise and it was nice but not worth it.

My partner and I did this walk on a Saturday morning. Left at 1:15am (took us 10 mins from hour hostel to get to the start). We arrive at the summit at 3:30am and waited. And waited. The sky started to change. AMAZING! We left the summit at 6:30am as we had to get a bus to Hatton between 8:30am and 9am. 1. Take a warm jacket and something windproof (I‚Äôm talking a ski jacket - it was freezing!) 2. Take something to sit on. Concrete steps are no fun for 2.5 hours 3. Take a blanket as some sections are no shoes 4. For the ladies, wear loose pants. I wore tights for comfort and after 2 hours of being gawked at by groups of local men/boys I was pretty over it

Climbing the 5500+ concrete steps to adams peak took us 3 hours with many stops along the way. There was many tea shops and toilets so the climb is possible for anyone of any fitness. The view from the top is well worth the effort, one of the most beautiful things I‚Äôve ever experienced. Very cold so pack a puffer and take a blanket if it‚Äôs windy because you have to wait a bit at the top for sunrise. Highly highly recommend!!!

For me the hiking is tough coz i‚Äôm not a hiker üòÖ. Climbing up around 2am, luckcy we arrived on time for the sunrise. It takes around 5 hour for the hiked and 2.5 hour going down. I don‚Äôt think I can finally to the top if I‚Äôm hiking after the sunrise. Unfortunately, hiking when its dark soni could not see the track.. if not I surely surrender. I couldn‚Äôt feel my leg when going down but its worth it!! The value of the nature is priceless.

The climb is exhausting due to the 5500 steps, but it's totally worth it. Be prepared to walk out early (at 2 or 3 a.m.) in order to see the stunning sunrise from the top. It's very cold on the top and you are supposed to take off your shoes, so be prepared and dress warm! After the sun goes up, it's getting much warmer. You can buy some food and drinks on the way up (or down), but take your own water as well. It's very crowded on the top before and during the sunrise, but you can find a good spot for photos. If on Sri Lanka, that's a must do!
We took the hike at 2:30am and arrived 30 minutes before sunrise. The next day i couldn't feel my legs! But it is worth the climb
We were visited Adam's peak with our family. Really nice place to visit this place and highly RECOMEND to visit siripadaya. At least one time needs to hike Adam's peak.

This was the best trip ever! We started to climb up early in the morning to catch sunrise. It wasn't easy - About 5 500 steps. But the view from the peak is worth it! Absolutely amazing. Would deffinately do it again if visiting Sri Lanka.

Warning: this will hurt your legs. You're walking up 5.5K steps...and then down the same steps. The steps are all in good shape, ignore anyone saying they're "crumbling", the path is fine, although very steep in places. We saw 80 years olds (or older!) doing this, albeit they were incredibly slow of course. That was actually part of the magic, watching these ageing pilgrims dragging themselves up the mountain. Overall, we started about 02:15 on Monday morning, got to the top about 5am and had a tea in the last shop before the final climb. We were back down again by 8am for breakfast. At the top, the temple was packed for sunrise, but slightly further down it was amazing. We had a guide who spoke sod all English, but really knew his viewing spots well and guided us away from the main crowds to empty spaces further down the steps. Notes: - Do not go on a weekend (other than Sunday night, Monday morning). We met other travellers who got stuck in a queue and spent 3 hours covering 50 yards on a Saturday night/Sunday morning.....). Sri Lankans take this seriously in the main season. - Avoid any poya days, also packed - Toilets are fine if you're ok with a normal asian drop toilet (aka hole in the ground, and a bucket of water) - Loads of food + drink on the way up - Guide useful, IF, they know the spots to catch the sunrise in a bit of piece - Don't expect to see any wildlife, it's all about the view

This is a challenging climb. We set off at 2:30 which was ample time to reach the top with plenty of breaks on the way. It was exceptionally cold at the top so if you're early for sunrise it might be advisable to wait at the final tea shop for a while and then do the final 10 minutes of climbing nearer to 6am. View from the top is absolutely stunning, definitely makes the climbing worth it. My calves were a mess for 3 days after, should've done some stretches before!

This was one of the best things my wife and I did during our 3 week honeymoon in Sri Lanka. We found lots of conflicting advice online beforehand, so here are our tips, for anyone interested in doing the hike; - The hike took us 2hrs 50mins up and 2hrs down. We stopped a few times on the way up to get drinks/our breath but not at all on the way down. For comparison, it took us about 1hr 30mins to hike Ella Rock. - Don‚Äôt bring food or water - you can pick it up cheaply and easily on the way - Shorts/elephant pants and t-shirt are perfect for the hike itself. You‚Äôll want a long sleeved top and maybe a hat for the summit but not much more - we overpacked and regretted it! - If the weather isn‚Äôt looking great then you can buy fleeces, waterproofs, hats, gloves and luminous teddy bears from numerous market stalls in Dalhousie for next to nothing. - Best view of the sunrise is from the steps immediately in front of the temple - you‚Äôll need to get there early to get a spot but it‚Äôs absolutely worth it :D If you‚Äôre even half considering doing this, make it part of your trip. It‚Äôs an experience we wouldn‚Äôt want to have missed out on!

One of the highlights of my Sri Lanka trip. The walk up is not fun, the first hour or so is probably the hardest, just because it's so early (best to start at around 2am). But once you break through that wall the walk becomes easier, even if the steps become steeper. My group of 6 and I did it in exactly 3 hours, and that was with a lot of very lengthy stops. There are places to grab snacks, fruit and water at consistent intervals all the way up the mountain. Definitely bring a thick jumper or blanket with you, as the summit is FREEZING! Also be prepared to share the summit with ALOT of likeminded people. It can get pretty crowded up there waiting for the sunrise. The walk down is much quicker, and with the sun up, you get to take in all the amazing views at different levels! I think this is a must do when in SL. Side note; please be respectful to SL culture and customs. Inside the temple area at the summit there is a big sign to remove footwear and also to not take photos of the temple itself. Yet I saw SO MANY non-Sri Lankans wearing shoes (until being told by police to remove them) and taking selfies with the temple. If you're going to visit Sri Lanka and monuments sacred to them, just please exercise some respect :)

I echo most of the other comments, the hike took me 2.5 hours with 5 min stops every 20 mins, started at 2.30 Only gets cold about 500m from the top, but I am from the Uk so aclimatased to cooler weather. No need to pack any food or drinks, you can buy it all on the way up/down It‚Äôs incredibly crowded at the top, and difficult to see the sunrise compared to other hikes I‚Äôve done (like Bali), it‚Äôs a religious pilgrimage so sunrise is not the objective of 90% of the people understandably! Don‚Äôt do what I did and climb on a Poya / Full moon day. The train from Kandy to Hatton was packed, the hike busy and when you reach Ella later that day all the restaurants are not serving alcohol due to the religious day which trust me is needed after that hike!

This was one of the most beautiful treks I have done. The climb up is fairly easy since it's all steps. However, make sure you are well rested before you start the ascend. Start around 2-2:30 to reach in time for the sunrise. Make sure you carry warm clothes and light snacks.

We just finished climbing Adams Peak from Nallathannia, so here are some observations which may be helpful. A - Try NOT to go on Sat or Sun because all the Sri Lankans are off work and they will be there. It has been a pilgrimage site for at least 800 years (Marco Polo mentioned it in 1200) and it remains an important destination for them. If you have to go on those days, consider getting a guide. We had one and he took us on a short cut, which was actually a cut over to the second, less used path to the top. (Looking at Google maps satellite imagery I am 90% certain it was the Adiyamala Thenna Geththarpana footpath but I did not confirm this with the guide or any locals). This way was not crowded and we walked right up to the top. (DON'T however go back down this way without a guide, because if you miss the footpath cut off, you will walk down 14 km, instead of 7 km AND you will be in the wrong town, which is a 2 hour drive back to Nallathannia - per our guide). The people on the main route were backed up & stopped at least 500 meters below the top and they did not make it to the top for sunrise. Indeed they were still standing/sitting on the stairs when we went down that way about 45 min after sunrise. Apparently none of the other (young & fit) hikers, who stayed at our hotel the night before, made it to the top today because of that issue. B - Unless you are really on a Pilgrimage or unless it is a week day and the Temple is wide open,  there is no need to stand in the line to walk through the Temple. First,  the Sri Lankans waiting in line were incredibly rude & aggressive. One of them hit my wife with his backpack to push her to the side and then pulled his friend up into her spot. Also, inside you get two seconds while they hustle you through like cattle AND the actual footprint is covered with Holy cloth etc. so you can't even see it. Instead of standing in that line, stake out a good spot to view the sunrise. C - If you take the cutover, take a headlight or good flashlight for each person. It's a trail, not stairs,  and there are no lights along the path. D - If you have bad joints or weak quads, consider taking a cane or 1 or 2 walking sticks, for the way down. Going up is a cardiovascular stress test, but coming down will cause pain in any arthritic joints you may have AND by the halfway point your quads will be Jello. Walking sticks would have helped a great deal. The photos are: 1-The lights along the top of the path at 2 am. 2-The hordes of people about 500 meters from the top,  completely stopped and still waiting to get to the top at 7am. 3- Sunrise from near the top.

Strange feeling walking up stone steps when you should be asleep Left Nuwara Elija at 11 pm and arrived about 2 am for the hike upwards There are lots of shops to buy water and candy on arrival  as you will need it later on . Just follow the stone steps to the top . Arrived at the summit about 4 am . Walk diagonally up the steps . It might help for the journey to go quicker . It gets gradually tougher and tougher and it‚Äôs best to take a breath and stop for a few minutes . You will be soaked in sweat by the time you reach the top . It could be worse and the ascent could be on a slippery slope but it‚Äôs stone steps the whole way . There are stone steps to sit whilst waiting for sunrise and a temple above plays Bhajans and Music . It‚Äôs a special space . It‚Äôs very windy on the summit . Wear long trousers and bring a jumper and scarf . It‚Äôs a wait for sunrise from 4 am so wrap up The sunrise and views of the sky are awesome at the time of sunrise . You don‚Äôt have to get there too early - at 4 am I had a few teas for 100 rs each and spoke to random people . In reality you can arrive at 6 am for the sunrise . Going down only took about an hour as you can skip down the stones without too much problem . I was back home to Nuwara Elija by 10 am

This is really worth the walk! So fantastic views and the sunrise was amazing to watch! It was quite hard to walk up there if you are not used to walk stairs.. i still have problems with walking 2 days after the climbüòÇ remember when u finaly come up, you also have to walk the stairs downüòÖ absolutley worth it! We where recomended to walk at 02 at night to see sunrise.. wich means you won‚Äôt see anything on your way up! But after sunrise and daylight appears its like the mountain reveals its secrets.. amazing! And all the way down you will have great views and stunning moments.. inbetween swearing over your uncotrolable shaking legsüòú

We climbed Adams peak yesterday and loved it for a few reasons: - we woke up at midnight to start the hike, while this sounds stupid it meant ~half the tea shops were shut and we were walking solely with locals. It was a very reverential experience and we didn‚Äôt see another foreign tourist until 700m from the summit - we took a good amount of warm clothes - I had extra pants (thin), cardigan, jacket, rain jacket, beanie. My partner had the same without the cardi. We also bought a thin blanket at Nuwara Eliya which was extremely helpful. We weren‚Äôt warm but it was ok. - hiking so early meant we got a great view at the top. - we got stunning views - very clear day! Would highly recommend! We loved it (even though right now my knees and calves are killing me)

One of the most challenging and rewarding experiences in Sri Lanka. Get prepared, it won't be easy. But really rewarding. You don't need any special climbing skills, as the path is always with stairs. At the last part, you will find handrails. However, you need to be physically prepared. Go soon, so you have time to stop some times. Take warm clothes. We were there in the summer, the night was hot, but the temperature and the wind at the top... freezing! (After the climbing, your clothes will be wet, which makes it worst). Despite all that, the views are undescribable. We saw one of the most beautiful sunrises ever! (And already seen que a few, in some iconic places). I would imagine that even if we didn't had the sunrise, the moment when the morning ceremonies occurred, was magical. One thing, try to respect those ceremonies and people who go there because of their faith. Avoid make to much noise and throttling around in front of them (as, unfortunately, many tourists do). Overall, my advice: be prepared, the journey is as much hard as fulfilling.

This by far was the most hectic and energy draining experience I've had my whole life. We started the journey at 2:00 and we reached the peak at around 6:30. Throughout the journey, my legs were paining me like crazy but after you reach the peak you have that sense of accomplishment that comes with it. It's definetely worth it to try it once (Please note that the "foot" upstairs is not open until it's peak time - not sure what month is that). You will keep climbing up and up and up and up and up and it will seem like it's going forever, but me and my wife managed to do it and in the end we were satisfied with the experience. We reached the bottom at around 9:30, but my legs are sore till this day (been 5 days). Enjoy the experience and sunset on top :)!!

This is a tough gig......and I run a couple of marathons a year. Nothing compares to 5,500 steps up & back down again. Don‚Äôt worry though - every age, shape & size is going up - from 90 years olds, to 3 year old kids. If you get puffed, or need a break, do what the locals do, just take a 10 minute break on the steps & get going again when ready. What to wear! Walking up can be very hot & sweaty - we all wore sportswear - shorts & a singlet/t-shirt & good shoes. When the pace slows due to the crowds near the top, you will need to pull out a long sleeve top & leggings/track pants etc and a beanie/hoodie will be useful.....you‚Äôll need them because it is cold at the top. We did the walk on a Sunday - which is the busiest day for locals - probably between 3,000 - 5,000 locals! (No accurate estimate there was that many people!) It took us 6 hours, leaving at midnight - which included 2 hours slow wait when 300 meters from the top. I would recommend doing Adam‚Äôs Peak mid-week (Tues - Thurs) and avoid the weekends. In saying that, the volume of Buddhists going up simply highlighted just how sacred Adams Peak is. Loads of food, tea & water shops all the way along the track & toilets too - don‚Äôt overload yourself with carrying heavy water bottles - carry warm clothes instead. Get to the top & you‚Äôll always look back & think - ‚Äúthat was a bit hard, but god it was worth it!

If you are not a religious person, don‚Äôt go here! If you just want a good view over beautiful scenery, choose another mountain, there are plenty of them in Sri Lanka. This is by far the worst experience I had in this country. There are shops selling mostly garbage all the way up to the summit. The whole tourist trap thing is overwhelming. This could have been a nice place to visit if you removed all the shops, the lights, the music and chanting from the mountain, and left only the trail to the monastery on the summit. If walking in a que up a mountain on stairs that seems to leed to Ayia Napa, after a long and teadeus journey, this is the place for you!
If you want to avoid a long queue and you  accept to see sunset is the go at 3 pm. The jorney takes 2 hours if you hurry otherwise 3 hours.

The views are spectacular but you have to get there before 9:30am or so. Clouds usually roll in around 10am. It‚Äôs about 7km from the Dambathenna village so, if you‚Äôre taking a bus you still have quite a hike to get to the top. You can also get a tuktuk from the village or from Haputale of course. Entry fee is LKR150 pp. The hike down is quite nice if you don‚Äôt want to hike up AND down (tuktuk up then walk down to the village to catch a bus or a tuktuk).
The most amazing view in Sri Lanka. We are started climbing at 2.30 and we arriwed before the sunrise. Many people going to the Sri Pada all day and night and soooooo many shop in the road.

72 km east of Colombo 2.243 m conic mountain is Adams peak , Muslim Christians  Buddhist considering Holly Top of hill 1/5 m foot print belong Buddha or Adams 5 hour climb to peak for me it was 2/5 hour I climb 5.500 step to see Majestic sunrise and the shadow

5,500 stairs made my knees shake by the time I went up & down but the challenges & spectacular views of the sunrise are worth it. Wear warm clothing, the cold up there can make or break your experience. Would do it again.

This was probably the most memorable experience we had from our two and a half week long trip in Sri Lanka. Get up at 2am and hike the 1000 altitude meters (3300 vertical ft) in 3-4 hours, and be at the peak to watch the sun rise a bit after 6am. Then walk down again (if you think that will be a piece of cake, you may be very wrong) for around two hours. There are stalls almost all the way to the top where you can buy tea, soda, food, etc. Bring warm clothes. It will be chilly on the peak, particularly before the sun rises. Also, be prepared that you will be far from alone on the peak. From January (particularly on weekends and full moon Days) until the peak(!) in April, the number of visitors increase drastically. But it's a fun thing to do. And hard work. The views after sunrise are spectacular.

Just tried to complete the climb, unfortunately due to huge numbers we gave up about 500m short of the summit, We attempted the climb on the Sunday of a festival long weekend which was a mistake.after a good start we got to the 4.3km mark and it then took over two hours to go a further km. We did enjoy the festival atmospheres until we were hemmed in and jostled as we the stayed still for long periods and inched forward periodically. Strong advice don't go in Jan on a holiday weekend to avoid disappointment or waiting all day and missing the sunrise. My feet are sore and I was glad of a taking pole. If you have bad knees may not be for you.
A challenging hike that is reward with a spectacle sunrise. Be warned the climb is very steep and can be quite cold at the top if you arrive early like we did.

Gorgeous sunset and ceremony up at the temple. The climb up wasn‚Äôt too bad and took about 3 hours but the way down was brutal. It took us 4 hours and my legs still hurt 2 days later. It was all worth it though!

Unsure what the fuss is. It's free (weird for Sri Lanka) but you walk in the dark to see the sunrise so miss the views The first part of the walk is past 100s of identical shops selling tat, toys or sweets, and latter food and drinks. There is literally no point packing these things as you have so many options right up to the top. The top is a temple with no views, far too many people and no shoes (tough in the cold) The sunrise is great from the stairs to dalhousie about 2 mins from the top where its leas crowded and good views.  It's worth seeing this but a sunrise is better at little Adams peak, Ella rock and Horton plains where the view is the same, but the location more hidden. Be warned its not a remote cliff top, it's literally stairs and a temple so don't expect anything more at the top. 5500 stairs was tough going.  Took us two hours in both directions but up was definitely a struggle

I tried to find a review that said 'this is fun, this is easy, you will love it' It was the hardest yet most enlightening experience I have had! It's tough! It hurts -particularly coming down! It's eye opening! It's a fab feeling being at the summit! You're all in it together. Definitely wear layers, take water, have a positive attitude and enjoy the breathtaking views at dawn We left just after 2am-got to the temple at the top at 5am. We were up there for a while due to the crazy crowds (it was xmas eve) and we arrived back at our hotel around 9am. Good luck-take photos!
We avoided the busy night ascend for sunrise and instead did start the climb early morning around 8:45am. It is quite exhausting but rewarding also. Only stairs. Nice views from atop.

The hike up the stairs was tough but loads of little rest stops. Take warm clothes and buy some snacks for when you're at the top, you'll appreciate it. But seriously it is cold up there!!!! The thing is, whilst beautiful you are surrounded by so many others, I'm sure everyone was thinking the same that it would be better without the other 500 people. Yes, that many! No exaggeration. But it was also a vibe of camaraderie so also good fun. Views are awesome.

Was absolutely incredible though you feel it in your legs a couple of days later. I‚Äôm a pretty fast walker so got up at 4am and had to wait around at the top for 2 hours. If you‚Äôre a strong walker/runner, be prepared for getting up there early and take a warm hat at least and a scarf. It gets really chilly with the wind. The walk down is also incredibly beautiful. I‚Äôm traveling solo and I felt perfectly safe.

Adams peak is a tough hike especially for someone who doesn‚Äôt work out. 5500 steps, almost 3hours of non stop climbing. Prepare your calves for some soreness!! However not gonna be a Debbie downer, the hike is done by children and elderly. So if they can do it you can do it! There are lots of shops alone the way, they got snacks and water and motivation to keep going! Also there‚Äôs lights along the track and toilets every 20min. You don‚Äôt have to wear hiking shoes; some people go with flip flops and some running shoes. I prefer running shoes or any comfy ones you own. We reached the top at 5:30am and sunrise started at 6:00am and trust me; the hike was worth the view. May the force be with you- enjoy!

Something you have to see and do for yourself! Words can‚Äôt describe the feeling once you get up there and pictures can not do the view any justice.
