Would recommend doing it on a weekday as there isn‚Äôt so many people there. The locals told us that weekends are very very busy climbing up it! We are a pretty fit couple and there were times that did test us but the track has shop stalls along the way which offer seats to rest. I would recommend buying your water and snacks before hand as they do charge a fair bit more up the mountain.  (but as they should, they cart boxes of drinks and whatever else all the way up there over there heads) The trek took us roughly 3 hours with regular stops to rest the legs and a coffee break at one of the stalls. There is regular police and medical posts along the way also! The hardest part of the trek would be the last 500 meters which does get pretty steep, but there is no shame in taking it slowly and moving to one side to get the jelly legs going again. Once at the top, the police let you know that it can get very busy and to keep your belongings on you and in your site at all times. We took a go pro and an expensive camera up and had no problems with anyone being suspicious or anything like that so I think that is just a standard warning. The best place to view the sunset is at the viewing deck to the left of the stairs as you arrive, get a good spot as it packed out while we were there and you don‚Äôt want to miss the sunrise (no words to explain it) It is very very cold once you stop hiking and relax to wait for the sun rise, so definitely take some warm clothes/gloves whatever else you need (there‚Äôs friendly and cheap shops in town if you didn‚Äôt bring any) The climb down is a breeze, once you get all the blood back into your legs. There was a few stacks down the stairs (including myself lol) but nothing to major. The sun has came out and the view down the mountain is visible and breath taking! We were blessed by a monk on the way down which was an awesome experience. We highly recommend you do NOT miss out this. It‚Äôs scary to look up at it and think ‚Äúthat looks friggen impossible.‚Äù But it is easier than it looks and you won‚Äôt regret it ! Enjoy.

Adam's peak its very beautiful place and good for rock climbing. its normal take 4 hours to climbing. but i take only 2.20 hours only. the time is depending on your power. but after the climbing i got a lag pain in my body. i hope it will be ok after one week. i start my climbing 3.45 am from nallathanni and i take a rest for every 45 minutes then finally i reach the place. dress cord is very important be course its very cold place.

Firstly, to the person who wrote a review saying the hike is easy to moderate...you‚Äôre wrong! My boyfriend and I are relatively fit people who exercise often and we found this hike was very challenging. We managed to finish the hike in 2 hrs 15, and it‚Äôs safe to say that it‚Äôs been 4 days and our calves are still recovering. In saying that, it was rewarding when we got to the top, with a lovely view and if you are around the area I would highly recommend you take on the challenge!

Start from Nallathanniya, NOT HATTON, Hatton is 30 km away from the starting point. The trek is a tough one, but doable and totally worth it. ANYONE can do it, you just have to start early, have water and chocolate/candy for energy, take breaks when required.... n you should be up there in no time. We started at 2AM and we reached the top by 5AM to witness the sunrise a little before 6AM. The views are spectacular and one of the best sunrises we have witnessed. You don't need a guide, no payment either.... its FREE. There are monks at various points asking for donation, just give them a friendly smile and ignore/avoid them politely. The top stairs have railing so that helps the final part and you might not need the trekking sticks. We didn't get any and we were fine. But you do need a torch or headlamp. Our guesthouse lend us a torch and that was very helpful, they also told us that we dont need to rent a trekking stick either. We stayed in Queensark which was 200 meters away from the start. You can also stay in Grand Adams Peak, Vegetable Garden, Slightly Chilled Guesthouse and Restaurant... these are within the same distance from the starting point which is approx. 200 meters. You start at 2AM and take frequent breaks. Make sure you have plenty of water and chocolate/candy/sugary stuff to get energy. There is a tea stall almost 500 meters before the top, and you can get Sri Lankan break and tea to get carbs n sugar. Its 3 hours to go up and 2 hours to come down. We spent 1 hour enjoying the sunrise and the surrounding natural beauty. Starting at night is better cuz during the day it get pretty hot and hence, it gets harder to get up. Plus, there will be atleast 40-50 climbers with you anyways, so that helps to get up as well. Important: The trek is FREE, but there will be LOTS of monks on the way who will ask for donation (MONEY). You don't have to register your name anywhere either. You can see them from a distance, and when you see them, keep a distance, have a friendly smile when they say hi, and politely wave, say thanks n keep walking fast. They are friendly, n wont insist, so its easy to avoid them.

I loved this hike because I hated it while I was huffing and puffing my way up there. We took 3 hours and 15 minutes to get up and 2 hours and 15 minutes to get down. There were others who were much faster with the descent, but this is all we managed with our fitness levels. The town to go to trek this place is called Nallathaniya. Book a place which is in the town so you are close to the base. You will be regretful especially when it's done and your muscles are sore. The town has not much else so plan to leave right after the trek. We headed to Nuwara Eliya but Ella isn't too far either. The nearest bus stand is Hatton which is connected by rail as well. We stayed at a place called Ayos Hill Adam's Peak which arranges transportation to the base camp but over all, the location was way too far from the base (almost 4 kms). The peak in itself has not much to offer except the view of the sunrise unless you are the religious type. Get up there and perch yourself on one of the steps on top to get a good view. It's tough but not impossible so do not be scared of the challenge. You can buy water along the way as there will be lot of eateries selling tea/snacks etc. Carry some fruits like banana with you which is the best food option while trekking. Travel as light as possible.

I would recommend you stay in one of the many guesthouses near the base of Adam's Peak. That way you can start the walk/climb directly from the hotel and avoid needing to arrange transport. We started out from the hotel at 2am which was perfect. We were ahead of the masses although there were definitely many other walkers at the same time. Don't worry if you are on your own as there are so many people on the walk. The start of the climb is easy with a gradual incline. There are parts of the track that are not as well lit as others and we did use the flashlight on our phones to see the way - but mostly the track is well lit. The climb gets gradually tougher on the way up and the last section is the hardest with steep narrow steps but there is a railing which does help a lot. The climb took us around two and a half hours with a few short stops along the way. to catch our breath. There are small stalls along the way if you want to but water, drinks or snacks. There are also local toilets along the way as well. There were a lot of people the morning we climbed to the top which created a "traffic jam" near the top. When we reached the very top it was crowded. It is best to find a spot to sit out of the wind and wait for the sunrise. Do take something warm with you as it is chilly. I thought a thin sweater would be fine but I was shivering. A warmer covering would have been much better. Once the light starts to break through everyone is standing with cameras and many  jostling for the best vantage spot. I would recommend moving down from the top a little and getting a better spot with uninterrupted views where you can enjoy the moment. The walk back down Adam's Peak was much easier and took about two hours. The scenery on the walk down is breathtaking and the misty clouds add to the experience. Although the calf muscles were sore the next day it was well worth the climb in this beautiful part of Sri Lanka. Do it!

Great climb. We know the peak maybe covered in most so wasn‚Äôt disappointed by the lack of a view. I would recommend starting off early, 02.30. Brace yourself for a steady climb of uneven steps for 2.5 hours. There are stall that sell water on the way up so don‚Äôt load yourself down. Do definitely take a change of socks for the summit where it‚Äôs probably wet and you have to take your shoes off. Take a torch too incase the light on the path go out. The summit is underwhelmed from a tourist point of view. A bit are ‚Äúare we here?‚Äù Sums it up. 1960‚Äôs concrete bunker and some quaint areas for lighting candles and reflection. We much preferred sigiriyia and lions rock

It was one of the best experiences in my life! Be sure to start at 1.30/2 am with warm clothes packed in your backpack (do not wear them until you are on top). Bring a hat for the cold wind and gloves. Bring more layers, such as gym clothes in technical materials. The view of the sunrise from the top is spectacular! You will forget how sore your legs are :)

We arrived into Nallathaniya after sunset to smash sri pada the next morning. It started raining that night and when we left our accommodation at 3:30am it was still raining. We would have waited a day hoping for better weather but there didn't seem much to do in the area unless you had a boat or scooter, so off we went on the off chance it would clear before sunrise or maybe the peak was above the clouds? It wasn't and the rain didn't stop until we had had brunch back at the bottom. We seemed to be the last tourist to leave as we didn't pass anyone and were welcomed at the top to a packed out miserable audience staring at the clouds waiting for a sunrise that clearly wasn't going to come. At the top don't take your shoes off at the first sign, wait until you actually go into the temple. At about 10am as we were leaving the town the clouds parted and I saw the peak, so I should have started walking at a more sensible hour to get a view. It was a tough walk up and down and my legs were shaking at the bottom. If it was clear and I got a sunrise I think I would have given it a 5 star.

I find it hard to express how this climb made me feel.  As a solo female traveller I felt safe and protected by fellow hikers and the view and atmosphere was something I will never forget. Those visiting Sri Lanka really must take this trek. Difficult for the last hour but so so worth it.  I was brought to tears by sunrise December 13, 2017....

Was here the second day of the season, which was around december 2th. The village Dalhousie is awefull, don't stay there unless you really have to. I started around 00u30, way too early. I reached the top around 4, with a lot of breaks. Too many breaks, but I knew I would be there too early. The steps were well lit, so you don't need a torch. Every 200 metres you can have a drink or some food if you want. I sticked with coffee, but they also had other things like coca cola, redbull, etc. Very nice scenery, but if you walk at night you will only see it coming down. Very cold up top, especially if you have to wait 2 hours before sunrise. There are sleeping places to stay out off the wind, but it is crowdy. At 5-5h30 most other tourists arrive. It get's way too crowded to enjoy the sunrise. Smartphones and camaras spoil the feeling. Without those it can be one of the best ecpierences. Great views with misty valleys, green mountains, waterfalls, etc. If you feel fit enough, do it! But don't expect the summit for yourself.

From its base at Dalhousie, Adam's Peak looks stunning and challenging to the walker/climber.  But after a fairly gentle start to the climb, the stairs to the top get steeper and steeper.  Towards the top there are some welcome hand rails for assistance.  At the top (2243m high) is the very modest temple housing the 'footprint' of Buddha - though the footprint is housed in a small structure that was closed to viewing on the day of my visit!  Terrific views and way up and from the top.  The descent can lead to 'wobbly knees' for those - like me - not used to descending hundreds and hundreds of steps on legs weary from the ascent!  Only attempt this ascent if you are reasonably fit.

Adam‚Äôs Peak Sri lankan people believe the place where Adam's first set foot on earth after being cast out of heaven We start to hike after midnight 2am unfortunately that day but rain weather we didn't see the sun set .every one saying its clearly can see most of the days We travel with family chauffeur Jay and his # +94702044472 fantastic Driver will recommend him to everyone

My wife and I decided that we can‚Äôt visit Sri Lanka without also going up to the top of Adam‚Äôs Peak. We started the night at 3 am ( after sleeping for a couple of hours at best before ) and started the hike. At first we were excited and all in for the experience. Very Important: torch, water, waterproof jacket, and snacks. At some point it started becoming very challenging especially in the last bit of the hike. You can find along the way some shops that sell water , tea, and snacks. Better not to overload yourself with water bottles and buy some water based on need as you go up. The place is peaceful and certainly a good workout. We reached the top in almost 3 hours and then the biggest disappointment was the fog where you could literally not see anything beyond 10 meters... that was such a bummer! Then we started the decent and it took us almost 2.5 hours. The decent ( at least for me) was the hardest part as all the pressure goes on your knees. It was really painful and I arrived to the hotel in real pain. To add on to the suffering, I got bit by leech in my legs and arms ( for those who don‚Äôt know what leech is, it‚Äôs a worm that sucks out your blood ) .... i only felt and saw it when I got back and saw all the blood on my legs and arms and clothes. All in all I would not recommend this unless you‚Äôre 100% sure you could see the sunrise from the top. Otherwise, it‚Äôs a total waste.

We did the climb off season (the temple at the top was shut) and really enjoyed it! We set off at 2am in order to get up before sun rise - it took us a bit over 2 hours to get to the top (so arguably woke up a bit too early), but the climb was actually really cool and we also enjoyed chilling at the top waiting for the sun. The path is super easy to follow and we got lucky with a clear and very starry night. The views as you descend are amazing! Bring some warm clothes as the top is quite breezy at night.

Leaving our hotel at 2.45am with our three small children we climbed (with many stops along the way!) to summit before sunrise. We were there in the off season so there were no lights along the way -we took head lamps and torches which you can pic up cheap from a little shop in town. Not many people climbing just a handful of other tourists, our kids were the only kids on the mountain that day, so received a lot of attention & praise from other hikers. Some of the shops were open on the path, more during the season apparently. It was truly magical and such a wonderful thing to do as a family. Our girls are only 8 yrs, 5 years and three years but were able to do the entire climb, it's tough in parts but there is a clear path all the way. Take some layers to wear. It's not cold when you set off but gets colder as you get higher then it's pretty chilly when you sit at the top to wait for the sun to rise. Do it, it's awesome!

a group of seven of us made the journey to climb adams peak. starting at 2.30 we managed to reach the top by 5.30. we had a guide as it was off season and there is no lighting during this time. was difficult at times with lots of uneven steep steps but definitely worth it! also would recommend staying at queensark a wonderful bnb with very helpful team and great food

We climbed out of season on a weekday. We climbed at 2.30am. Despite it being out of season there are places open to have water/tea/snacks on the way up, they just aren‚Äôt as plentiful as peak season. We walked up in t-shirts but you need the layers when you‚Äôre at the top. I‚Äôm a very slow walker and managed this in 3 hours with breaks. Going down I was much slower than most but thoroughly enjoyed the views and snapped away so it probably took me 2hrs. I used a walking pole too which I found very useful for my ‚Äòjelly legs‚Äô when I first started to descend. All the hard work of climbing is paid off by the spectacular views from the top and on the descent. This was my husbands favourite destination in Sri Lanka. He actually went into the temple at the top too after discussion/donation to a monk there (I‚Äôd already started my decent given my aforementioned slowness!) take small change for donation to the various monks along the way if you‚Äôre so inclined (I think I crossed 5 in total)

Wonderful walk up a big mountain in the middle of the night. Totally worth getting up at 2am to make the trip. Lovely camaraderie on the way and atmosphere at the top. We went slightly out of season and there were about 100 people in total on the climb. I would imagine that in season (Dec-April), there would be a much more lively atmosphere. We took our two children (7&12) and they both made it to the top (with a little assistance for the 7 year old)

We climbed at 3:30am from the Green House guest house to catch the sunrise in perfect time. the guest house was great. Right next to the beginning of the trek the man of the house is a gent. The walk was hard but worth it.

A lot of people do not plan a visit , and will not do the walk at 3 in the morning but it is absolutely worth doing and planning into your itinerary. A lifetime experience , great photos and so glad I did it - even if my legs are very stiff!

My friends and I recently Adams Peak and would highly recommend it if you want to see a nice sunrise. We stayed at Walthsala in Nallathanniya which was a very convenient location to do the hike, about 400m or so away. We set off at 2:15am and got up there at 5:15am. It was bucketing down rain, which is usually expected but just as we were reaching the top it stopped. About 2 weeks ago I did Mount Everest base camp and I would actually put this walk in the difficult category it is about 2hrs straight of very steep stairs. Along the way there are a few monks trying to get you to sign a book and they ask for a fair bit of money as a donation so don't get conned into that unless you want toot course. The views from the top were great, it was a little chilly when we did it, but mainly from the rain. And it wasn't overly busy maybe 30 people max.

We got up at 3am to start the hike and summit by sunrise. The weather wasn't perfect but we still wanted to give it a go. We encountered two monks on our walk up, sitting below temples. The first monk told us we must enter our names in the log book and make a donation. He showed us the book and said everyone pays 1000 rupees per person. We had not expected to need money for the hike and had only brought small change with us (nor were we in a position to donate such an amount). We wrote our names and explained that all we had on us was about 200 rupees, at which the monk expressed his disappointment and told us not to fill in the "amount" column (he presumably did it after we left to make sure a high amount was entered, so future tourists would not try to match our small donation). The monk at the second temple stopped us as well, but said "No donation necessary, sign only". We were relived because we had given all our money to the first monk. However after we signed our names the monk asked for a donation - We explained we had no money left. He then angrily crossed our names out of the log book and waved us away! Based on the number of entries were saw for the date we hiked and the number of people that were at the summit, not everyone had written in the log books / given a donation, but when you approach the monks alone (there was no one else around us at those points), they insist that you must enter your name and pay. But it's totally your choice! A guide is not necessary, the path is all concreted and clear, and there are plenty of people on the track.

We started to climb at 2.30am, the weather was ok we could see the stars in the sky so it was a good new so far, but after 1h of climbing, it started to rain a lot and we were in a huge fog.. an umbrella and a weatherproof weren't enough to protect us from the rain.. but we decided to finish it and go to the top anyway. During the climbing we saw a lot of waste along the path.. we were surprised to see such a touristic place looking like a bin :/ So we finally got to the top before the sunrise after 2h45 of climbing. But we couldn't see anything because of the fog and the rain, we waited 30 minutes in the cold and hoped it would stop but nothing.. so we left it and went down.. at the end, it wasn't worth the climbing. Really don't understand people that say it was a fantastic experience when they see nothing... ok it is a trying climbing but really doesn't worth it...

Good free activity to do in Sri Lanka (rare). Gruelling climb, you must have some fitness. Top of climb was not as expected. You stand looking over an ugly rooftop at the sunrise but still a good view. We heard it can be very busy in high season with queuing up to the top but when we went (sept) there was hardly anyone and it was almost free of walkers all the way to the top.

We first booked a hotel in hatton beacuse they have mentioned in booking.com that there is only 10.3km to adams peak which is actually 34 km away.we cancelled it and came to dellhouse also called Nallathaniya in where many nice hotels serve rooms and only 600m away from adamspeak.Be ware that you should book a hotel in Nallathannya to do the climb  with pleasure

We did the hike at 2 in the morning.sunrise was amazing and at abt 6.we booked a hotel by booking.com which showed 11km from adamspeak..but it is 35 km away.we had to find another hotel in nallathanniya and we found a nice hotel which is just 500m away from adamspeak.check the distance hotel when you make the booking. Hatton is 35 km away from adamspeak.we must book a hotel in NALLATHANNIYA to do adamspeak NOT IN HATTON

a must when traveling in srilanka ,nice with great views be sure you book a hotel in adam's peak normally in booking.com they says 8.8 km from adam'speak but actually the hotel was 40km so we didn't stay we arrived to nallathanniya we saw many hotel am stay there,it was much comfortable because we were near the base of the climb there was no tranportation fee when you book be sure you book a hotel in nallathanniya not in maskeliya or hatton or anywhere else

We traveled to adams peak from kandy. We get bus and go to hattan and then get bus again and go to adams peak . The bus ticket was abiut 40 rupees we arrived at night and found a cozy hotell and stay for 2 nights there . The hotels reservations said to us we should go to climb on 2 am and watch sunrise and back in early morning . But we feel sleepy too mich and we missed sunrise üòÇ and we started climbing at 7 am . In the way we feel paradise big trees big flowers big waterfalls everything is big there and beautiful. We visited temples in way and they give 1500 rupees for donations!!! After climbing for 5 or 6 hours ( I should say very very hard hours) we arrived but the temple was closed!!! And any body said to us !! In first 6 months of year the adams peak temple was closed !!! But we werent angry or unhappy because we had alot of wonderful view in our way .

And you're not the only ones, pilgrim season has a fair few travellers, so you'll never be alone. It is dark, so take a torch! You'll need all your phone battery for photos. It's tough. It's constant stairs for 2 to 4 hours. We managed it in just over 2. And coming back down is just as tough. Make sure you stretch before and after. Take warm clothing as it's freezing and very windy at the top, a blanket to sit on is useful, snacks and drinks. Sugary drinks are useful for the energy. Trainers are perfectly adequate and we found walking poles helped.

I climbed with children aged 11 and 12, so it took us four hours to reach the top. I decided to climb in the daylight, not wanting to climb in the dark with children.  The most difficult thing is not knowing how much further there is to go as we were off peak season for climbing and there were very few other people around to tell us, which in some ways is an advantage. It was a very wet day so there was no view from the top and it was not possible to get in to see the footprint. This is a taxing climb, but we enjoyed the challenge. We were followed by a small dog all the way up and down which made the trip even better.

I've read quite a lot of reviews saying that it's raining season, mating season for animals and off season where the temple of footprint is closed. But I decided to go simply because the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary is a part of UNESCO Heritage Site (which I'm collecting) and set it as a goal to reach the top. We started off late at 4am expecting not to see the sunrise because we saw the peak was surrounded by cloud the day before and knew that there won't be any sunrise. We also started light only with our rain jackets, a bottle of of water that we barely drink due to the rain, and our smartphone as torchlight as there's no light on the road. We spot no animals on the way but heard a lot of frogs croaking from the bushes. It was raining and foggy. Our sport shoes got wet quickly but it didn't affect much of the ascent. The climb was not so hard as there are proper stairs either made of rocks or concrete. When we're half way up we already saw some hikers coming down. We've been told there's no sunrise and the temple is locked. It didn't bother us much as we already knew that and our main goal was just to reach the top. We arrived at the top at around 7:30am and found it really foggy, and the temple was closed. While we're taking photos from the gap of the gate, a man from the shelter opened the door and told us it's off season and it's closed. We replied with smiles and he went back to the shelter. Surprisingly with a minute or two he opened the door and came up to the temple with his jacket on. He opened the side entrance and told us to take off our shoes and enter. We were shocked but followed his lead to the site where the "footprint" was situated. There's a door locked but you could peek into it from bottom. It's just amazing to get to see the real thing in front of our eyes, after so many people had told us that the temple was closed, nothing to see and asked us to turn back! It's just unbelievable! We gave some donation before we left. There's some other donation in the bowl (which was not wet) and we knew that we're not the only lucky ones. We went down with great joyfulness because we had accomplished our goal, seeing the unexpected and starting to see the greenery of the forest in the mist. The trees were really beautiful in the mist, just like in fairy tales. And the tea valley and waterfalls at the bottom of the mountain was a bonus to the hike. To conclude, it's not easy to reach the top as it takes hours to reach the top and not easy while raining, but as long as you're optimistic who knows what's waiting for you ahead. Just go for it! It's definitely something memorable, at least your legs soreness will remind you for a few days, but it's worth it.

A great experience that everyone should do in his life time its a mix between hiking, climbing and cultural knowledge you'll meet many monks along the way and visit many temples till you arrive to the top for the grand temple after passing on 5500 stairs step !! its a little bit hard to get up there but am sure its much harder to get down because your legs will be numb :D and it will stay numb for 2-3 days after but if you ever visited Sri lanka ... don't miss Adam's peak challenge :)

‚ÄúSri Pada‚Äù Adams peak though not the highest mountain of Sri Lanka, the striking pyramid of Adam's Peak (7,360 ft) is certainly the most remarkable. A depression in the rocky summit resembles a huge footprint, which has been venerated as a sacred sigh from remote antiquity. This was identified by Buddhists as the Buddha's footprint, by Hindus as that of Shiva, and by Muslims as Adam's. Later the Portuguese attributed it to St. Thomas the Apostle. Lovely amazing and historical place to see...

Climbing the Adams peak is surely a must do activity if you are in Sri Lanka. It is not an easy climb and we saw many people who were really struggling along the way. There are supposed to be around 5500 steps and it gets quite steep at times. The view of the sunrise is very beautiful from the peak and this is the reason most people  start climbing at night. We started climbing at 2:00AM and were able to reach the top at 4:45AM. This meant we had to wait in the cold weather for more than an hour before sunrise (around 6AM); but this wasnt so bad as it gave us some time to catch our breath and also meet many of the others who had come from different parts of the world. We made friends with a group of Chinese youngsters, one of whom was celebrating her birthday. We cut a cake and sang for her :) The sunrise itself was really beautiful and the view of the valley from the peak is amazing. We spent about half an hour just soaking it all up and taking pics. Getting down is obviously an easier task and we managed it in about 2 hours. We had a few aches the next day, but it was well worth it.

A must visit for an adventurer visiting Sri Lanka. Recommended to start climbing at night, so you can reach the top for sunrise. I used 2,5 hours for a medium speed ascend. In addition to all the natural dimensions of the experience, this is also really a pure cultural experience. If you don't like buddhism, this is maybe not for you. Really memorable visit.

We climbed Sri Pada in August, normally the off season and often has hazy views. We were very lucky and got up for the sunrise walk and had absolutely spectacular views. It rained a bit but was still excellent. Definitely stretch your legs afterwards though, all those stairs on the way down were a killer

On our planning trip to Sri Lanka, this was something we read about it and decided not to do. First we do not have any religion, second we do not really tried climbing and third we wanted surf, beach and sun! Well Budah, Shiva and Adam had a different plan for us! due to bad weather conditions and floods we had to adjust our journey and decided to stopover at Adam¬¥s peak before going to Colombo. Must say without being a believers, a treeking lover, it was one of the best chanlange i have done in my life! Although very demanding, you can really feel your mind getting empty by being focus on the walking steps along the way! it was raining all night, didn't¬¥t have the chance to visit the temple as it was close in low season! But worthy as personal achievement.We were 2 at start become 4 on the first steps and a dog we walked with us all the way up who we named Adam. Adam didn't¬¥t came down is karma said so. :)It took us 2 hours and half to go up, and maybe another 2 to came down.

We decided to climb Adams Peak at the start of August, after we had seen it was highly recommended by the guide books and other travellers. We climbed as a group of 3 on a Saturday, starting our ascent at 1:30am and reaching the summit at 4:30am We did have a look at other reviews/discussions from this time of year and noted a few things that were mentioned, which I have covered below. Animals: We did not see any wildlife on our climb, although as the first climbers of the day we were followed up by 2 dogs (one of which was at the bottom starting the climb with another group as we came back down). However, the climb is very eerie in the dark and when visibility is particularly poor I would suggest a group of 3 or more is best for a night climb Lighting: As has been mentioned on here the climb is not lit all year round, despite what some guide books say. If climbing at night I would recommend using head torches, as due to the gradient of the climb at some points it would be best to have both hands free. Neither of our 3 torches ran low on batteries during the climb, but it's probably worth taking at least one spare set. The climb: The start of the climb is pretty poor, with around 1km of shacks that are used as shops in the peak season. The climb itself is varied but the gradient generally increases as you move up the mountain. It was hard work but if you take your time it is very doable. No shops were open past the start of the climb. The weather: The weather was awful. We had spent 2 weeks in Galle and Colombo and despite the weather saying rain all day every day we had about 10 minutes of rain up to this point in the trip. It turns out the weather for hill country is spot on. From the minute we arrived until we left 2 nights later it was chucking it down. We were wearing goretex full waterproofs (jacket and trousers) and waterproof walking boots and within the first 30mins-1hr we were completely drenched and had to change at the top. On the way down I wore a poncho and found it was very good at keeping me dry and cool. The summit: A complete waste of time in the off season. We reached the top at around 4:30 and found it was completely deserted. It is a quite built up concrete area with no where to sit or take shelter. The footprint itself is on the very peak and is closed at this time of year, surrounded by a wall. Eventually a man who heard us came out and told us it would be closed until December, but offered tea for 100lkr. We decided to wait until sunrise at 6am, with around 30 European tourists arriving at the top in this time, all very disappointed that it was closed, with some heading straight back down before sunrise. Despite our hopes the rain persisted and all we could see of the sunrise was a blue colour to the clouds. The descent: We heard the descent had the best views, but again due to the weather we saw absolutely nothing until we reached the very bottom, where we had a beautiful view of the valley. Overall, I would suggest not attempting the climb during July or August unless there is a patch of clear weather, as the reward from achieving the climb itself is simply not worth it. The attached photo is our view from the summit at sunrise.

Hands down the BEST experience of my life! It's a hard climb and you need to give yourself enough time if you wanna reach the top by sunset! But, if you're in Sri Lanka you really should consider attempting it! Loved every minute!

I was keen to do the climb despite it being off season. Sadly many Sri Lankan's had frightened me about it saying that wild animals might attack me etc. Thankfully, I didn't see one animal the entire hike! Other than friendly dogs owned by the guides. Being off season it rained the entire hike however I found this quite refreshing! Alas the top was cloudy but I was proud to have completed the climb. Apparently there have been some clear days so it really is just luck! Only takes 2-2.5hrs to the top at this time of year if you have a moderate level of fitness. There were still about 100 of us who completed it for sunrise, it must get very busy at peak season! A guide isn't a necessity as the path is very clear I just got one as a solo traveler. Make sure you take a torch!
Lovely place to travel with a group of people.Has the most amazing view. Definitely you should add to your holiday bucket.

Stayed in Dalhousie for only 1 night with the sole purpose of climbing Adams Peak. Weather was drizzly when we arrived and progressively got worse through the night. We set the alarm for 1.30am and decided if it was very heavy rain we would not do the climb. As luck would have it there was only a fine misty drizzle and off we set at 1.55 am. Didn't  see any one else until after the half way point. This is by no means an easy climb. We are in our early 50's and have  a reasonable standard of fitness .We passed several others who would have been half our age who were having real difficulty .Made it to the top in 2 hrs 35 minutes with lots of short rest stops along the way and would have been in the first 10 to arrive. Only saw one shop open on the way up and the vendor advised us we were at the 3 km mark. The last section of the climb is particularly challenging with very steep steps which seem to go on for ever. I relied heavily on the handrails on each side to haul myself up. Weather steadily got worse and we encountered heavy rain and howling winds. Was very cold at the top and very obvious there would be no amazing sunrise ( only cloud and mist) as a reward for our efforts so we only stayed long enough at the top to get  a few photos and to put a merino clothing layer on. Others seemed quite happy to stay up there. The trip down took far longer than I thought it would - 2 hours 15 even though we hardly stopped. Feeling  the effects 1 day later in the calf muscles but no regrets. My tips would be: 1. Be prepared with a good head torch- we brought them from home. It would have been so much harder to have to hold a hand torch. We saw others just using flashlight function from their iPhone and others foolishly enough with no light. The walk is hard enough without not being able to see where you are going 2.  Wear sensible shoes and carry some thermal layers to put on when you get to the top especially if it is raining 3.  A good rain jacket is essential - the thin rain ponchos others had on were no match for the very windy and wet  conditions. We even saw several carrying umbrellas!! 4. No need to pack heaps of food and water. A few snacks and bananas and just enough water to get you through. We used a litre between the 2 of us. 5 . No need to hire a guide although I wouldn't like to do it on your own 6. Make sure you take the same track down (Hatton Road) otherwise it will add hours to your hike back In summary it is still a must do even for no sunrise  and views purely for the sense of achievement. Completing it in the dark adds to the thrill and adventure. In summary really please

I got to Hatton by train. Then I easily took a bus to Maskeliya. From there, I took a tuk tuk to Dalhousie. Dalhousie is a town full of hotels that most tourists use for the climb. The reason I took the bus to Maskeliya is to decrease the cost. I'm on a budget. The tuk tuk drivers wanted around 1500 rupee from Hatton to Dalhousie. I paid about 500 for just Maskeliya to Dalhousie (half of the trip). It's nice joining the locals on the bus. The bus ride was very fun as the driver furiously rushed up the mountain. I got to my hotel and all the guests were brought together in order for the hotel staff to go over key points about the climb. I'm guessing a lot of hotels do the same thing. Anything you need for the climb can be bought or rented at your hotel. The one thing I really suggest you bring is a strong and long-lasting headlight or flashlight. The one I rented from my hotel was extremely weak. They referred to it as a torch. My iPhone light is much stronger than this rented torch. I got up at 1:40am and started walking out the door at 1:55am. Along the way, I met a group of people who also wanted to reach the top of Adam's peak. In fact, I never felt alone going up even with my weak torch because there were so many people trying to accomplish the same thing as me - to see the sunrise at the top. It was raining, but my hotel loaned me a rain poncho. The hike was hard for me, especially since I'm out of shape. There were closed shops to the top because it's off-season. I made it to the top within 2.5 hours with frequent breaks. It was all clouds and fog when I got to the top. A guy was selling delicious tea at the top for 100 rupee per cup. The temple was closed and nobody was around to open the gate to the temple by sunrise so we all left. Took 2.5 hours getting down, which is much harder as the knees take on a lot of pressure of your weight. Going down felt longer as well because I could see where I'm going as opposed to going up in the dark where I'm focused on each step. Recommendation for a 2am journey: - climb during in-season because off-season does not have favorable odds of seeing a clear view - bring a strong, long-lasting flashlight - be prepared to change into dry clothes at the top because you're sweaty at the top with the clothes you wear and it will get cold once your body cools off from the hike and the wind blows hard up there (feels colder if it's raining) - prep as you would for a hike

Definitely worth doing during your stay in Sri Lanka. Everything we read recommended going up at 2/2:30 am and said it would take roughly three hours to climb. We woke up at this time to find it pouring with rain so left it until the morning and started at 11am. The sky was completely clear by then so we got much better views than the people we spoke to who had gone at night. The climb is very tough so pack a lot of water and snacks. Ask the locals about the forecast because by the time we got to the top the clouds were covering any views. Great sense of achievement though and definitely a must do in Sri Lanka. We stayed at Punsisi rest and found it a great place to stay for the hike.

Some advice for young and fit travelers; Don't bother to start walking 4 hours before sunrise in low season. We reached the top within 2 hours and had to survive the cold wind at the top of the mountain because we started the hike too early. So 2,5 hours is more than enough, if you want to be absolutely sure, start 3 hours before sunrise.

Not an easy climb at all. I admit I totally underestimated the challenge. Most estimates we read were 2-4hrs for the climb, thought we could do it in 2.5 but did 3.5 hrs instead. The descent was no easy task either, the climb took all our legs and left us with little to handle the 2.5hr journey down. It is not a technical climb at all, just thousands of unevenly laid steps. Unless you know for sure your legs are in good shape, please give yourself 3-4 hrs for the climb. Be aware that chances of seeing the sun rise are low during off season, we were surrounded by rain and fog/clouds the whole time up there (see photo attached). Hope you find fulfillment from completing the climb like we did, otherwise you might want to reconsider if all your hopes are on seeing the view from on top.

We went July 17,2017 which we knew was off season. Pros- No crowds to battle, very peaceful hike. Pretty rewarding to conquer a mountain :) Cons- unfortunately we didn't see the sunrise due to the fog layer Tips (from a 30yr old)- > I'm a personal trainer by profession and thought it was challenging. I made it up in 2hrs at a good pace without stopping. I would say the average person will take closer to 3hrs, and I'd budget 4hrs if you do not exercise. > Don't forget to stretch before, during and after! Your body will thank you. >Headlamps are 100% necessary if you're trying to be there for sunrise. >Have a food & water plan! Not much is open at 2-3am during off season so be sure to get water and food the night before and pack it for energy the day of the hike. > Bring layers, the top can be wet, windy and cold. >You have to pass through a temple on the way- they record your name, country of origin, and donation amount. We didn't think to bring cash and felt kind of bad about to that. Average donation appeared to be between 500-1000LKR per person. >Walking sticks are helpful for the way down to reduce impact on the knees.

We made the journey in low season, so didn't know what to expect. The climb was well worth it, especially as we made some great friends along the way. It was a clear run up to the top as there were no pilgrims, but when we reached the summit the clouds didn't part. Despite this we both found the experience worthwhile, although it may be better to climb during the day to give the clouds chance to disperse. The views will definitely be worth it in high season however. We made the climb in 2 hours and I'd say we are both fairly fit (its not overly challenging)

Adams peak is not an easily climb and I would advise a reasonable level of fitness to attempt it. Nevertheless there are plenty of places to rest and as long as you avoid climbing on a poya day (I did this), you will reach the peak in good time. I would advise climbing Adams peak at night so that you arrive when the sun is rising. I've done it and there is no better way to appreciate the views. The footprint at the top is a must see although please make sure to remove your shoes as a mark of respect. The signs for this are not very obvious. I would also advise bringing a light jacket as it does tend to get chilly closer to the top. I cannot stress how beautiful and scenic the views are from above and I would encourage all visitors and locals to climb it at least once.

Even if you have to start the hike at 2 in the morning (in order to get the sunrise) it is clearly worth the effort. 3/4 hours climbing/trekking/walking that really test your innerself but in the end when you get to the top and have the sunrise it is astonishing

Adam‚Äôs Peak (Sri Padaya) is a scared pilgrim site specially for Buddhists. They believe imprint of the summit is the footprint of Lord Buddha. Trek is very popular among tourists because of breathtaking views across its surrounding. Site area is a sanctuary. Pilgrimage season starts from December and it lasts until May. Best time to go there is between February and March. Start your climb late night and get down after watching sunrise.

We went out of season. Decided to leave at 3am with another group of 3. It took 3 hours to summit (Age 26 and 27 and in OK shape). We didn't see the sunrise because of fog and rain which of course is pure bad luck. The hike is challenging but a fun exercise. Expect SORE legs! TIPS: Expect a couple of stray dogs to follow you ALL the way to the top! Expect them to get in fight with other stray dogs over who gets to follow you. There is NO open shops so bring your own food and water! There is NO light so bring a reliable flashlight. (Sun up around 5:30) We were warned about fake monks trying to scam you and after 300meters the first fake monks awoke and tried to lure us into their "temple". Our hotel and driver warned us about these people and you can easily take the official road around their temple. Some of our party went into their lairs and were pressured to pay a 1000lkr in donations and get "special" wristbands and write their names in a book. Our hotel said that this has NOTHING to do with buddhism and a donation is never forced and the size of the donation is always up to you. Our guide and the hotel told us that NONE of the money paid here goes to the temple but only into their own pockets. If you want to donate do it at the official boxes. Beware of leeches! 4 out of a 5 party group was bitten and it bled for some hours.

What an experience!!! Make sure you have an early night the night before, I think we were asleep by 8:00pm. We woke up at 2:00am in the pitch black to start the journey. I'm not going to lie, the climb is tough. My partner and I are very fit people and we were huffing and puffing and sweating throughout. Although everyone walks at their own pace and wakes up at a time that will give them enough time to reach the top. We reached the top at 5:00am. There are lots of pit stops and tucker shops along the way to buy water and snacks. Food and drink gets more expensive the higher you get as the locals have to walk all the supplies up the hill themselves.The path is made up of concrete steps and is very well lit the whole way with street lamp style lights. Although the climb may seem hard, it is sooo worth it when you reach the top. The view is incredible. Everyone is silent as you watch the sun rise - I've never experienced anything so sureal. The descent was alot faster than the actual climb. We were down in under 2 hours. Everyone then has a big BIG breakfast - which feels very well deserved. Tips: 1. Bring a backpack with water and sugary snacks for energy. 2. Bring a jacket, beanie and gloves. The higher you get, the colder it gets. Sitting up the top is FREEZING - trust me! 3. People recommend hiring and paying for a guide 'tracker'. I would advise AGAINST this. Its very unnecessary as the path is very clear and well lit throughout. 4. Watch you're legs on the way down - they will be jelly! There are eldery monks and children as young as 5 or 6 that do this climb. Do not let people scare you into doing it. If you take you're time, pace your self and take breaks at the designated rest stops - you will be fine. It is a once in a life time experience and I would highly recommend it. It was one of the highlights of Sri Lanka for me!

Commenced the walk at 2.00am towards the end of April and the night was not unduly cold, so all the rugging up was not really needed. The stairs are a mixture of wide and easy at the start and progressively steeper and more tiring towards the end.  I highly recommend investing around $2 for some walking sticks as they helped a lot. Whilst there was a fairly large number of people doing the trek, it moved fairly steadily.  Different story at the top where there was little room to move, however, the dawn glimpse was lovely.  Took around 3.5 hrs to the top with snack stops and about 2 hrs to get down.  A gruelling but fun climb, but only once.
Do not expect that the steps is ending. You have to just keep climbing and look at the steps in the dark. If the stamina is right, you will reach the top just nice at the sunrise.

Climbed it on 14/6/17 overnight as a couple from a guesthouse in Dalhousie. Despite research, we hadn't realised how much difference it being out of season makes to the climb experience. Firstly, there are no local pilgrims and very few tourists. We saw none at all until the last 2k. Secondly, there are no lights out of season except for at a couple of police points and at the top. There are almost no shops open- we saw two the night we climbed. Thirdly, the temple at the top is locked for the entire six month out of season period (may to December) This means if you are planning to hike it between may and December, you need to take a torch, all food and water and probably a friend as it is a bit creepy being so deserted. The top becomes a bit anticlimactic as you get cold, see sunrise and wait for the temple to open at 6 until the chap who lives at the top and sells you a tea tells you it's closed. It's a great hike, hard work at the top but with stunning views between the clouds. As others have said, coming down is tough and if you have any joint issues walking poles may be sensible. It took us (young and fit-ish, don't routinely exercise other than walking) 2 hours each way. Definitely worth a go!

We started around 3 to go up the stairs and it took us around 3 hours incl breaks. And i can say that we were exhausted when we got to the top.. When we left the hostel we were warned about pickpockets and all i can say is watch your stuff because they are there. We saw around 3 groups, of 2 children and one teen,  who would hang around you and follow you. The whole time they would keep their eyes on you. So keep you stuff safe! Apart from that we had so much fun, sat and talked with some locals while we rested en the view was to die for. You have to see it yourself!

In every year in season time I use to walk to the top of Adam's Peak to warship. There are main three routes to walk up to the top. 1-Rathnapura 2- Kuruvita 3 -Nallathanniya (Hatton) 1-Rathnapura - most longest route with steps, travel through the forest 2- Kuruvita  - most Beautiful and difficult path, travel through the forest 3 -Nallathanniya (Hatton) - Shortest path and easiest. my opinion is to take the difficult path to climb up and easiest to climb down.
