Join locals as they make their holy pilgrimage to Sri Pada.  A very rewarding and spiritual experience and when you see elderly men and women walking down/up without any shoes on in the middle of the cold night to make this pilgrimage, consider yourself very fortunate to be joining with them and sharing this very special experience.  When you arrive at the summit, try to arrive for sunrise and stay around for the ceremony and chanting.  It is will worth it. Try to arrive the previous afternoon and book your accommodation for 2 nights if you have the time - that way you don't need to rush down to make your exit out of Dalhousie and can take your time enjoying the views on the way down and put yourself back to bed when you get down for a much needed rest!

Started climbing the mountain around 6:30 pm as we went on a fully crowded day .... knowing it will be bit of a hard hike we stared slowly and move on but as it was bit of a misty day senarice where beautiful.... if you are not use to this kind of a hike better take rest every hours time and go slow to the summit You have lot of shops around to buy foods and all other needs hence carry less to avoid hassle And around 10:30 we where in summit Remember this is a pilgrimage place in Sri Lanka hence if you are not Buddhist please be quiet and enjoy the view breez around you as lot of eldaries treats this as a secret place .... hike is good for your health and build your friendship among others during the journey Worth doing this at least once a life time

Adams Peak is definetly a place to visit during your stay in Sri Lanka. It might be a tough journey up the 6000 steps, but it's all worth it. You meet alot of locals and other tourists on the way up there. But expect some sore legs the day after. Would recommend to start the ascend around 1 or 2 AM, so you can see the sunrise at 6!

This is definitely one of the more gruelling climbs that I have taken part in. We started early in the morning around 2am (as is recommended) with the goal of catching the sunrise. The view from the top was breathtaking, but in my opinion if you are not the kind of person who enjoys a good workout this might not be for you.

I considered myself to be of reasonable fitness before climbing Adams peak but it was SO tough!! I am glad I did it, but pace yourself! It took us 3 hrs with a good couple of pit stops. Did love the shops along the way....the tea near the top was amazing! The views at the top were indescribable but I couldn't walk properly for at least 4 days afterwards..... I am glad I did it, but not something I would do again!!
Great hike, not too many people. We started at 3:15 and made it to the top for the 5:45 sunrise, amazing view.

My boyfriend and I climbed Adams peak a couple of days ago, the morning of 8th May and it was a unique and rewarding experience. Please be aware that the season ends on 10th May, which means that all the lights leading the way will be switched off, so ensure you take a torch or headlamp to find your way up if you are planning a sunrise climb. We set off from our hotel (Hugging clouds - near the start of the route) at 2:30am, and were soon blessed by some friendly monks at the temple near the base of the mountain (we gave a 1000 rupee donation but no pressure is applied so feel free to give as much or little as you wish). There are a couple of forks in the route near the start, however both options always seem to join back together after a few hundred meters. The first hour walk is very enjoyable, sections of steps followed by small sections of flat, there were shops and cafes selling food and drinks so we didn't need to worry about carrying much water with us (not completely sure if these are still open out of season). We travelled quite lightly, just a small backpack with a jumper, extra layers & vegtable rottis. After the first hour the trail gets a little tougher, with longer sections of steeper steps, however there are still some rest points if you need a short break. The route wasn't too crowded when we visited and so we were able to go at our own pace. We reached the top just before 4:30am and entered the temple area (the temple area covers the whole peak, so unless you go into the temple you'll have to descend the mountain slightly to wait for sunrise). You are required to remove your shoes to enter and I would advise to layer up straight away- you quickly get cold at the top once your sweat cools! We waiting for just over an hour and we were able to enjoy a picturesque sunrise, illuminating the clouds over the lake and the nearby valleys. We didn't stay at the top long, but instead started walking down, to see the sunrise at various other secluded parts of the trail. It took around two hours to walk back down and the views were lovely. We tried to do a few stretches when we got back to the hotel, to lessen the ache the next day. If you are relatively fit, then maybe set off around 3am from the base of the mountain, to limit your time in the cold waiting for the sunrise at the top. Alternatively, set off earlier and have a rest or two on the way up. As long as you go at your own steady pace, most people should be able to complete this climb (we saw very elderly people, children & people in jeans and flip flops make it to the top - impressive)! If you are climbing adam's peak for sunrise you will probably want to stay at Dalhousie/Nallathanniya the night before - there are plenty of hotels to chose from near the base of the mountain. To get here from Kandy or Ella you need to catch the train to Hatton (around three hours from either of those starting points), then catch the bus from Hatton to Dalhousie (another hour and a half). Or you should catch a tuktuk or taxi from Hatton if you don't fancy the bus. Try set off earlish if you can, so you can enjoy an early dinner & an early night. Happy climbing :)

We started our hike from hatton and we finished from rathnapura.But remember hatton road is perfect because there were so many shops and washrooms.If you go there on holidays it may be tuff to climb so try to go on week days.

I have only given this 2 stars due to the amazing views with being able to see the shadow of the mountain on the clouds after sunrise, other than that I was SO disappointed. This had been the trip I was most looking forward to prior to coming to Sri Lanka, but ended up being about the worst. The group that had gone up the night before had not made it to the top before sunrise so we left at midnight to ensure we would make it (which I was dubious about, but didn't have a choice). Making your way to the top was an interesting experience. There are so many people to say what time of night it is, with little shops at the beginning and at various points on the way up. The lights towards the top look lovely as you climb, but that is about it for the walk up. As you get closer to the top it gets more and more crowded, to the point where you are being pushed around at times. There are people sleeping everywhere making it difficult to climb at points and you are also dodging running stretcher carriers at times as they career down the mountain with collapsed people. Once at the top, there is a small temple which you literally are crushed by people to get into, then there is nothing else. We arrived at 3am so had to sit on the top of the mountain in the cold for 3 hours waiting for sunrise. The actual sunrise was quite spectacular, but the amount of people detracts from the whole experience to the point where it completely lost its magic. You then need to leave the top immediately to avoid the worst of the crowd, but you are literally crushed trying to get down. Our guide then wanted to rush us down the mountain to avoid the crowds so I had to lag behind to take in the stunning views of being up above the clouds and seeing the peaks shadow on them. On the way down reality really hits with rubbish everywhere and I was left with a feeling of sadness that such a hugely significant religious site could be treated like crap.

This is spoken of as something that every religion has some part in but it is all Buddhist. It is Buddhism everywhere, not necessarily a complaint from me but information. If you do not see value in Buddhism or think of it as idol worship it will be bothersome to you. The route, for being a pilgrimage, is extremely non serene. It is full of vendors all the way up, not meditation stops but normal kades selling tea, soda, rotis. Some are playing radio stations. There is supposed to be no smoking or drinking, signs along the way give the instruction, but it still takes place. There are also signs to keep nature clean, love mother nature and so forth but the place it literally lined with trash and rubbish. There are toilets to use for a small fee along the way, but some decide to use the side of the path, which adds to the smell. I will say I was a bit surprised at the level of defilement in an area that is so often spoken of as a revered site. But I guess each has their idea of reverence. The walk up is 5k. The first 2k are relatively easy with only slight incline. The 3rd and 4th gets a bit more challenging.  The final kilometer is a killer, heading at a very steep incline, but it's only 5k, not too bad. The difficult part is the decent. This whole thing is concrete, mostly steps, over 5000 of them. That is killer on the knees, calves, thights, feet coming down. I would not do this again for a number of reasons.

The day that I did it we had an exceptional sunrise (I've uploaded a photo). Obviously you're not guaranteed that. I'm early 40's and relatively fit - didn't have an issue with the steps. If you don't do any/much exercise you could have issues but I'd say that it shouldn't be an issue for most people. Definitely recommended - hope that you get a lucky clear day.

I am a fit 50 yo travelling with my 23 yo daughter. I was nervous about this climb, even considering abandoning it, and probably did far too much research about it, (some of it unhelpful) but figured we could always turn back if we had to. My advice is to DO IT! We departed our bungalow at 1am for the 1hr drive to Dalhousie. From there we started the walk, gentle at first, before the stairs begin in earnest! The middle section is quite gruelling with long flights of uneven stairs, but then the stairs become less steep for the final 1/3, with the final steep ascent divided by a rail into up and down sections. This section was a little crowded and the pace slows down, which is actually a good thing! It is cold at the top, so be prepared for that. Bright lights mar the sunrise somewhat, but the atmosphere is really exciting. Be sure to check out the west just after sunrise to see the weird pyramid shadow cast by the mountain. This was more spectacular than the sunrise. Don't rush down thinking it will be a bottleneck of people. It wasn't. Just a slow steady walk down; crowded at first but soon easing off beyond the place where you replace your shoes. What to take: A walking pole is such a saviour, but you only need one as there are often rails on one side; a beanie is essential, a fleece for the top and if you have bad knees a dose of anti-inflammatory before you leave. Either the walking pole or the anti inflammatories or both left me with no knee or any other pain during or after this walk, when I have suffered greatly on far easier climbs. Toilets are everywhere and are simple and clean enough for 20R. We took 2 small water bottles which was enough, but you can buy more along the way. Climbing at night means you don't get as thirsty. I would never attempt this during the day. It took us 2 1/2 hrs to get up, we spent 1 1/2 at the top and 2 1/2 to get back down. Ate only a small banana and a biscuit on the climb and returned for a huge breakfast at our accommodation. I can't recommend this highly enough...a surreal experience.

We started the hike about 1.00am and reached the peak at about 4.30am.Its very chilled in the peak so I recommend a jacket to bring with you. You should watch the sunrise from up above its a amazing experience.
Had a great time Difficult walk but worth the effort We started early morning and reached there in 3 hrs from the Siddhalepa resort where we stayed overnight Morning sunrise was fantastic
Lucky to had a chance to touch the beauty. Blessed to have a welcome tone from heaven. By the time to reach the top u feel great.

We climbed the mountain the beginning of May and decided to go with a guide as there are different routes you can take. Our guide was fantastic and let us go at our own pace and was very helpful going up the mountain. There are tea shops on the way up and a couple of toilets but beware these are disgusting and just a hole in the floor! We set off at 2am to get there for sunrise and it took us 4 hours up and 3 hours down. You have to do your research and pick your time wisely as it can get very busy during pilgrimage season and you can be queueing at the top. Physically it is probably the hardest thing I have ever done, the steps are uneven and can get very steep, especially towards the top. I had to stop a number of times for rest and it seems never ending but once you reach the top it is well worth it. If you make it for sunrise you see a shadow of the mountain cast onto the clouds and the view is beautiful. Coming down is just as hard due to the steep steps as it has alot of impact on your knees and prepare to be in pain the next day! It was a great experience though and well worth it! A Sri Lankan man we met told us they have a saying in Sri Lanka "if you never do it you are an idiot, if you do it twice you are an idiot" and I 100% agree!

I climbed with few of my friends and it was the end of the season(May).It was over crowded and some places (Mahagiridamba),we have to be in the line for more than 1.5 hours.We selected the Hatton nallathanni route. You have to start your climb in the middle of the night if you want to witness sunrise. My suggestion to get a place to stay around Nallathanni and start lightly. you can buy foods on the way to peak but prices are higher as the climb.Buy some food before the journey.

We're not young and not old, and consider ourselves reasonably fit. At least we did until we made this climb. It was very demanding physically, but well worth it when you see the sunrise from the top.

Arrived at our hotel in the afternoon before the climb. Views of Adams Peak, started at 0200, its broken into several sections and I think a nice gentle build up of stairs. To start couple of stair to flat path then sections of steep stairs to flat bits, the the end sections which is very near the top which is all very steep stairs, hand railing in parts. Toilets are all ready way up, but not very clean and smelt awful walking past, lots and lots of rubbish which again I feel they need to clean up. Summit you get amazing views, but lots of others also waiting to see. If you go up the top where Adams foot print is remember to take shoes off out of respect. Great climb and make use of the free left and foot massage at the bottom

Started the hike around 12am (advice try to start early as it's always crowded) and reaches half an hour before sunrise.  Beautiful scenes but again you need to get real early to get a good view. Don't think a guide is required just follow the masses. Pack light and enjoy

We started this walk at 2:15 in order to get to the top for sunrise.  The majority of the walk up (though fairly tough) went smoothly, and we had got 90% of the way up within about 2-2hr30.  This is when we hit the crowds.  The final 10% of the way was just a stationary line of 1000s of people, leading all the way to the top.  We, somewhat cheekily, had to resort to going up the 'down' section of the path (which was empty) to which we were glad we did, else we would never have made it to the top in time for sunrise (we only just made it).  Standing in the queues would have taken at least another 3hrs to reach the top.  If you intend to walk up Adams peak at this time of the year I would recommend starting out even earlier, purely to try and miss all of the crowds.  It was extremely busy at the top, with a lot of pushing and shoving going on, which unfortunately made watching the sunrise a rather unpleasant experience.  The views from the top were beautiful, though sadly tarnished by the the final 10% of the journey.  It is cold at the top/ waiting in queues, so bring warmer clothes to put on at this point.  The views on the way down were great, and we couldn't believe how far we had climbed.

We started walking at 2:20 and we without too many breaks we made it to near enough the top for sunrise. We found a good enough spot to watch the sunrise off the path and rejoined the queue after it had risen. We made it to the edge of the top and saw the crowds and that the view wasn't any better than what we had already seen so we turned around, it wasn't worth the crowds! Coming down was by far in a way the hardest bit so make sure you save some energy. However coming down in the light was much nicer the views are amazing. In short it's worth it if you don't mind the queues for the top.

This hike is definitely more difficult than I expected!! It's over 5000 steps to the top - steps which are very steep in parts. We did the climb in the middle of Sinhalese New Year so it was VERY busy. It took us over an hour and half to get up the last 200m as there were so many people. However, it was totally worth it for the amazing sun rise views!! Would recommend doing this for sure!

We were lucky, good weather and enough time to reach the top before sunrise, but not all who attempt this hike are going to enjoy it. It is a difficult hike - 7 km up hill, and the last 2km getting steep. It's all concrete steps, so that helps. We walked a total of 8 hours that day. We started at 1:30am and got there just at 6:15am, and it was jammed packed! It is an adventure, one time only experience, with the reward of the sunrise. If you were unlucky- rain, cold, winds, hurt knee....it's going to be not much fun. Our kids made it up and down (ages 7 and 9), but it was a struggle.

Adams Peak is advertised as a must when in sri Lanka. The trip itself is verry heavy and you should expect to be walking for minimum two hours. When you get up there is a que to see the footprint of the buddah where pictures are prohibbited. After seeing the footprint there is nothing more to see before the sunrise. So i reccomend waiting as long as you can before starting the hike. So you get less waiting time at the top (it gets cold). Due to the huge amount of people leaving after sunrise it gets caothic. But if you have the time, dont mind the cold and like an adventure this trip is Nice.

We woke up at 02:30 in the morning and started out a little later. All Sri Lankan's already went the night before so we had the mountain to ourselves first. Once on the steps we met more people and encountered the ubiquitous shops selling snacks and tea. We were even blessed by a monk, got a white dread, which he tied around our wrists. We donated 1000 lrk each. The steps became very steep at the end and legs were hurting, but we made it before sunrise. Place on top was packed since it is was also new year for the locals, but we found a spot to see the sunrise. The way back was easy with a beautiful walk through the valley back, which we did not see going up in the morning since it was dark. We were back at 08:30, had breakfast and started the rest of the day.

We climbed Adam's peak on a Friday night which should have been really busy.  However, since it was New Year the week after, everyone must have been climbing then as it wasn't too busy at all.  We made it up in around two and a half hours.  It is 5500 steps and not easy by any means.  However, unless is it mega busy, you can certainly take your time and have a few stops on the way.  If I was to do it again, I would take more steps as my legs were very sore for a few days after and rather wobbly on the climb down!  The top is a sacred site so make sure your legs and shoulders are covered.  It is also very cold and windy at the top (it is a mountain after all!) so do take warm clothes.  We were stunned by the views and the sunrise and definitely recommend it.

We started our hike up Adam's Peak at 2am on a Saturday night, thinking we would be among only a few "pilgrims" hiking at that hour. Wrong. There were thousands. And I mean thousands of Sri Lankans also make the trek. Unfortunately (or fortunately) we had chosen the last Sunday of the season to see Sri Prada, and many of the country locals were there to worship. We made it to the top by 430am, but only because our guide took us on a short cut that avoided an extraordinarily long line on another path to the top. The crushing crowd at the top made the sunrise a bit difficult to enjoy, but it was very moving to see so many Sri Lankans so determined to practice their faith; many barefooted old women climbed the long narrow stairs to the top to praise Buddha. In retrospect, my wife and I were glad to be a part of the Sri Lankan community on top of the peak, but if you don't have a taste for crowds, best to climb Adam's peak during with week, or in the off season (after March 31), when ONLY tourists make the trek. Wear good walking shoes and be prepared for a good workout! Also, if you do the trip at night, bring a dry piece of clothing to change into, and something warm, because it can get cold waiting for the sun to rise.

Adam's Peak 2,243 m (7,359 ft) tall conical mountain located in central Sri Lanka - just 40 minutes away from the Bungalow (Clovefield Villa) - Also known as Sri Pada Mountain. Usualy climbing season is from May to December but you can climb during the off season too with a Trekker. You will be able to see nice sceneries during the climb, and you must be on the top for Sun rise as you can see the sun is rising up from the Eastern Sky and the Shadow of the moountain falls in to the other side of the mountain. In a clearer day you can see up to the southern coastal belt from the Top. This is undoubtedly the most visited mountain in the country and you should visit this at least once. Great Place to be.

It's undoubtedly the most visited mountain of Sri Lanka - can be accessed from Hatton End as well as from Rathnapura End. Once you get in there you can see up to the beach in a clear day. Cold at Nights and the season is from December to May where lot of locals travels during the weekend. Nice place to be and Buddhists believes that it has the Foot Step of the Lord Buddha. It's a forest area so you can experience the nature and nice waterfalls and rivers on your way to the top. 35 minutes away from the place where i stayed Clovefield Villa.
Adam's Peak (Butterfly Mountain) it's only take two or three hours to summit this little mountain, the great one was the sunrise, it's very beautiful moment with the buddhist sound from the crowd

Should you climb Adam's Peak? If you like adventure, and a bit of a challenge: YES, it's rewarding and can be fun. If climbing ten flights of stairs leaves you begging for the sweet release of death, this is not the best of ideas. Here are some practical tips for those looking to climb Adam's Peak. WHEN TO CLIMB: In terms of weather, the best time of the year is from December to April. However, this also coincides with the pilgrimage season, which means there will be many people climbing the mountain with you. We climbed in mid-March; while there were quite a few pilgrims, it wasn't too bad. Avoid climbing on weekends, full moon (poya) days, and at the time of the Sinhalese New year (mid-April), as it will be more crowded on these days. If you wish to avoid crowds altogether, climb during the off-season, but be very mindful of the weather. It's probably best not to climb if it's rainy. In terms of time of day, you have two options again. I recommend a night-to-dawn climb, reaching the peak in time for the sunrise. Check sunrise time on the day of the climb, and begin your ascent accordingly, so that you have enough time to get to the top before sunrise. You can also choose to climb during the day, in which case bring along a hat, sunglasses and sunblock, for the sun can be quite strong. WHICH ROUTE TO TAKE: The Ratnapura route is longer. The Dalhousie route is shorter but steeper. We stayed in Maskeliya (a quiet, pretty town), and arranged for a van to pick us up at 2am on the day of the climb, to take us to Dalhousie. WHAT TO TAKE WITH YOU: Travel as light as possible because you'll regret any excess weight. Definitely carry a light jacket, especially if you're climbing before dawn: you may be sweating profusely during the climb, but it can get very windy and chilly at the peak. Consider dressing in layers. Check temperature/weather prediction before your climb, and carry rainwear if necessary. If you're climbing during pilgrimage season, there will be plenty of stalls along the entire route, selling everything from tea to RedBull, from chips to meals (all at a premium, naturally). You will not need a torch because the path will be well lit. There are quite a few small, dirty, pay-and-use toilets (charging anything from LKR 10-40; carry small-denomination notes). Take your camera: once the sun comes up, you'll be treated to some very beautiful views. Sunglasses may also be a good idea. If you're climbing off-season, it might be prudent to carry snacks (energy bars, bananas), water (electrolytes) and a torch. There are plenty of waste-bins along the route (and yet, people still litter the mountain). HOW LONG WILL IT TAKE? (These estimates are for the Dalhousie route.) If you're fit, it might take you 2 hours (inclusive of short breaks). Don't run up the mountain, though: enjoy the journey. If you're not fit, it might take you 3 to 3.5 hours, and your legs will curse you for the next few days. (Don't plan any strenuous activity immediately after the climb.) Climbing down won't be any faster if you're doing this during pilgrimage season because there will be plenty of people descending along with you. Regardless of fitness level, it's not a good idea to rush down a steep mountain: your knees will take a hit, and that will screw up the rest of your Sri Lanka trip. Set aside at least 7 hours in total for the entire trip from the base of the mountain to the top and back to the base. Include some time to relax at the top and reflect on your achievement. If you're climbing from Ratnapura, remember that it will take a bit longer. WHAT ELSE TO EXPECT: Towards the top, it might seem as if the steps never end. Just when you begin to believe you've made it to the peak, the mountain mocks you with the sight of more steps to climb, steeper than before. Don't give up! Pilgrims of all ages climb the 5000+ steps to the top. You'll see elderly people supporting themselves on crutches, trudging on uncomplainingly. You'll see parents holding infants in their arms, singing hymns as they climb. OTHER TIPS: If you want to catch the best view of the sunrise from the very top of the mountain (and take great photos), you'll have to reach the peak with at least 30 minutes to spare, manoeuvre yourself into a good spot facing east (the Dalhousie side, not the Ratnapura side), and wait patiently in the semi-darkness as pilgrims and tourists jostle to greet the sun. The limited space at the top means that it will be very crowded at the peak during pilgrimage season. Once the sun is up, the pilgrims will head for the shrine, offer prayers and start their descent; wait for the crowd to thin a bit. (During off-season, you needn't reach too early.) To walk into the shrine at the very top of the peak, you'll have to take off your shoes. After seeing the sunrise, walk over to the Ratnapura side of the peak. From this spot, you'll be able to see the eerily near-perfect conical shadow cast by Adam's Peak onto the hills over which it towers. (You might need to climb down a few steps for the best view.) There are absolutely no entry fees. When you begin your climb, you may be cajoled into making a donation. If you don't wish to donate money, it's perfectly okay to smile and politely decline: no one will be offended. You will not need a guide: there are steps leading straight up, and any seeming detours lead to the same place eventually. Lastly, if you're not quite fit but still determined to make the climb, go with a friend: you might be quite miserable otherwise. Good luck!

We travelled from Bentota to Siri Padaya with Sumi Tours. Our guide Sumi and driver Prasad couldn't do enough to assist us with our experience. Siri Padaya was amazing a 3 and 1/2 hour climb leaving the base at 2am to catch the sunrise at 6.15am. Thoroughly worth the effort but climb is challenging!!!!

my last trip to Adam's peak was the 5th one.It is really a worthy lifetime experience, the journey and the destination both!. We stayed in a hotel called 'White Elephant'prior to starting climbing at 2 am."White Elephant' is not a place that I would recommend. But the rest of the trip was really great.It took us about 4 hours to climb and 3 hours to come back but can do faster than that. We experienced the breathtaking views of the 'Sunrise' from the top of the mountain

A group of ten of us began climbing at 2am which we were advised to be the best time,  arrived to the top about thirty minutes before sunrise. Perfect timing. Very cold at the top and very busy but even the glimpse I had of the sun rising behind the clouds was worth the 6000+ steps. Legs took a bit of a beating in the days following but I would recommend and it will be the first on my list when I return to Sri Lanka. Simply amazing.

If you want a nice walk / hike up a mountain don't do this walk! We went on a Thursday night / Friday morning and the way up wasn't too bad in terms of how busy it was but the way down was ridiculous, we were getting squashed and shouted at, and there was hardly any space to come down after the sunrise. It didn't feel like a spiritual walk at all. And the path is littered with shops so the views are obscured and the locals are not educated to not throw plastic on the ground so there is a lot of rubbish around too. There isn't really a comfortable view point at the top because of the temple and other buildings they've decided to put there. The walk itself is not easy up or down, or legs were like jelly afterwards, we stretched before and after but couldn't walk properly for 3 days! Take warm clothes for the wait at the top.

I will not talk about religion etc. but only about the climbing experience. Spiritual thing is as you let it to be. We started climbing at 2AM and arrived to the top 5.30AM. We are rather sporty people but at the top we felt the speed we took. The temperature difference is around 15deg Celcius so better take some warm clothes to avoid warming up next to coconuts fire as we did :-) Going up isn't really 'climbing'. There are thousands of steps. The path, despite timing, is crowded. Looking around you will see lots of rubbish. The smell of urine is everywhere. It is just disgusting sometimes. Really bad experience. At the top all you got is waiting for sunrise in the crowd like at Rolling Stones concert. You can't really find any place to contemplate in peace. Crowded mess I'd say. I know this is spiritual place but if you're not so spiritual simply don't go, it isn't worth the effort.

It was a good experience, the exercise was needed after loafing around for some weeks. After reading some reviews I thought it would be much harder, but if you have an average level of fitness then it's just a couple of hours of huffing and puffing. If you are pretty fit you shouldn't start until at least 3am, as you will be waiting at the top cold and twiddling your thumbs. Speaking of the cold it wasn't THAT cold. I bought a thin sweater for 300 Rupees and had a hat, no problems. The sunrise was.....a sunrise!! nothing spectacular, like many others. Thankfully it didn't rain.

In amongst a superb trip to Sri Lanka this was the only low point. Despite the spiritual nature of the area and the wonderful hills the region is blessed with Adams Peak is a scar on the landscape. The path is a concrete highway of steps and mixed pavement. The "magical lighting " is not oil lamps or even full electric lights but neon strip lighting making you feel like you are walking up an urban high street. The entire route is strewn with litter and this UNESCO Nature Reserve is badly polluted by the number of pilgrims who, despite this being a holy place, can't be bothered to carry the bottle of coke they bought at one of the 1000's of stalls that line route back down with them. If you have every been on any kind of mountain/hill top at sunrise, that will be a better experience. Sharing a sunrise with 1000 selfie sticks is not that interesting. Don't waste your time, go hiking elsewhere in the area, I was gutted by how underwhelmed the experience.

Started the climb from our nearby guesthouse at 2am. It was very challenging in parts and very busy (especially at the top) however thoroughly enjoyable especially when you make it to the summit! Sunrise lovely - think we were unlucky as it was a bit misty but the views were still amazing. Definitely would recommend though be prepared for the leg ache afterwards!

Definitely worth the effort. Expect  to have sore calves for a few days..One of the best travel experiences I have ever done..The sunrise and the people  make this journey  worth every step...Don't  pack too much and don't  go too hard too early..I did it in 2 and a half hours and I'm  52 with reasonable fitness..very inspiring  to the variations of people  from the young to the  old completing this walk. So no complaints  abouts sore legs from me..

Climbing Sri Padaya was a fantastic experience. You should absolutely do it.  Here are my tips for a good trip: 1. Avoid the crowds and climb during the week and not on a Poya day. 2. Allow 3 hours. We're pretty fit and it took us a bit less than 3 hours at a leisurely pace. 3. Plan to give yourself 30 mins at the top before sunrise. You can take a look around, ring the bell, have something to eat and position yourself for a good view to the east. 4. You won't need a torch in-season. The track is lit all the way. 5. Take warm pants and a hoodie for the top.  It gets pretty cold up there! 6. Take a spare tshirt. You'll be soaked in sweat by the time you get to the top. 7. Take sunnies for the trip down. 8. Don't plan any serious climbing the days after, your legs will be sore!

One of the Sr√≠ Lanka highlights, but consider your visit. Way up take around 2 and half hour, or more. If you are not use to physical activity it could be much longer. At the top its just a half way and your leg will hurt you for nexy couple of days. At the top choose the place not like everybody else, but with a view to thr EAST :-) I like it, but its really crowded and could ruin your plans for next days.

Did the trek this year via Kuruvita trail (Erathna Route), which is approximately 16km one way and the most toughest track to the peak! During the season you have the track lit. Half the distance is without any steps just jumping over the rocks! Expect wildlife too although not much during the season... takes about 12hours to reach the peak. On the Kuruvita trail there are only a very few shops.. but there are many wayside rests (ambalama) on the way You find very few travellers on this jungle route so u can leisurely go unlike via Hatton. Take warm clothes, and edibles as its a long journey. I couldnt use my dslr most of the time as the trek uphill is very tough and risky.specially when going at night.. Started around 2pm and reached the peak at about 3.30am next day. The view of the sunrise is Spectacular!!! Suggest everyone to get down thru Hatton. (FYI Hatton route is about 10km up and down and takes about 6hrs one way.) Very tough journey! but you will enjoy this route! :)
