(FYI Hatton route is about 10km up and down and takes about 6hrs one way.) Very tough journey! but you will enjoy this route! :)

Visited for the third time. It was an amazing experience. We took Rathnapura palabaddara route.¬† It was little bit exhausting as there were lot of steps. Few tips. Better to climb during night time. If you are planning to¬† watch the sun rise ("Ira Sewaya") try to reach the summit arround 5am or reach arround 8 - 9pm on the previous day spend night there.. Because in between that, you may have to climb dawn¬† as there is no enough space at "uda maluwa" ( Summit ). In average from rathnapura side it ll take around 8hrs, from kuruwita side 10 - 12 hrs n from hatton side 4- 5 hrs(Time vary according to the¬† crew ).¬† There are enough waters sources¬† ,no need to carry heavy bottles.¬† Have some calorie dense food. Most importantly PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE DO NOT LITTLE.. Have a safe journey..

We went up at night and saw the sunrise from the top. It was a stunning moment when the Sun became visible and we saw the landscape, as we came by night. It was a little crowded sometimes the way up and on the top. Also our legs were hurting the next days we were really happy to be there. Give it a try and go by night. We startet at 1 am, so we were not in a hurry. (Were at the top 1h before sunrise)

We read a lot about Adam' Peak be gute going there. Of course we read that it is exhausting but as we are quite fit we didn't worry. We started at 1 am and were quite quick - it took us 2:50 to go up. The last part I just would not believe that the stairs wouldn't stop. As we finally made it, it was still dark but already crowded up there. We were happy to have another set of clothes with us as it was a bit cold up there and our clothes all sweaty. The sunrise was stunning and the way down was nice, too. But it still took 2:30 and felt even worse than going up. Our legs were hurting for at least two days but it really was worth it!

A scared site, well worth doing mixing with the many mainly Buddhist pilgrims and seeing the views from the top. Take something warm to wear at the top waiting for the sunrise, it is windy and chilly but by Northern European standards not cold.  Decent walking shoes or trainers, torches (the path is unlit in places and the steps vary in steepness and frequency) and we all wore walking trousers for both respect and chill factor.  Avoid the loos if possible but do take on water.  We also had some energy bars that proved useful. Calves will ache for a few days after and a reasonable degree of fitness is required. Four of us (50yrs +) did the Sri Pada climb on 19 Mar 17 setting off from Punsisi Rest House at 01:30.  Our driver had arranged the services of a local guide which we thought may have been unnecessary as essentially it's a set of steps going up and then the same set down again, what could go wrong?  The start was relatively easy, a small amount of people going up and coming down again.  It got busier and busier but we were making good time.  After a few hours our guide stopped, met with his Dad who was guiding a group of German tourists and informed us we were going to take a different route.  Torches to the ready we left the path and plunged into the jungle, scrambling up embankments and through trees and shrubs in the pitch black eventually coming out of a rough stone strewn path which after some time eventually led out onto one of the other longer but less well used paths to the top.  It was still a real effort to the top and became increasingly crowded with a queue of people going up one abreast and a queue coming down, lots of people stopped or sleeping on the path.  Eventually reaching the temple at the top, removing shoes we were amongst hundreds of people, many coming up from the original path we had set out on.  Our guides insisted they knew of a better place to see the sunrise and we started descending to a place just off the peak where we saw the magnificent sunrise.  The queue by this time on the ascent was four or five deep and extended down and up as far as the eye could see.  On our way down (after 06:30) we were asked by a Western couple how far off the top they were, they had started at 01:00 but had been stuck in the queue now for hours and were still probably 3 to 4 hours off the top.  It was only by following our guide 'off piste' that we had managed to reach the peak at all, the amount of people trying to come up the normal path had to be seen to be believed - please AVOID WEEKENDS at all costs.

I am a not sporty person at all. The adam's peak is managable (we did it in 2 1/2 hours) but it is really exhausting please keep that in mind! I think we've been extremely unlucky on our day but i was dissapointed. The whole way there are shops which keep annoying you if you just stop for a second, the top isn't a bit green at all just one temple and everything with concrete. We had bad weather so no nice sunset :( and there was this studpid annoying light! Do not stand at the stairs - the light will blind you the whole time and won't be turned off for the sunset!!! Search for a good place (where the stairs for going down are is the best place I think from where we have seen the sun rising behind the clouds) expected more so i was dissapointed a lot. The path itself (up and down) is really nice (despite the garbage) - PLEASE do not throw your garbage beside the stairs there are enough bins - hate that it looks like that!

The climb was a lot harder than expected! Most of it is stairs, so very hard on the legs. We made good time however, and were up the top with plenty of time to spare. When nearly at the summit, the police call over foreigners, and ask them to remove shoes, cover up, and keep hold of bags. Whilst it seemed a little unnecessary, it was nice that they were keeping an eye out for us. Once at the top, we waited a while for the sunrise. It does get very busy, and once the top is full, it's closed off, so leave plenty of time to get there, and be prepared to wait (in the cold!) for the sunrise to appear. Beautiful views, especially on the way back down. It was a little cloudy, but for us, this didn't detract too much. There are shops and (predictably grim) toilets along the way, so if you don't bring snacks etc, you can pick them up on the way. Most of the locals were in flip-flops, or had no shoes at all, however we saw a snake across the footpath, on the way up, so would recommend shoes.
Great trip had a big experience. Love it, first time we visited adams peak. It was amazing. Difficulty to climb. But  we did. Wish to go again

The Adam's Peak also known as "Sri Pada" is a 2,243 m (7,359 ft) tall conical mountain located in central Sri Lanka, i.e., "sacred footprint", a 1.8 m (5 ft 11 in) rock formation near the summit, which in Buddhist tradition is held to be the footprint of the Buddha, in Hindu tradition that of Shiva and in Islamic and Christian tradition that of Adam, or that of St. Thomas. In my opinion it is useless going there. It takes so many hours till you get to the peak. There are thousands and thousands of steps, it is basically a path to get to the peak till you finally see get to the top as I told you before there is a big rock there which is believed to be the "sacred footprint". And remember you also have to come all the way back! It's so hectic and hard to climb the mountain especially if you are travelling there with your family and kids. Everyone just gets tired.

I'm so glad I decided to climb Adams Peak, it was one of the highlights of my trip and something I'll never forget. I was a solo female traveller and had done lots of research prior to the climb. I can confirm you definitely do NOT need a tour guide for Adams Peak. It's so well lit, and there's thousands of other people climbing it too so you'll never be alone. It was quite tough in parts of the climb and the way down is also hard as your knees are pretty knackered by that point but it's totally worth it! Also, it's definitely a climb for all ages, I saw small children to elderly people the whole way up so you don't have to be super fit! I stayed at Daddy's guest house which was great and easy waking distance to the start. I left Daddy's about 1:45am and began my climb at 2:00am (it's a little walk to the start from all the guest houses). It took me about 3.5 hours to get to the top but it would have been quicker if it wasn't for the crowds and queues during the last 1km. What I wore for the climb: - sports / gym leggings - Trainers (you don't need hiking boots, locals do it barefoot or in flip flops which is pretty mad) - T-shirt - Long sleeved zipper / hoody At different points on the way up I got hot and and then cold but I'd say the majority of the time I had my long sleeve zipper round my waist. However you definitely need it at the top as it's much cooler and quite windy. Also, due to the crowds the climb is much slower closer to the top so you can often find yourself queuing and not moving for 5-10 mins. What to take for the climb: - A small / medium sized rucksack (sports type one) - Drinks & snacks - a bottle of water (I put some berocca in mine) and a coke (you'll need some sugar hits along the way). A packet of sweets & choc bar- I bought the drinks & sweets in the main town before the climb as it's cheaper but you can get drinks and snacks the entire way up, they are just more expensive. - Toilet roll - Phone / camera (obvs!) - A portable phone charger (you don't want your battery running out when you get to the top!) - Hand Sanitiser - Sun glasses & suncream (for the way down) -  A spare top (in case it rains) I was very lucky and saw the sunrise as it was a clear morning and I also had the perfect weather conditions as it didn't rain!  The sunrise & view was absolutely beautiful and I've never seen anything quite like it. I climbed it on a Friday morning which I knew would be busy but it wasn't too bad apart from the last 1km to the top which I did have to queue quite a bit. Try and avoid weekends if your itinerary allows it. I can't recommend doing this climb enough, you don't have to be super fit, you can take your time, there are plenty of stop off points along the way. Definitely one of my favourite parts of my Sri Lanka adventure.

We stayed in Nallathaniya for one night, just to visit Adams Peak. It is a really exhausting way up (over 5000 steps, which are all of different height and length. Some passages are really steep.) but it is definitely doable. We started at 2 am (at our guest house) and were at the top at 4:44am - sunrise was at around 6:20am... We had light rain the whole night. At first we thought we were dressed to warm but when you got near the top it got very cold and windy! (Especially if it is raining a bit). We wore a light jacket and a rain jacket over it. At the top we also wrapped us in the blanket we brought with us and were still freezing (over an hour in wet and windy environment isn't nice -.-). A lot of people were really poorly dressed (some in shorts and tank tops!?) And left before the sunrise since it was simply too cold... It also seems like locals go up there even earlier - with their flip-flops, on socks or even barefoot :-O A lot of them coming down the hill when you were climbing up and some were really really exhausted. In the end it was worth the way up and walking in the cold! The view was stunning even if it wasn't the glowing red sunrise you saw in many pictures (since it was cloudy and a bit rainy). Also to take pictures was hard since you are standing on steps side by side with lots of other tourists and locals - can't use a tripod (which would be useful in the low light) and there's a building which you have to overlook to see the sunrise! We didn't enter the temple since you should take off your shoes as usual - what we didn't wanted to do in that bad weather (even when some tourists and even locals entered with shoes on)... ...So take warm clothes with you (and maybe a fresh shirt to switch at the top!) and enjoy the view! We were there on a Monday. Weekends and on puja days it seem to be very very crowded (and you get stuck in "traffic" in the last hundreds of meters/steps without moving at all) so rather get there during the week. Also it is free of charge. At the bottom they want to tie route you through a small "temple" area where they want to persuade you to donate. Since this seemed to be a bit shady, we didn't donate anything there!
It was amazing experience. I didn't expect to see sunrise due to weather but the top was much more rewarding. It is a holy experience.

Started around 2 am from our hotel and slow paced we made it to the top after 3 hours. Last 30 mins it gets really cold. When we started at 2 am I was wondering why I need gloves, a scarf and additional wind jacket but after getting close to the summit it got really really cold and windy. I had to rent a blanket from the last cafe which was an excellent idea. It was very crowded at the top so I didnt stay long. The weather wasnt great (very cloudy) so I knew it wasnt worth to wait for the full sunrise. Going down was easy and pleasant but I got tired. I wasnt exhousted but it is a bit of a challenge.

We went up today in the morning at 2am and it took us 1h 40 min to get to the peak. We are 2 mid 20 aged men in quite good shape but in our opinion this experience can and should be done by everyone. Even locals go up there with their old grandparents and it's amazing to see how they work together to get to the peak. If you don't feel fit just try it and start early enough you will love it! Definitely a must do in Sri Lanka!
It will take time to climb up there, some people taking 2-3 hours and some 4-5 hours! It really depends on their fitness! Try roti with sambol and their coffee

We climbed Adam's peak 2 days ago, setting off at 2.30 am in the morning. It was cold once we started but we quickly warmed up whilst walking. It's a hard climb, we stopped a couple of times. I didn't enjoy the scenery leading up to the top. There are loads of 'flea market ' stalls all the way to the top taking away the feel of nature. We went on a full moon which is a Buddhist holiday so loads of locals climbed it as well. It was very crowded once we reached the top. We managed to get through the crowd at the top but decided to walk down the stairs a bit to see the sunrise.  It is worth the climb. The view from the top is amazing! You can buy water and food all the way up so no need to get it before you start. The walk down was a lot easier than up! Take dry clothes for the top. It is chilly once you stop climbing and cooled down.

This is one of the most sacred places for Buddhists all over the world. Hy especially at the dawn is breathtaking. It is wise to avoid Poyadays, and long weekend holidays, as this can be heavily crowded during those days. Best time to start climbing is 5-6 hours before dawn if climbing from Nallathanniya, or 12-14 hours before the dawn, if climbing from Ratnapura. Ratnapura trail is highly difficult and will test the physical endurance to the maximum level. It is always better to travel during the season, ie from December to May, unless seeking an adventure.

I climbed Adams Peak with my husband 2 days ago, the day after Poya. I thought it would be slightly easier than it was! The climb was very hard work, we stopped a few times but not for very long. We started the walk at 2am and got to the top at 4.00 am so had a while to wait until sunrise (6.20am) the top got very busy and was extremely cold! - Walking up Adams Peak we were boiling but I would deffinatley recommend bringing warm clothes for the top! We had planned to watch the sunrise from the top but it was so busy it felt like a penn as it's all walled with thick rails on top of the wall, if your standing against them it would be fine but if not it might be hard to see...so we climbed a few steps down and watched it from there & had a fantastic view. There wasn't a lot of clouds around so the sunrise & view was amazing, deffinatley worth climbing up all the steps! The walk down seemed easy at first but after a while of bounding down the stairs my legs and especially my knees were aching! I wouldn't say the way down is harder but it does hurt the knees a quite a bit... It's been a couple of days and the leg wobbles have finally gone but calfs and knees are still quite sore! Still can't walk down stairs that easily at the moment! When we got the village at the bottom of Adams Peak before we started the climb we were very surprised (in a good way) at how busy it was, there are lots of guest houses, restaurants etc and loads of stalls selling everything you need for the climb, rainmacks, jumpers, trousers etc. Overall very hard work, not as fit as I thought but worth it, amazing views and a great experience!
Countless other sunrises to experience on our planet that include less garbage. Less people and more of a challenge.

Do not underestimate the brutality of those steps. My legs felt like the could not hold me by the time I returned to the bottom. There's lots of tea places along the way which are really cute, be sure to add sugar for the extra energy! Bring warm clothes as it gets cold at the top while waiting for sunrise.

I am 62 and 100 kg . It took my wife and I 4and a half hours to climb and 2and a half down with plenty of stops . The path is lit all the way up from November to April when climbing stops due to season. A small torch may be useful for some shadowy steps. There are stalls with water , hot and cold drinks and food at regular intervals all the way up. There are very basic toilets at regular intervals, cafes charge a small fee for use. The path is concrete steps all the way up . It starts wide about 4 metres with flat lengths and occasionally short flights, the second stretch is similar width with continuous steps of differing height, the last part is narrower with metal handrails to the top. We started at 2am in light shower and about 20 degree c . A light polyester base layer and light waterproof is enough. At the top it 10 degrees and a bit windy. I personally did not need another layer as it was like back home in Manchester Uk. There were no leeches as mentioned by another reviewer, you would need to go off the track into bush for this to be considered an issue. The length of climb is 7 kilometres each way plus a bit each way from your hotel . Our guide advised there are 5500 steps plus a vertical ascent of 1000 metres. As he said the village is at 1100 metres altitude, this maybe more like 1100 metres ascent. Don,t worry give it a go. The local pilgrims walking with no shoes or flip flops and singing their way up is inspirational. You will need to take off your shoes at the top and queue to visit the temple and impression of Buddas foot in the rock. The sunrise and mountain top vista are sensational.

It is a special place, really tiring climb but rewarding sight! we started climbing from Nallathaniya around 2am and we reached the summit at 4:45, so waaaay before the sunrise (we went straight to the top, stopped only to make small rests-no tea drinking and eating in the stands). If you avoid the weekend or public holidays it should be enough to start at 2am. SPECIAL ADVICE: bring some insoles that you can put into your socks once you have to remove your shoes at the top. It can get really cold up there and if it is raining (as it was with us), you will thank youself :-) The scenes are breathtaking. The only sad thing is how they treat this holy place (and their nature in general) - a lot of rubbish all around.

Very beautiful sunrise above the sea of clouds. It is a must-visit in Sri Lanka if you are able to climb up 1,000 meters of stairs. Timing is very important to avoid missing the moment (the Sun doesn't wait for us). Recommend to reach the peak before 5:30AM. Both my bf and I are about the age of 30, do regular exercise. We set off from Slightly Chilled (one of the hostels/hotels at Dalhousie) at 2:20AM and reached the peak near 5AM. The way up to the peak is well paved, light-up and stores, so no worries about sturdy hiking boots, torch lights, thirst, hunger and toilets. While we will get a good amount of perspiration on the way up, it's really cold when waiting on top, so do bring enough warm clothings. Also, remember to wear or bring long pants, because it's a temple at the peak.

We started at 2 am. It was raining and cold. But you can buy everything you need up there. Also there is no need to bring food or water, you can buy it along the way. The mountain looks impressive in the dark, like a chain of lights all the way up to the top. I found it an incredible experience to go up in the dark and after sunset to be able to see what is actually around you. The hike is not to difficult. You see singing locals in flip flops :) The view from the top is just fabulous but its crowded and there is not really enough time to enjoy the view and relax because the police sends you back down

You need to start your trip at 2 am to reach there before the sunrise, people are nice and you have many spots to stop and rest with tea and coffee. Defiantly suggest you to go there... Try to get a jacket with you, 5 am its + 10 there

We read a lot of reviews about what to wear/how long it takes etc and there were mixed reports. So, this is our view, we are 2 55 year olds, I am a runner so very fit, my husband is averagely fit. 1. It is worth doing: if you like a challenge it ticks boxes; for the sunset if you are lucky enough to have a clear day, but for me the highlight was walking back down and taking in the scenery and views which were superb. 2. Age related/fitness related: I was fine on the uphill overtaking people far younger, but it does take its toll on the knees, so going down was harder. 3. Whatever fitness you can do it at your pace. Watching the locals, there are people carrying children up, very old men and ladies, so there is no excuse 4. When we climbed it was 60% Sri Lankans: 40% tourists, so that makes you think about the significance of the climb. 5. There are tea shops/toilets on the way, so there is no need to carry much other than a small bottle of water. I advise the Milo, a great treat before the final climb! 6. Clothes, we climbed in February, so cooler, it is warm ascending, it is slightly windy at the top so an extra layer is needed, going down the sun is up, so it is warmer. 7. Time it takes: we left around 2.30 and arrived at the summit about an hour too early for sunset. So with 2 stops, it is about 2.5 to 3 hours. If you are early, stop at the tea room and keep warm for a bit before the final climb. 8. It is busy at the top, if you stay outside the Temple, then get as high as you can on the steps, or stay in front of the temple somewhere on the climb up for a very clear view Consensual sigh as sun came up!!

We got up at 2am like everyone else and made the 2 hour journey up the mountain for what was one of the most spectacular sunrises I have ever seen. The mist clings to the lower reaches like a blanket and you can almost see all the way out to the coast. The one this you have to keep in mind is that you will not have this spot to yourself there are thousands of people up the top, local and foreigners all vying for a premium spot. Don't let this bother you though as all the jostling is part of the experience. We are relatively fit people and had sore calf muscles for days so be aware it is steep going with steps 85% of the time.

It was so nice (and at times very hard!) to climb Adam's peak- you start at around 2 am and get there at sunrise which is magnificent. there are lots and lots of stops where you can drink a cup of tea or coffee, buy water etc. (you have a sign before last stop so you know if you get there too early that you can keep warm there) We climbed on thursday since we heared that it's really crowden during weekends, but it was really crowded at that time too- last 100 steps or so we climbed for over a half an hour (it was not crowded until that point). I was really nervous because I didn't want to miss the sunrise, but 3, 3 and a half hours is enough time to climb (we are not in the greatest shape but we don't suck either :D, and we did make 2 or 3 stops for a tea) (near police station in Nallathaniya there is a map which we took a picture of since it shows different stops and the miles you crossed at that point- was really helpful because it helped us calculate the tempo we were having)

We are a family of four, my 2 girls aged 12 and 7 did this climb, we started at 3pm and was at the top by sunset took us 3 and half hrs. There are plenty of stops along the way, we had a lot of sweets and fizzy drinks to keep us going, we took advantage of the stops too and rested our legs. The people climbing were so nice and even sang as walking up. The last part is steep and tougher on your legs, stairs all the way to the top. I know a lot of people go at 2am and reach top for sun rise, as we had young children we wasn't sure how well the lights on the stairs will be, on our way down it was dark yes, but you cAn see the steps, some parts didn't have light, but advise you to carry a mobile with light, or a torch light. But I have to say a lot more people where climbing in the evening so on top would have been a lot more busier. My husband didn't wait in a queue to see the footprint, he was in and out, its a lot more quieter. Avoid weekends and full moons. Ask your driver or hotel staff if it's any special day before you climb. As we are Muslim and I wear a headscarf, I realised with all the Buddhist temples in Sri Lanka that we visited I was not allowed in, I was asked to take off head scarf, but anyone with head covering had to take it off, you cannot wear a hat. So before the climb I knew that there is a 90% chance I maybe not allowed in the temple. I did walk right to the top and walk around the temple no one stopped me or said anything to me, people where really nice, but didn't enter the temple with the footprint. There are toilets along the way, on the way down my youngest needed to go, it's hole in the ground, and not well kept, but when we reached the bottom there are plenty of restaurants, we used the facilities in a restaurant and got food at the same time. We found a stall at the bottom of the peak free massage on legs, and they advertising a vapour rub, cost about 2usd for the rub they didn't force us to buy we felt bad after a free good massage (that we really needed) we brought out of courtesy and tipped the staff, they didn't want to take it. I noticed that at Adams Peak that the people, even the young kids serving behind the stalls where grateful and some didn't want to take any extra money. Overall it's a great walk, you will feel in in your carves the next couple of days but, it's a great achievement.

We started the climb at 3AM, determined to reach the top before sunrise. The path is paved, well-lit and safe - being a solo female, I made my way up on my own okay. It was a looooong climb and some of the steps are really steep. There are a lot of small stores selling water, tea, coffee, etc along the way. Anyway, if you are climbing the Peak for sunrise, I would say that the best viewpoint would be by the last shop (about 100m to the top). It gets really crowded during the peak season and there aren't really much space nor a viewing deck on top! It gets really chilly on the top, keep warm!

We have done it today. Left our hotel at midnight and started the walk at around 1.20am. Most people walk from Hatton side, we did Ratapura instead. We are fools! The pain and suffering experienced climbing up is a delight in comparison to the mind bending and bone shattering agony of walking your sorry self back down again. On the same day. It's a beautiful walk, you can see and hear lots of monkeys, birds and butterflies and we barely saw any people during the night which also make it quite special but the endless steps going for 11km could break the bravest. As you hope you are almost there reaching the peak there is another thousand steep steps round the corner. Finally we reached there just after the sunrise and the views were spectacular. Not for someone who suffers from vertigo!!! I do and almost gave up on the last 200m but managed to reach the top eventually. We walked back the same route for another 7 hours and felt like crying half of the time. It's a wonderful track but for us: couple in their 30's and quite fit, it was an experience we will never repeat. Go from Hatton or return that way. Enjoy, it's worth it.

One of most sacred placed among buddists...visited for the third time...have a wonderful experience..took more than 8hours to reach to the top due to unexpected large crowd..never seen such a crowd in history...for visitors please avoid long weekends...and try to much as possible to start to climb at 9-10 in night...it will help you to climb easily without much pressure..eventhough hatton route is the shortest way it had more than 5000 steps to climb...

We have decide to climb Adam's peak on our 5 day trip to Sri Lanka. The only day available on our schedule was on Saturday, National day of Sri Lanka. We started at 1am due to expected crowds and for sunrise we were stuck for 4 hours without any movement for 2 hours, about 100m before the entrance to the sacred place. What you gonna see on top is to discover for you, not to spoil the experience. It has nice paved road, so gym shoes are great for the trek. As it looks us 7 hours to reach the top (and we very quite fit, it was just for the crowds you can see on the pictures), I highly recommend to avoid going on Friday and Saturday, as many Sri Lankans come here for their spiritual journey. The Sunrise from the top was ok, not anything spectacular after seeing sunrise from many other places around the world. The early morning climb is recommend though to avoid the heat and sun on the way. It can get pretty warm, despite parts of the trail being covered by trees. The night has a different atmosphere overall :)

The thought of starting a 2-3 hour climb at 2am was daunting but I was determined to do it and I am glad that I did. For a reasonably healthy person, the climb up although not easy is very doable. The key thing is the pace yourself, depending on your fitness level and the state of your legs. There are many pits stop on the way up so finding a place to rest and refresh is not difficult. Most reviews talk about the spectacular sunrise, which it definitely was. However, for me, the journey up was an amazing experience in itself. I was struck by the little children who with their short legs found fun in making the arduous journey up, I was gently reminded of a parent's love seeing mothers and fathers carry their little children up the stairs despite their own tiredness and reminded of people's tenacity when I saw people 1.5x my age make this same journey up with me. Once up there, make your way into the temple grounds and soak in the Buddhist chants and spirituality of the place. It is not just a great site from which to witness and take pretty sunrise pictures. It is also a great place to just be with yourself and soak up the serenity of the place in the midst of all the chaos. Despite my legs being sore for the rest of the day, I would recommend anyone who goes to Sri Lanka to try this in a heart beat.
Nice walk  5000 stairs. Beautifull sun rise and I enyoj to walk. Start by night to see. 2-4 hours depent off age and haw many people go to up

first and fore, if you have respiratory troubles or vertigo or you haven`t done intensive sport exercises for ages , please do not try to climb it otherwise do it within 6-7 hours and get lots of rest whenever you feel tired. think of carrying a little back bag with you where to put a bottle of water, hot drinks and little snacks although you can find hot drinks and food in the several coffee shops all the way to the mountain`s summit. according to your physical/health condition, climb that mountain ( 90% stairs ) at night to reach the moment that everybody looks for : the sunrise over the summit of the whole mountain. indescribable scenery indeed ! the beauty of nature keeps you speechless. just admire it with your eyes . it`s so sublime, perfectly perfect . once you do it ( up and down )you will feel extremely tired, worn out to death with curvatures in your legs and feet ( think of buying a pomade anti - curvatures), and you`ll need at least 2 days of pure relaxation ( think of programming Adam`s peak in the end of your circuit ) But you will feel happy and proud that you did it.

We left at 2:30am and easily made it up the top by 5:30am.I'm quite fit but I still found the last 1000 or so steps of the trek pretty hard!!! Unfortunately the fog ruined the sunrise for us as we couldn't see much, but it was still a great experience and I am happy we did it! Views on the way down are incredible. By the time we got back to the hotel I was quite stiff and the next day I couldn't get out of bed!!! Haha so don't plan too much for the next day!

The most holiest place on earth. This is a buddhist holy place where Lord Buddha once has climbed by foot and placed his footprint on top of the peak. He did so as the Gid Sumana Saman has invited Lord Buddha to do so. Best place on earth to view the magnificent sunriae which is very rare. Its a must visit place for every person on earth.
Awesome view, great atmosphere and an experience you will never forget, no matter if you reach the top or not.

This climb is definitely worth the effort. It's free, it's a beautiful area and the peak is majestic dominating the skyline. The only thing is, hundreds of people- locals and tourists alike, begin their journey at night and by sunrise which is the climax of the adventure there's hardly room on the summit, which stinks of rubbish. We did the trek our trek early in the morning avoiding all the crowds. We got a full night of sleep, When we summiteed around 8.00am there were only a dozen or so on the top and by 10am we were back having brunch.

My friend told me about Adam's Peak and how it was a very tough challenge. I was told it takes around 4 hours for the climb and another 3 to descent. We had a very limited time window considering our schedule here. We left from Bentota at 0300hrs in the Morning, reached Colombo at 0500hrs, from where we took a train to Hattan, reached Hattan at 1130hrs, took a bus to Nallathanniya and got to the base of the Peak at 1330 hrs,after finishing our Lunch, we started the Climb at 1400hrs. The view on the way up is Thrilling. but even when you're just a kilometer away the peak looks like it's too far. the stairs get steeper and tougher with every kilometer. On reaching the Summit,there wasn't much of a view, or maybe I was expecting too much. After spending some time at the summit, we started our descent at 1715 hrs  which we finished at 1820 hrs, Since we were planning to leave for Nuwara Eliya the same evening.there were no buses at that time, the only one would leave at 2130h rs, making our entire run useless. The Police was kind enough to find us a Tuk Tuk. All in all, it was a good experience for the challenge, not for the view.

My partner and I completed this trek from 1am. The walk is hard, very hard. We found the summit amazing, and more then just the sunrise, there are multiple religions that have affiliations with this peak, and that was the most inspiring part. The tourists that go there, have no respect for the peak or the trek itself really detract from the experience.
It was my best trip ever !! For me  the first time I went to Adam's Peak!! I had very good time with my friends .I won't forget my experience!!

We started to ascend the 5500 stairs at 2 am in the morning on a Sunday, in January, two days after full moon, so it was really high season for the pilgrims. Despite our early departure we still had to wait in the line 150m in altitude before the summit for 3 hours! Nonetheless, although we were not at the summit, we found a nice spot to watch the sun rise and it was amazing. This was one of the most beautiful moments in my entire life (and I have seen sunrises in the mountains before). The atmosphere was magic. However I think others were not so lucky as it is very important to start early enough to look out for a nice spot. You really don't want to stay in the crowd behind 3m tall bushes and see nothing when the sun shows up. Finally at the summit the spirituality of the monastery is exciting despite the crowds that make it a bit uncomfortable. Unlike most other people, we took all our luggage (backpacks) with us to go down on the other side to Ratnapura. The descent is 12000 stairs and took us 4.5 hours (including small breaks) so that we arrived at 3 pm in the valley, from where we took the 1 hour bus ride to Ratnapura. Adam's Peak is a definitive must for visitors of Sri Lanka, though you need to know that it is exhausting.

Adams Peak is an outstanding peak with a Buddhist temple at the very top. There is a path to the top which consists largely of concrete steps, just under 5900 of them. My husband and I climbed at night leaving our hotel at 1.30am and reached the summit at 5am. We were there in good time to see the sunrise at a little after 6am. It was really tough and we were exhausted when we reached the top, but I am so glad we did it. Both of us ached for about three days afterwards. But neither of us are fitness freaks so it's not surprising we ached! A lovely experience walking up the mountain with many other pilgrims, most of whom are Sri Lankan's from all over the country. Its a very inspirational place and walking up the mountain enabled us to really experience local culture and to enjoy the beauty of the landscape from the top as the sun comes up. Many of the pilgrims are elderly or carrying their children to the summit to ask for a blessing from this holy place. I would really recommend this as an activity to do if you are going to Sri Lanka, combine with visiting the tea plantations.

We are a couple in our 60's but are regular walkers and whilst we didn't find the climb up Adam's Peak easy it is achievable. We started walking at 2am and reached the summit in 2 1/2 hrs, the first third is relatively easy, the middle third is hard and the last third is very hard. The steps were well lit but are uneven and some are quite high, there are hand rails on the steeper parts. We were very lucky and had a marvelous sunrise, the summit was busy but not crowded, do take warm layers to wear when at the top as it can be windy and cold. The walk down is also a challenge but the views are wonderful and keep you going.

You can never anticipate the weather when travelling the Adam's Peak as the climate will change very often (sunshine, raining, cloudy, foggy) in a short period of time due to high mountain.  So raincoat, towel, a pair of spare sock, gloves, hiking stick (some hotels will have spares for lending) and warm clothes are highly recommended to be with you.  If you want to enter into the temple at the summit, you have to take off your shoes. We didn't follow the majority to start climbing at 2 am but 5 am so it was more easier to hike as the route was not crowded.  It took us 3 hours to the summit (first hour for the pretty flat steps while the last 2 hours for the steep stairs).  There are shops for hot food and drink on the route to the top so you can recharge your energy whenever it is necessary.  Don't forget to enjoy the awesome scenery on the way up or down.  Usually within 6 hours, you can complete the whole journey (for experienced and strong travelers, may be 1 to 1.5 hours less except during the peak hours in peak seasons). You can have meals 24 hours from the starting point so don't worry about where and when to have breakfast if you want to start climbing at 2 am (or even earlier).  Also, the price for the meals is very reasonable (I can say much cheaper than in other popular cities).

Wow what a climb! You think you're in a good shade think again. Haha! We started at 2pm and not regretting it. The climb was tough as hell but small streetshops along the way to get refreshments. Be aware that there is many people at the top and you get to stand very close! But the sunrise is all worth it. At least for us it was. It was really cold at the top so bring ekstra layers of clothes. The way down was harder than expected! Legs and mind were tired and shaking all the way down. Boundaries were pushed! Loved it

adam peak is a must visit place. good to have chance to join the activities & religion with sri lanka local people. although sunrise with fog we can't see anything but good to finish the challenge on it.

This was a challenging walk, the steps never end. I did this solo and quickly realised it would have been a lot easier with others. I was lucky to find many groups of people to walk with along the way and keep me company. It was very very cold at the top while waiting around in limited space for the sunrise.

I was unsure about climbing Adam's Peak, even after deciding to do it. I couldn't gauge the difficulty and wasn't sure I'd manage the climb. I arrived in Nallathaniya in the afternoon and started walking right away because it had stopped raining. I set out at 3.30pm and reached the top in two and a half hours - I stopped three times for five minute breaks. I managed to catch the last moments of sunrise. It took me two hours to descend. The climb was tough, but manageable. You can use the handrails at the top to help pull yourself up. As everyone says, walking back down is harder. It was dark when I descended and, although the path is lit, a torch made things easier. I walked alone and probably wouldn't do that again. There weren't many people around in the afternoon/evening, so I was alone for long stretches (a good and bad thing) and, as a woman, seemed to attract a lot of attention. Several locals stopped to check on me and whether I had anyone walking with me, they seemed to be concerned about my safety. There were also a couple of forks in the road on the way up and I needed to check I was on the right path. I met some lovely locals on the way up and down, there was a nice camaraderie despite there being so few people about. It does get cold at the top and you will sweat going up and down! You can buy food/water along the way. To give you an idea of my fitness level, I walk for 30 minutes, 5-7 days per week. A few weeks before I left for Sri Lanka, I started 'training' by walking up/down a mountain (approx 850m high) twice per day, everyday, for 10 days. I think this helped, but my legs are still a bit sore days after. This climb is special and I'm glad I did it. For me, it wasn't about the sunset (or sunrise), it was about the actual walk, the act of taking one more step every time it felt difficult. Is this a must-do? Probably not, but if you understand your motivation for doing it, I think you'll enjoy it.

My partner and I did the sunrise hike of Adam's Peak. As you must already know, it's quite the hike. It took us somewhere between 2-3 hours to summit, and nearly and equal amount of time to come back down. We were really underwhelmed by what we found when we arrived at the top. First of all, it was freezing cold and a bit windy at the top. Second of all, it was WAY too crowded. There were "seats" on a concrete wall that surrounds the temple on the very top of the mountain, but by the time the sun started coming up the police had everyone stand up so that more people could pack into the space. You get jammed in like sardines and watch the sunrise through a chain link fence. Essentially, if you're not a very tall person you'll just be watching the backs of the people in front of you, and if you can see over them, the view is marred by the dozens of cell phones everyone is waving all over taking pictures and videos for the entire hour the sun comes up. On top of it, at least the day we were these, the sunrise wasn't even pretty. There were a few streaks of pink and yellow, but it was mostly grey and drab and then just sunny. I've seen better sunrises driving to work in the morning at home. If I had to do this over, I would opt for hiking one of the less touristed mountains nearby - in the daytime when it's warm.

I was worried about this, whether I would be fit enough, would it be too crowded (we climbed on Poya), would it be littered with rubbish as some other reviewers have said. It was fabulous! Hard but great. I am of average fitness in my early 50's and it was completely doable. It took 3 hours for me - my 17 year old mostly waited for me but could have made it in much less time. I didn't stop at a tea house as I was worried about getting to the top for sunrise but had multiple short breaks (sometimes every few steps!). We left at 1.10am from slightly chilled guest house. We were there in plenty of time. Others that left at 2am the day after Poya, Friday only got to the last tea house as it was too busy. I think it's not so much or just a slow moving queue but at the top it's actually a really small area so it's like it fils up and then the last (steep) flight of stairs also fills up and you cannot get forward. I am really pleased we had a great view of the sunrise from the peak after all that effort (truly spectacular) and were also able to get to the other side to see the shadow. Climbing on Poya was fantastic- there was such a sense of camaraderie. An older local lady stroked by arm (in friendship?) during a mutual pause in climbing and a young girl also grasped my hand as if to say we are nearly there! So so lovely. Yes on the way back in the daylight you can see some rubbish but they are really trying. We were handed a bag for rubbish! And there is the odd yuk smell. Don't let that put you off. The climb down whilst I initially such a relief to be going down not up is SO tough on the old knees after 10 mins (climbing down took me 2 hours). My legs hurt when squatting or walking up stairs or even getting up from a chair! for a few days despite stretching. So all in all it's no Sunday stroll and I wouldn't make it a regular thing but I was so pleased we did it! One thing we totally underestimated is ow very very cold it is at the top. We were not well enough prepared and it felt ICY that bit wasn't fun!

Arrived Nallathaniya around 8pm after 6 hour drive from Kandy tired, sleepy and hungry. Had a quick meal and briefing from the guy who run the hotel and also gave us some advice when climbing the Peak.  Then had a couple of hour sleep and started our climb at 2am. It took us 3 and a half hour to reach the summit. The place was packed and it was pretty cold. Some people are shivering, and some looks exhausted. We patiently waited for the sun to rise and when it did, it was the most beautiful thing I have seen. The view from the summit was spectacular. It was a very hard work and I had to stop many times to catch my breath but it was all worth it in the end. It took us another 3 hours to come back down and my legs aches so badly the next day and walked like a robot. It was such a great joy and quite an achievement to able to climbed the 5,500 steps, 5 km walk and 2,243 m (7,359ft) tall mountain. Sri Pada, a very sacred and spiritual place to visit. A must do when visiting Sri Lanka.

We climbed sri pada on a semi rainy morning. Left the hotel in town at 2:15am and started the climb around 2:30am. With climbed between 2,5/3hrs excl 2 teastops. (we are 28/29, moderately fit) This made us arrive early at the top. First half was relatively easy, second half were steeper stairs without the flatter sloped parts, and was hard on our calves. Unfortunately, there were rainy clouds at the top, so we walked down for 15 minutes for a better view of the valley. No sunrise view though due to the clouds above. Walking down we had nice views but also a few stray rainshowers. Downward was a little hard on the knees. Way down took about 2hrs taking it easy excl a stop for some breakfast roti's. We thought the climb was gonna be a little easier. Now 2 days later, feeling some serious muscle recovery going on, so make sure to plan a few easy going days after this climb!

A really special experience that Sri Lanka has to offer. The hike up takes around 3 hours slow walking, leaving lots of time for toilet and tea breaks. Starting at 2:30am provides the whole walk with a special, electric atmosphere. Plenty of people around, so it's a safe walk. Dress warmly but be flexible - the lower section of the walk will have you sweating but towards the top things get chilly. Oh, and perhaps the best spot to take a break is at the top right before you enter the peak, at the last available tea house. It's lively and they serve good tea. People huddle here before sunrise. No doubt you'll visit a few spots, though. Speaking of the top, I must say I'm a bit disssappinted. Not by the views (it was foggy so I can't comment). The layout of the temple is confusing, and with the rain and fog and wind and people flying around it makes the experience disorientating. Signs are everywhere asking you to take your shoes off, but locals and tourists alike seemed to be ok with leaving them on, perhaps on account of the rain. There was a gate leading to the temple top that was half closed for some reason, making people queue up unnecessarily. Minor quibbles with the temple aside, I'd imagine this would be a fantastic sunrise spot. One day I'll get to see it...
The steps are not for the faint hearted but it's a fabulous experience and highly recommended - avoid the crowds and do it on a weekday and non Poya day.

We climbed Adam's Peak at night which is when most people do it. Ideally you see a nice sunrise, we didn't and it rained instead. Most of climbing Adam's Peak is the experience rather than anything else. At the top is a temple with Buddha's footprint in it - for Sri Lankan Buddhists this is really important and many climb it every year. As such the path is very busy with all kinds of people - young children, the elderly, sick etc and this adds to the walk. There are also shops etc all the way up selling food etc. All quite unusual. There are 5200odd steps and it is fairly tiring. No shoes allowed at the top, I went barefoot and saved my socks (very wet) maybe worth bringing a spare pair of you want to wear socks. Bring a coat or umbrella, the weather can easily change. I didn't find it that cold, even at 2am but again it could be.

If you think rising at 2am to take on 5500+ stairs is fun then this is for you- if not bypass this horrific climb. I didn't think this was going to be fun but I was hopeful the views and sunrise at the top was going to be worth the horrendous climb- boy was I wrong!  There was no sunrise as it was foggy and clouds were thick. This only made the climbing of the steep steep stairs all the much worse, after the first steps we though they couldn't get worse, we were wrong- they only kept getting steeper and steeper to the point where you had to hold on to the rails for dear life for fear of falling backwards. By this stage the legs are killing, you are gasping for air and are desperate for water, but you don't want to drink for fear of using the toilets. (Bring toilet paper). Don't be fooled by thinking going down is going to be any easier! It's harder! Your legs are shaking, your calfs are killing and you want to die. I'm sure if we saw the sunrise I would be much happier that I got up at 1.30am as advised by other reviews to climb Adams peak. My advise: check the weather for fog/clouds! Don't get up at 1.30am if you are even remotely fit, it took us 2.5 hours and then had to wait about 2 hours for the sun to rise at 6.20am. Leave at about 3.30am for ample time. Enjoy !

This can clearly be seen from Dalhousie, the small settlement where the walk begins. Sri Lankan Buddhist pilgrims walk up and sometimes down during the night but most foreign visitors start in the early hours of the morning, aiming to be at the top just before dawn. We set off at 1.30am and got to the top just after 5am. The path was brilliantly lit all the way up. The climb should not be underestimated. It is arduous and unrelenting. The track begins at a fairly low gradient winding past many stalls selling a variety of food and drink for pilgrims and souvenirs to take home. However, after about an hour the steps are much steeper and become more difficult. Amazingly there are stalls selling soft drinks, tea and coffee plus bottles of water and snacks. Even the steep steps are made of concrete and in the steepest places there are handrails. In fact the last section has handrails all the way up. On arrival at the top it was very cold and you definitely need extra layers until the sun rises. It wasn't the most majestic sunrise the day we were there but still worthwhile and atmospheric. It is extremely hard on your knees coming down, I was in much pain, but still consider the whole experience very worthwhile.

We woke up at 2am to get to the top to catch the sunrise. We started in the Whatsalla Inn hotel , and there were many people on their way to the top so I think you are never alone when going there. It was not crowded though. In the halfway we thought we wont do it, 6000 stairs, its not fun. But it is one  GREAT experience and you should definitely go there and make it to really feel Sri Lankan atmosphere there. awesome. (it took like 3 hours to get to the top )

We went to Sri Pada just before bank holiday. We were staying in Nallathaniya and the journey was easy to start from the hostel. Hostel staff gave us information of the trekking so we could easily do it our own. Trekking, hiking or walking... how to descripe journey up there was memorable. 5 hours, 20000 steps and 14 km together. Legs were quite sore few days afterwards but it was worth it! Because of the public holiday Temple on the top of the Sri Pada was packed and we could't get nice photos. Anyway, the view was awesome and beautiful all the way down (it was dark all the way up) that made you forget all the pain!
Located in a beautiful area of the southern Hill Country, this lofty peak has sparked the imagination for centuries.
Must visit place! 5500 steps, 3 hours to the top and 1,5 h back! It's not very easy, but it's so worth it!

It's really practical to stay in a guesthouse in Dalhousie, because then you don't need to do a one hour transfer in the middle of the night. You start at 2am from Dalhousie and hike for 3 hours (a lot of stairs). There are a lot of stalls on the way where you can take a break and have a tea. When we arrived at 5am at the top, we still had to wait for one hour. Make sure that you take a shirt for changing and a warm jacket, because it is quite chilly at the top. Try to find a spot where you can actually see the sunrise. Overall, it is quite nice, but very exhausting

The climb was very intense but you feel so good at the end. We are very fit so it only took us two hours to reach the peak (they suggest it takes 3hrs30mins) so leave a little later if you are fit and want to peak at sunrise. Make sure to dress warm!

First of all a warning- this is an all night trek and it is pretty strenuous. It is all steps on the way and although I would consider myself to be reasonably fit but found that this walk was difficult in parts. You need to leave in the middle of the night to be at the top for sunrise and unless you are staying nearby it is a long drive from Kandy, for example, and the roads are bumpy so there's not much chance of getting any sleep on the way. It is also very cold on the way up so make sure you bring warm clothes. If you don't have any packed then don't worry as you can buy cheap fleeces etc in the shops at the bottom. All that said this is a really different thing to do while you are on a holiday in Sri Lanka and it is so rewarding when you get to the top and then also when you get to the bottom and see how far you have walked (it is dark when you are climbing so you don't really get a sense for how high it is). It is so colourful and really interesting. There are lots of interesting religious sites on the way and tea stations where you can stop for a well deserved break. The sun rise is breathtaking. Try to time your walk so that you neither have to rush on the way up nor have to wait too long for sunrise when you are there near the top (as you will be cold and tired). This will depend on your fitness levels, how many tea breaks you want to take on the way and what time sunrise is at the time of the year. MAKE SURE YOU COME BACK DOWN THE WAY YOU CAME UP. There are two entrances/exits which will take you out different sides of the mountain so the last thing you need after a long trek is to be on your way back only to find you have to climb back up to the top to take the other exit!!!! Make sure you get a good rest before you do this and take time off to recover the next day.

The journey to the mountain and then to the summit was incredible. From staying along the coast one can catch a train to kandy and then catch a connecting train to hatton. From hatton there was a bus that ran every half hour to Adams peak. The travel was 12hrs from midigama to final destination using only public transport (approx 600 rupees). On the way back we caught a long distance tuk tuk and ten two connecting busses, this took 6hrs but cost approx 6000 rupees). The climb was tough and very cold. There were many locals making the  pilgrimage to the top, old and young. Having tea on the way up was festive as everyone tried to escape the cold conditions. I highly recommend this to anyone in Sri Lanka over December/January. The trail was light all the way to the top and it was full moon as well. No head your house needed

It was exhausting and my legs were sore for the next three days but it was totally worth it. Even if you are not in that good shape I recommend it, just take it slow. The view on top is amazing and definetly worth a 2,5 hour walk on the stairs. Just be sure to get up early enough, so you dont miss the view.

What an amazing experience! We left our hotel and started our walk at 1:50am. We are fairly fit 28/29 yr olds.  We reached the summit after two tea stops at 4:50am. When we got to the summit and temple there were lots of people gathering on the steps  just outside the temple.  We decided to use our compass on our phone and realised where everyone was sitting was facing the wrong direction and a building and lights were also in the way so we walked back to the stairs to face east. We found  and took PRIME position just to the left of the stairs that entered the temple area where it says to take off your shoes to enter the area. This was the most amazing spot and by the time there were glimpses of light people realised where we were sitting was amazing! It is very cold up the top, especially if you sweat with a backpack on whilst walking up the mountain. Luckily we took a polar fleece blanket from the hotel! We had perfect timing and weather! The toilets were surprisingly clean and the hot chocolate milo was definitely worth the wait on the way back down!

The hike requires decent fitness to do in good time but if you don't have a time limit it's achievable by most. It is quite crowded at the peak for the sunrise so it might be worth going during the day if missing that doesn't perturb you. The views coming down once the sun had risen were absolutely spectacular

We stayed in Delhousie (also called Nallathanniya) in order to do the 2am climb to Sri Pada (also called Adams Peak). Our hotel (blue sky guest house) was a 5-10 minute walk from the start of the official walk. The ascent took us 2.5 hours but we certainly could have taken our time and done it at more leisurely pace - we also know of people with little fitness who have woken at midnight to take their time on the way up and have plenty of breaks so that is a good option. There are dozens of tea houses on the way up to stop for food or drinks - though we didn't eat at any because it was too early. It is freezing at the top (and you can't wear shoes) so definitely have beanies, scarves, thick socks, thermals etc, but it gets so hot when you walk up so probably don't layer up at the bottom. There is no official cost to climb but monks will ask you for 1000 rupee as a donation at the bottom. The difficulty of the climb seems to have made the views even more spectacular. The entire top is a temple and it is hard to know in the dark where to go for sunrise, but people move around and you'll get a chance to get good views. We have had friends climb though and get a foggy day where they saw nothing, so there is a lot of luck involved!

Best seen from a far unless fit and adventurous. Best to pass if you're staying in a luxury hotel (i.e. Tea Trails, a Relais & Chateaux property) since hiking this requires waking up at 1am to begin the hike to see the sunrise.

Most people do this hike starting early in the morning around 2am. My husband and I did not care for that. Sunrises are sunrises and I didn't want to be cold and tired while doing this. We started the walk at 8am which was the best decision we made. As we were walking up loads of people were coming down. We did not find it too hot as a lot of the walk up is shaded from trees and there is a nice breeze to help with the sun. Because we started at 8am, we were pretty much the only ones going up and it was great. We could stop whenever we wanted, we never felt pressured to keep going or that we were in the way of others who can walk faster. The walk up is beautiful with great views. Once we got up to the top, it was slightly disappointing. The temple is built in a strange way that pretty much blocks your view. Because we were the only ones up at the top (since we did it at a different time than everyone else) we were able to freely walk around and find the best spots to get a great view. If you go at 2am with the crowds, you probably won't get a great view or the ideal spot to see the sunrise. If you don't care for sunrises, don't go at 2am with the crowds. Go after the sunrise and you will enjoy the hike and view much more. Also, don't think you will see the 'footprint', It is covered by the temple and be prepared to be sore for days after.

Don't underestimate this one & ignore the guide book claims of a 2-3 hr climb. That might be true if your young &/or super fit. We started the climb at 1:30am & didn't get to near the summit for sunrise until 6:30am. But there was still another hour of patience required because of a bottleneck of pilgrims & tourists near the top. Lots of tea houses along the way & places to rest. It also gets very cold at the top - so something light that cuts the wind is useful. Interesting to meet Muslims & Hindus as well as Buddhists as pilgrims. Magnificent views at the top / interesting to see many people returning before the sunrise üåÖ

My wife and I decided to do this walk for NYE, we have had a pretty rubbish year with people we love passing and so it felt like a good way to mentally have a fresh start to 2017. 2 days after our Adams Peak experience we have finally recovered! It was awesome but be prepared for a few days of pain to follow! In my option (my wife is yet to recover sufficiently to agree with me) this was our best experience in Sri Lanka, it is humbling to be walking alongside people taking part in a religious pilgrimage. Be prepared, the walk is harder than you think it will be! Over the full day we walked 6,500 steps this is the equivalent to; 4.2 times up and down the Empire State Building 10 times the number in the Eiffel Tower 17 times the number in Notre Damme Or 446 times up and down a floor in your home! Having said that it is amazing, it is a humbling experience to be part of. About 3/4 of the way up I was having a rest and got talking to a family of 2 in their mid  40s with kids ages about. 8 and 12 who I was telling them how hard work this was. They told me this was their second time and they had walked 70Km just to get to this point! Wow! Just wow! That put me in my place! The way is well lit during the main period but I wouldn't fancy doing it in the pitch black out of season. The climb goes from easy to bruitily hard by the end but there were usually people singing and very young children still running ahead of me which helps to keep you going. Sunrise is amazing as is the first 1000 steps or so in the light but after that the views are less good. If you can not get a place at the top take a seat on the stone steps near the summit which will give you a great view when the sun comes up. The walk down is hard work, stop often because you will get jelly legs! Also you get to hear the morning sermon on the way down from the speakers in the lights which is pretty cool. Our advise is don't bring too much up with you, the walk is hard enough and you can get tons of water in the main season from the tea shops, we took 3 litres of water and didn't need it. We would wholeheartedly recommend it. It took a few months to persuade my wife it was a good plan so if one of you is unsure start nagging now! Happy travels, Mr and Mrs V

My friends and I went up Adams Peak and it was a trek to remember it's absolutely beautiful at the top and can see for miles around, it took us 3 hours to reach the summit and is well worth the 5250 steps. Be careful and pack warm clothes as it does get bitterly cold at the top of the mountain.

This is view of Samanala Kanda(Butterfly mountain) Adams Peak has very long history.    There is legend according to "The Mahawansa"    ( the book of repoted our history) to remember  The first visiting of Lord Buddha signend his holly foot print on the stone. In ancient era there was a god Saman,due to his invitation The Lord buddha willed to mark the foot on the stone. Nowa days that place is covered and you can touched your forehead. Christian believe that it is the foot print of Adam(the first man,son of god) therefore they called Adam's peak. Hindus believe that it was the foot mark of God Sivwa and they come here and wash the stone that which was foot marked.they apply saffren and sandle wood to scrub the stone and drink that water(Government banned this activity  and covered after that because it caused to damaged the foot print. Muslims believe that it is foot print of god allah or prophet mohomed. How ever there are  more witness to believe this is the foot print of Lord Buddha(The histori al report of Sri Lanka-The Mahawansaya,Pahiyan monk's reports,Br Bells reports,Mr SenarathParanawitharana's reports,Ellawala Medhankara thero's reports,etc...

Nice play to visit , Nearest Hotels are around 6 KM away from top , You need to hike around 5500 stairs to reach on top , You also can enjoy the sunrise views from top , for that you have to start your journey 12 mid night, 4 to 5 hors required to reach on top. better to bring the winter jacket and penalty of water .

It is good to climb once in your life to this mountain It has lot of steps to climb up We started climbing up at 02:30 am and reached to the top before 05:00 am It is good to stay and watch sun rise The shadow reflection of this mountain looks amazing It's very cold and windy on top so it's good to carry wind proof jacket along with pullovers. We came down on same speed It took us 02 and half hours to come down

I climbed Tuesday December 27th, leaving at 2:30 a.m. and taking a very leisurely 4 hours going up and atop the summit. Even on a weekday and non-Poya day, the uppermost steps were very crowded and I had a long wait to climb the last bit. Thin clouds around the summit prevented the famous shadow from appearing, but I had beautiful views of the countryside on the way down, which took a bit over 2 hours. Badly behaving monks near the trailhead asked foreign visitors to sign registration books, then sneakily added Rs. 2,000 notations to previous entries to trick foreigners into paying that as an admission fee. Monks also offered to tie strings around visitors' wrists as a way to solicit donations. Yet just around the corner a sign stated that there's no fee to climb Adam's Peak! You can safely ignore these monks.

We hiked Sri Pada on Dec. 8, 2016, a few days before Poya day, full moon and the start of the pilgrimage season. We started at about 2:45AM and reached the top at 6:30. There were about 100 or so other hikers with us. My feeling is that this was probably the highlight of our Sri Lankan trip, amongst many many highlights. But I doubt I would do it again. Mainly because it was seriously difficult. We had great weather on the way up as we ascended , felt very close to the stars. The last 1000, 500, 100 meters were a real struggle.  Ringing the bell at the Buddhist monastery felt special and like a real sense of accomplishment. On the way down stop at "The Last Tea House" just 100 meters from the top for the best vegetable roti... kind of like a stuffed vegetable pocket sandwich in a grilled roti. The views coming down were spectacular. Hiking down took about 21/2 hours and we could feel our legs become increasingly jelly like. We did the "crab walk" for next 3 days due to the soreness in our legs. No doubt, this is a serious hike, I think even for those in excellent shape. So happy we did it.
we climbed on 28th December with my friends.started around 8'o clock in night and we reached to the top around 1 am in the morning.not very crowdy day.able to see sunset in the morning!.
